State Law reference- Illinois Municipal Code, 65 ILCS 5/1-1-1. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 2-1. - Village seal. 
(a)  The corporate seal of the village shall be circular in form and be so constructed as to impress upon paper the words "Village Seal" in a circle formed by the words "Libertyville, Lake Co., Ill." 
(b)  The seal shall be and remain in the custody of the village clerk to be used by him in all cases provided for by the ordinances of the village or the laws of the state. 
(Code 1977, § 1.10) 
State Law reference- Seal authorized, 65 ILCS 5/2-2-12. 
Sec. 2-2. - Access to records. 
(a)  In accordance with the requirements of the Freedom of Information Act [5 ILCS 140/1 et seq.], the village president, or any trustee, and the village administrator [5 ILCS 140/1 et seq.] shall, at any time so desired, have free access to the examination of all books, papers, vouchers, warrants, entries and accounts of each and every office and position of employment in the village, and all public records of the village. 
(b)  Except as otherwise provided by administrative order or ordinance, and in accordance with the requirements of the Freedom of Information Act [5 ILCS 140/1 et seq.], the public shall have access to examine village public records during normal weekday business hours when the municipal building is open. Copies of village public records shall be made available to the public only upon payment of fees as established in the annual fee ordinance. 
(c)  The village clerk shall keep a full record of all proceedings of all meetings of the board of trustees and shall make such records available for public inspection at least twenty-four (24) hours before the next regularly scheduled meeting of the board of trustees. 
Sec. 2-3. - Village logo. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful to use the official village logo for any use, exclusive of official village business, and unless with the prior approval in writing from the village administrator. 
(b)  It shall be unlawful to alter the size, color, shading, layout, font and all other changes to the official village logo without the consent and knowledge of the village administrator. 
(Ord. No. 06-O-53, § 2, 5-23-06) 
Secs. 2-4-2-10. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - PUBLIC MEETINGS 

Sec. 2-11. - Open meetings. 
    All meetings of all village boards, committees and commissions shall be held in compliance with the Open Meetings Act [5 ILCS 120/1 et seq.], as the same may, from time to time, be amended. 
Sec. 2-12. - Quorum. 
(a)  Unless otherwise expressly provided in this Code or by state law, a quorum of a board, committee or commission shall be a majority of the duly elected or appointed and serving members of that board, committee or commission. 
(b)  No business shall be transacted by any board, committee or commission without a quorum. If less than a quorum is present, the meeting may be adjourned from time to time as provided in the Open Meetings Act [5 ILCS 120/1 et seq.]. The chairman, president or, if applicable, the applicable village staff representative shall notify all members of the date of the adjourned meeting and shall also notify such other interested parties as may be designated in the vote of adjournment. 
Sec. 2-13. - Schedule. 
    A schedule of all regular meeting dates, times and places of every village board, committee and commission shall be established annually by each such board, committee and commission. The village clerk shall publish annually such schedule in a newspaper of general circulation within the village and shall post such schedules at the municipal building. 
Sec. 2-14. - Location. 
    All regular and special meetings of the board of trustees and all other village boards, committees and commissions shall be held at the municipal building unless otherwise noticed or unless adjourned to a larger facility to accommodate members of the public attending any such meeting. 
Secs. 2-15-2-25. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - BOARD OF TRUSTEES 
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 2-26. - Governing body, composition. 
    The village shall be governed by a board of trustees, which shall be elected at large and shall consist of a president and six (6) trustees. 
(Code 1977, § 2.1.1) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, 65 ILCS 5/3-12-5, 5/3-5-1, 5/3-5-2. 
Sec. 2-27. - Compensation. 
    Each trustee shall receive four thousand eight hundred dollars ($4,800.00) per annum, payable semiannually. No other salary or compensation shall be allowed any trustee. 
(Code 1977, § 2.1.3(a); Ord. No. 84-0-57, § 2, 12-26-84; Ord. No. 96-O-57, § 2, 10-8-96) 
State Law reference- Compensation of trustees, 65 ILCS 5/3-1-37. 
Sec. 2-28. - Regular meetings. 
    The board of trustees shall meet regularly on the second and fourth Tuesday of each month at 8:00 p.m. in the council room in the municipal building at 118 West Cook Avenue within the village. Any meeting of the board of trustees duly convened at the regular meeting place may be adjourned to another location by action of the board and any special meeting may be held at some other location at the discretion of the president or trustees duly calling the meeting pursuant to the provisions of this section. If any regular meeting date is a legal holiday, the regular meeting that otherwise would be held on such date shall be held on the day immediately succeeding the legal holiday at 8:00 p.m. 
(Code 1977, § 2.1.4(a); Ord. No. 89-0-51, § 1, 10-10-89; Ord. No. 99-O-28, § 2, 3-23-99) 
State Law reference- Power of board of trustees to set meeting time, place, etc., 65 ILCS 5/3-2-5, 5/3-11-13; notice of meetings, 5 ILCS 120/42.02; schedule of meetings, 5 ILCS 120/42.03. 
Sec. 2-29. - Special meetings. 
    A special meeting of the board of trustees may be called by the president or any three (3) trustees. 
(Code 1977, § 2.1.4(b)) 
State Law reference- Authority to call special meetings, 65 ILCS 5/3-2-5, 5/3-11-13; notice of meetings, 5 ILCS 120/42.02. 
Sec. 2-30. - Place and hour of meetings. 
    In case the place of the holding of an adjourned or special meeting is not otherwise designated, the meeting shall be in the village board room, and in case the hour for the holding of any such meeting is not otherwise designated, the time shall be at 8:00 p.m. of the day of the holding thereof. 
(Code 1977, § 2.1.4(d)) 
State Law reference- Authority to designate time and place of meetings, 65 ILCS 5/3-2-5, 5/3-11-13. 
Sec. 2-31. - Committees. 
    The president, subject to the approval of the board of trustees, shall appoint the members of the standing and special committees, and shall designate the chairman of each committee. The standing committees shall be as follows: 
Finance. 
License and permits. 
Fire and police. 
Parks and recreation. 
Special projects/buildings. 
Water and sewer. 
Streets. 
(Code 1977, § 2.1.5; Ord. No. 83-0-8, § 1, 5-17-83) 
Secs. 2-32-2-49. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - VILLAGE PRESIDENT[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
State Law reference- President generally, 65 ILCS 5/1-1-2.1, 5/3-5-1, 5/3-12-2, 5/3-11-1 et seq.; oath and bond, 65 ILCS 5/3-14-3; compensation of president, 65 ILCS 5/3-13-6. 

Sec. 2-50. - Term. 
    As provided by statute, the regular term of the president shall be four (4) years. 
(Code 1977, § 2.2(a)) 
State Law reference- Term of president, 65 ILCS 5/3-5-1. 
Sec. 2-51. - May be called mayor. 
    The president may be referred to as the mayor. 
State Law reference- Terms "mayor" and "president" interchangeable, 65 ILCS 5/1-1-2(8), 5/3-12-2. 
Sec. 2-52. - Supervisory powers. 
    The president shall be the chief executive officer of the village and shall perform all such duties as may be required of him by statute or ordinance. He shall have general supervision over all the executive officers of the village and over all of the employees of the village. He shall have the power and authority to inspect all books and records kept by any village officer or employee at any reasonable time. The president shall also have the powers conferred upon him by state law. 
(Code 1977, § 2.2(b)) 
Sec. 2-53. - Bond, oath and compensation. 
    Before entering upon the duties of the office, the president shall give a surety bond conditioned upon the faithful performance of his or her duties, in the sum of three thousand dollars ($3,000.00). The president shall take the oath of office prescribed by statute, and shall receive as compensation the sum of twelve thousand dollars ($12,000.00) per annum, payable semiannually. 
(Code 1977, § 2.2(c); Ord. No. 84-0-57, § 3, 12-26-84; Ord. No. 96-O-57, § 3, 10-8-96) 
Sec. 2-54. - Voting. 
    The village president may vote on any ordinance, resolution, motion, matter or question coming before the board of trustees, unless otherwise expressly prohibited by state statute. 
State Law reference- Right of president to vote, 65 ILCS 5/3-12-5, 5/3-11-14, 5/3-11-17. 
Sec. 2-55. - President pro tem. 
    If the village president is absent from any meeting of the board of trustees, the board of trustees shall, by an affirmative vote of a majority of the quorum, elect a president pro tem from those trustees present. The president pro tem shall have the same powers as the village president. Nothing in this subsection shall deprive a president pro tem from voting in his capacity as trustee, but he shall not be entitled to an additional vote in his capacity as president pro tem. 
Secs. 2-56-2-60. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 3. - RULES OF PROCEDURE[3] 

Footnotes: 
--- (3) --- 
State Law reference- Authority of board of trustees to determine its rules of procedure, 65 ILCS 5/3-12-5, 5/3-11-11. 

Sec. 2-61. - Generally. 
    The provisions of this division shall govern the meetings of the board of trustees. 
(Code 1977, § 2.1.7) 
Sec. 2-62. - Suspension of rules. 
    The rules of procedure set forth in this division shall not be suspended unless by concurrence of two-thirds of all the members of the board of trustees. 
(Code 1977, § 2.1.7(j)) 
Sec. 2-63. - Robert's Rules of Order. 
    In all matters not particularly specified in this division, the board of trustees shall be governed by Robert's Rules of Order revised for parliamentary and legislative practice. 
(Code 1977, § 2.1.7(i)) 
Sec. 2-64. - Speaking on the question. 
    Except by unanimous consent of the board of trustees, speeches on all questions shall be limited to ten (10) minutes. 
(Code 1977, § 2.1.7(a)) 
Sec. 2-65. - Voting. 
    Every member of the board of trustees present, when a question is taken shall vote, unless excused by the board or unless he may be directly interested in the question, in which case he shall not vote. Every motion shall be reduced to writing if the president or any member of the board desires it. 
(Code 1977, § 2.1.7(b); Ord. No. 91-0-66, § 1, 12-10-91) 
State Law reference- Pecuniary interests in contracts, 65 ILCS 5/3-14-4. 
Sec. 2-66. - Vote required. 
(a)  The number of votes required to pass any ordinance, resolution or motion shall be as required by state statute or applicable village code or regulation. 
(b)  Where no state statute or applicable village code or regulation specifies the number of votes required, the affirmative vote of a majority of all members of the board of trustees, including the village president, shall be necessary for the passage of any ordinance for whatever purpose, and for the passage of any resolution or motion to create any liability against the village or for the expenditure of village money. Other measures may be passed by the affirmative vote of a majority of the quorum voting thereon. 
(c)  In determining the number of votes in favor of any proposition, only a vote of "yea," "aye" or "yes" shall be counted as an affirmative vote. Votes of "abstain," "pass" or "present" or a refusal to vote shall not be counted as concurring in the vote or votes of any other members of the board of trustees but, rather, shall be ignored in determining both the number of affirmative votes and the number of negative votes on a proposition. 
State Law reference- Required votes, 65 ILCS 5/3-12-5, 5/3-11-17; quorum, 65 ILCS 5/3-11-12. 
Sec. 2-67. - Question to be stated. 
    Every question or motion, when seconded, shall be stated by the president distinctly before it is open for debate. The president may call any member to perform the duties of the chair, but such substitution shall not extend beyond an adjournment. 
(Code 1977, § 2.1.7(c)) 
Sec. 2-68. - Recordation of votes. 
    The ayes and nays upon any question coming before the board of trustees shall be taken and entered on the journal. 
(Code 1977, § 2.1.7(d)) 
Sec. 2-69. - Omnibus vote. 
    The board of trustees at any meeting may, by unanimous consent of the president and all members present, take a single vote by "ayes" and "nays" on the several questions of the passage of any two (2) or more orders, ordinances, resolutions, proclamations or motions placed together for voting purposes in a single group, and designated for such purposes on the agenda of the board as "omnibus vote agenda" matters. In such event, the "ayes" and "nays" on the omnibus vote agenda matters shall be entered in the journal under the designation "omnibus vote" and the "ayes" and "nays" on the omnibus vote agenda matters shall be entered in the journal as the "ayes" and "nays" for each such order, ordinance, resolution, proclamation or motion included in the roll call on the omnibus vote agenda or, in lieu thereof, the words "omnibus vote" shall be entered in the journal in each such case; provided, however, that by request prior to the announcement of the vote on the omnibus vote agenda, the president or any member may have his vote on any specific item recorded as "nay" or "abstain" or "excused" notwithstanding his vote of "aye" on the omnibus vote agenda. The question of the passage or failure of each order, ordinance, resolution, proclamation or motion on the omnibus vote agenda shall be determined individually by the votes so recorded. 
(Ord. No. 91-0-66, § 1, 12-10-91) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, 65 ILCS 5/3-11-17. 
Sec. 2-70. - Motion to lay on table. 
    A motion to lay on the table shall not be debatable; but a motion to lay on the table with any condition shall be subject to amendment and debate. 
(Code 1977, § 2.1.7(e)) 
Sec. 2-71. - Reconsideration of motions. 
    When a motion has once been carried in the affirmative or negative, it shall be in order for any member who voted on the side which prevailed to move a reconsideration thereof at the same meeting of the board, but not at any time thereafter. No question that has been once decided and reconsidered, and decided a second time, shall again be considered. 
(Code 1977, § 2.1.7(f)) 
Sec. 2-72. - Recordation of ordinances. 
    All ordinances passed by the board of trustees shall be consecutively numbered and recorded by the village clerk in proper books with indexes. The original shall be filed in the office of the village administrator and due proof of publication of all ordinances requiring publication shall be provided by the village clerk, and such proof or affidavit of publication shall be attached to and filed with the ordinances. The village clerk shall also notice on the book of ordinances, at the foot of the record of each ordinance, a memorandum of the date of the passage and, if published or posted, of the date of the publication or posting of such ordinance. 
Sec. 2-73. - Ordinances to be signed. 
    All ordinances passed by the board of trustees shall be signed by the village clerk together with the village president or the president pro tem, as the case may be. 
State Law reference- Recording of ordinances, 65 ILCS 5/1-2-5. 
Sec. 2-74. - Written communications. 
    Written communications received by the village need not be read in full, but the clerk may report the substance thereof only to the board and thereafter the president may refer the communication to the appropriate committee; provided, however, that any such communication shall be read in full and separately acted upon by the board if so requested by the president or any member of the board. Upon completion of the reading or reporting of all communications a motion shall be made and a vote taken relative to the referrals of such communications made by the president. 
(Code 1977, § 2.1.7(g)) 
Sec. 2-75. - Referral to committee. 
    When any new matter is introduced at any meeting, it shall be referred by the president without discussion to the appropriate committee and lay over until the next meeting, unless by the consent of two-thirds of all the trustees present the same shall be taken up for immediate consideration. 
(Code 1977, § 2.1.7(h)) 
ARTICLE IV. - OFFICERS AND EMPLOYEES[4] 
Footnotes: 
--- (4) --- 
Cross reference- Fire department, § 10-26 et seq.; police department, § 19-26 et seq. 

DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 2-76. - Elections and terms of office. 
(a)  The term of office of the trustees shall be four (4) years and until their respective successors are elected and have qualified. 
(b)  The terms of office of village president and village clerk shall be four (4) years. They shall be elected by the electors of the village at the regular village election held on the first Tuesday of April of the year 1981 and each fourth year thereafter. 
(c)  The first regular or special meeting of the corporate authorities of this municipality, held in May immediately following a general municipal election held in this village, is hereby fixed as the time for the inauguration of officers newly elected at such election. 
(d)  Vacancies in office shall be filled as prescribed by the Illinois Municipal Code, 65 ILCS 5/1-1-1 et seq., as amended. 
(Code 1977, § 2.1.2; Ord. No. 81-0-7, § 1, 3-24-81) 
State Law reference- Terms of office, 65 ILCS 5/3-5-1, 5/3-5-2, 5/3-5-9; time for installing newly elected officers, 65 ILCS 5/3-2-2; filling of vacancies, 65 ILCS 5/3-2-7, 5/3-2-8. 
Sec. 2-77. - Oath. 
    Unless otherwise specifically prescribed in this Code, each officer of the village must take and subscribe to the following oath: 
"I do solemnly swear (or affirm) that I will support the Constitution of the United States, and the Constitution of the State of Illinois, and that I will faithfully discharge the duties of the office of ___________ according to the best of my ability." 
(Code 1977, § 2.25) 
State Law reference- Required oath and filing thereof, 65 ILCS 5/3-14-3. 
Sec. 2-78. - Bond. 
    Unless otherwise specifically prescribed by this Code or state law, each officer of the village shall furnish a bond in the amount of two hundred dollars ($200.00) with security to be approved by the corporate authorities. Except for the village treasurer, an officer is in compliance with this section if the village has obtained a blanket bond covering all village officers. 
(Code 1977, § 2.26) 
State Law reference- Bond required, 65 ILCS 5/3-14-3. 
Sec. 2-79. - Indemnification. 
(a)  It is hereby found and determined that in order that all corporate authorities, commissioners, board members, officers and employees of the village may be secure in their person and property while engaging in any authorized activity within the scope of their duties or employment on behalf of the village, it is in the best interests of the village to provide the indemnities set forth in this section to all corporate authorities, commissioners, board members, officer and employees of the village. 
(b)  Subject to the provisions of this section, the village shall defend, save harmless and indemnify its current and former corporate authorities, commissioners, board members, officers or employees against any civil, criminal or administrative action, suit or proceeding instituted or threatened to be instituted against them, based upon any act, error or omission that could be reasonably construed to be within the exercise of their lawful duties or scope of employment, and against judgments, fines and other costs and liabilities, including amounts paid in settlement sustained as a result of, and reasonable expenses, including attorneys' fees, incurred in connection with the investigation, defense, adverse decision, compromise or settlement of any such action, suit or proceeding or threat thereof. 
(c)  This section shall not apply to providing defense or indemnification to any such corporate authority, commissioner, board member, officer or employee: 
(1)  In any such action, suit or proceeding instituted by or on behalf of the village against such trustee, commissioner, board member, officer or employee; 
(2)  In any criminal action against any such corporate authority, commissioner, board member, officer or employee where such person had no reasonable cause to believe that his actions were lawful; 
(3)  In any action where such corporate authority, commissioner, board member, officer or employee fails or refuses to cooperate reasonably with the village in investigating and defending such action through counsel approved by the village; or 
(4)  With respect to the settlement or compromise of any action unless the village has first approved such settlement or compromise. 
(d)  Any defense, hold harmless or indemnification under this section shall be provided by the village only upon a determination that such defense, hold harmless or indemnification is proper under the standards set forth in this section. Such determination shall be made: 
(1)  By the village by a majority vote of a quorum of the corporate authorities composed of only such members of the corporate authority who are not parties to such action, suit or proceedings; or 
(2)  If such a quorum is not obtainable, or, even if obtainable, if a quorum of disinterested persons as aforesaid so directs, by independent legal counsel, in a written opinion. 
The validity of any such determination shall be subject to judicial challenge by the person seeking the defense, hold harmless or indemnity and, if such challenge is successful, the village shall pay the costs and expenses thereof, including reasonable attorneys' fees. 
(e)  The rights expressed in this section shall not be exclusive of any other rights which any current or former corporate authority, commissioner, board member, officer or employee may have as a matter of law. The foregoing rights shall, in the case of the death of the corporate authority, commissioner, board member, officer or employee, accrue to the benefit of his successors. 
(f)  The liability of the village for payments under this section may be insured to the extent permitted by law but to the extent not insured shall be payable out of the funds and monies of the village. 
(g)  Nothing in this section shall be deemed to limit or modify the authority of the village under state law to defend or indemnify parties or persons as otherwise provided and permitted by law. 
(Ord. No. 84-0-5, §§ 1-5, 2-28-84) 
State Law reference- Local Governmental and Governmental Employees Tort Immunity Act, 745 ILCS 10/1-101 et seq.; indemnification of police officers, 65 ILCS 5/1-4-6, 5/1-4-8. 
Sec. 2-80. - Duties generally. 
(a)  In addition to the duties provided for in this Code, each village officer and employee shall perform such duties, and be subject to such other lawful rules and regulations, as the board of trustees may require or as the village administrator may lawfully establish. 
(b)  Any village officer or employee assigned to any department or division of the village may be required to perform work in any other department or division by the village administrator, or as may be required by resolution or ordinance of the board of trustees. 
Sec. 2-81. - Surrender of effects of office. 
    Any elected or appointed village officer or employee whose term of elected office, appointment or employment shall have expired or been terminated or whose office or position is vacated by his resignation, discharge, inability to serve, or for any other reason prior to its expiration shall, immediately upon the expiration of his term or the vacating of his position, as the case may be, and in any event not later than five (5) days after notification or request by the village administrator or the village president, deliver to the village administrator all books, maps, keys, badges, property and effects of every description that may be in his possession and belonging to the village or pertaining to his office. 
State Law reference- Delivery of office to successor, 65 ILCS 5/3-14-2. 
Sec. 2-82. - Personnel manual adopted. 
    The personnel manual approved by the village board is adopted by reference. 
State Law reference- Adoption by reference, 65 ILCS 5/1-3-1 et seq., 50 ILCS 220/1 et seq. 
Sec. 2-83. - STATE OFficials and Employees Ethic Act. 
(a)  The regulations of Sections 5-15 (5 ILCS 430/5-15) and Article 10 (5 ILCS 430/10-10 through 10-40) of the State Officials and Employees Ethics Act, 5 ILCS 430/1-1 et seq., (hereinafter referred to as the "act" in this section) are hereby adopted by reference and made applicable to the officers and employees of the village to the extent required by 5 ILCS 430/70-5. 
(b)  The solicitation or acceptance of gifts prohibited to be solicited or accepted under the act, by any officer or any employee of the city/village, is hereby prohibited. 
(c)  The offering or making of gifts prohibited to be offered or made to an officer or employee of the village under the act, is hereby prohibited. 
(d)  The participation in political activities prohibited under the act, by any officer or employee of the village, is hereby prohibited. 
(e)  For purposes of this section, the terms "officer" and "employee" shall be defined as set forth in 5 ILCS 430/70-5(c). 
(f)  The penalties for violations of this section shall be the same as those penalties set forth in 5 ILCS 430/50-5 for similar violations of the act. 
(g)  This section repeals Village of Libertyville Ordinance 99-O-52 (sections 2-99 through 2-104) but does not repeal or otherwise amend or modify any other existing ordinances or policies which regulate the conduct of village officers and employees. To the extent that any such existing ordinances or policies are less restrictive than this section, however, the provisions of this section shall prevail in accordance with the provisions of 5 ILCS 430/70-5(a). 
(h)  Any amendment to the act that becomes effective after the effective date of this section shall be incorporated into this section by reference and shall be applicable to the solicitation, acceptance, offering and making of gifts and to prohibited political activities. However, any amendment that makes its provisions optional for adoption by municipalities shall not be incorporated into this section by reference without formal action by the corporate authorities of the village. 
(i)  If the Illinois Supreme Court declares the act unconstitutional in its entirety, then this section shall be repealed as of the date that the Illinois Supreme Court's decision becomes final and not subject to any further appeals or rehearings. This section shall be deemed repealed without further action by the corporate authorities of the village if the act is found unconstitutional by the Illinois Supreme Court. 
(j)  If the Illinois Supreme Court declares part of the act unconstitutional but upholds the constitutionality of the remainder of the act, or does not address the remainder of the act, then the remainder of the act as adopted by this section shall remain in full force and effect; however, that part of this section relating to the part of the act found unconstitutional shall be deemed repealed without further action by the corporate authorities of the village. 
(Ord. No. 04-O-35, § 1, 5-11-04) 
Secs. 2-84-2-91. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - SPECIFIC OFFICERS AND EMPLOYEES[5] 

Footnotes: 
--- (5) --- 
Cross reference- Animal warden, § 5-3. 

Sec. 2-92. - Clerk. 
(a)  Election and term. The village clerk shall be elected and serve for a four-year term and until his successor is elected and qualified, as provided by statute. 
(b)  Oath, bond. The clerk, before entering upon the duties of his office, shall take the oath of office prescribed by law, and shall execute a bond to the village in the penal sum of three thousand dollars ($3,000.00), with security as shall be approved by the president and board of trustees, conditioned for the faithful performance of the duties of his office, and the payment of all moneys that may be received by him, according to law and ordinance. The bond shall be filed with the treasurer. 
(c)  Powers and duties. The village clerk has the powers and duties provided for by state law. 
(d)  Office. The clerk shall keep his office in the municipal building or at such other place as the board of trustees may direct. 
(e)  Compensation. The compensation of the village clerk is four thousand eight hundred dollars ($4,800.00) per annum, payable semiannually. 
(Code 1977, § 2.3; Ord. No. 84-0-57, § 4, 12-26-84; Ord. No. 96-O-57, § 4, 10-8-96) 
State Law reference- Village clerk generally, 65 ILCS 5/3-5-9, 5/3-10-7 et seq.; oath and bond, 65 ILCS 5/3-14-3; limitations on compensation of clerk, 65 ILCS 5/3-13-1. 
Sec. 2-93. - Deputy village clerk. 
(a)  The village clerk is hereby authorized to appoint one (1) deputy clerk who, without limitation, shall have the power and duty to execute all documents, papers, receipts, orders, checks and other instruments required by any law to be executed by the village clerk, to affix the corporate seal thereto whenever required, and to make such records and perform any and all duties and functions performable by the village clerk. Any such appointment may be revoked at any time and a new appointment may thereafter be made if desired. Any such appointment, however, shall run concurrently with the village clerk's term of office unless sooner terminated. An original of the instrument making an appointment of a deputy by the village clerk shall be filed and shall remain on file in the office of the village clerk. Any person accepting an appointment as deputy of the village clerk hereunder shall take and subscribe the same oath or affirmation as is required of village officers and such oath or affirmation shall be filed and remain on file in the office of the village clerk. The deputy clerk shall be bonded in the same manner as the village clerk. 
(b)  In signing any documents, the deputy clerk shall sign the name of the clerk with the word "by" and the deputy clerk's own name and the words "deputy clerk." 
(c)  The powers and duties of the deputy clerk shall be exercised only in the absence of the clerk from the place where the clerk's office is maintained, and only when either written direction has been given by the clerk to such deputy clerk to exercise such power or the corporate authorities have determined by resolution that the clerk is temporarily or permanently incapacitated to perform such function. 
(d)  When duly authorized for the signature affixed by any such deputy in the manner hereinabove prescribed on any document, including but not limited to contracts, bonds, or other obligations of the village, such document shall have the same effect as if the documents so executed had been signed by the clerk in person. 
(Code 1977, § 2.6) 
State Law reference- Deputy clerk, 65 ILCS 5/3-10-9. 
Sec. 2-94. - Village administrator. 
(a)  Appointment. The village administrator shall be appointed by the village president subject to the majority approval of the board of trustees for an indefinite term. He shall be chosen for his executive and administrative qualifications with special reference to his actual experience in or his knowledge of accepted practice in respect to the duties of his office hereinafter set forth. At the time of his appointment he need not be a resident of the village, but during his tenure of office he shall reside within the village. No trustee shall receive such appointment while he is serving in that capacity. 
(b)  Removal. The board of trustees may remove the village administrator by formal action at any time, for any reason or no reason, by a majority vote of its members. 
(c)  Chief administrative officer. The village administrator shall be the chief administrative officer of the village. He may head one (1) or more departments and shall be responsible to the village board for the proper administration of all affairs of the village, excepting such affairs or matters as the board of trustees may from time to time determine shall be under their direct control and supervision. 
(d)  Powers and duties. All provisions contained in this section shall be subject to the exceptions set forth in subsection (c) above. To the ends hereinbefore contemplated, but subject to the exceptions and qualifications hereinbefore set forth, the village administrator shall have power and shall be required to: 
(1)  Appoint, and when necessary for the good of the village suspend or remove any employee of the village, excepting any enumerated below; provided further, that he may authorize the head of a department or office under his control to appoint, suspend, or remove subordinates in such department or office. 
(2)  Recommend to the president and board of trustees the appointment, suspension or removal of the following officers, employees and persons retained for services to the village: village attorney, finance director/treasurer, police chief, fire chief, director of public works, recreation and sports complex director, director of ESDA and any others which are by village ordinance or other applicable provision to be appointed by the board of trustees or its president. 
(3)  Prepare the budget annually and submit it to the village board together with a message describing the important features and be responsible for its administration after adoption. 
(4)  Prepare and submit to the board of trustees as of the end of the fiscal year a complete report on the finances and administrative activities of the village of the preceding year. 
(5)  Keep the board of trustees advised of the financial condition and future needs of the village, and make such recommendations as he may deem desirable. 
(6)  Recommend to the board of trustees a standard schedule of pay for each appointive office and position in the village service, including minimum, intermediate, and maximum rates. 
(7)  Recommend to the board of trustees, from time to time, adoption of such measures as he may deem necessary or expedient for the health, safety, or welfare of the community or for the improvement of administrative services. 
(8)  Recommend to the board of trustees the creating, consolidating and combining of offices, positions, departments or units of the administrative and executive departments of the village. 
(9)  Attend all meetings of the board of trustees unless excused therefrom and take part in the discussion of all matters coming before the board. He shall be entitled to notice of all meetings of the board. 
(10)  Supervise the purchase of all materials, supplies and equipment for which funds are provided in the budget; let contracts necessary for operation or maintenance of village services for amounts not exceeding twenty thousand dollars ($20,000.00). For a purchase of more than twenty thousand dollars ($20,000.00), such bids shall be presented to the board of trustees for approval or rejection. The administrator may issue such rules governing purchasing procedures within the administrative organization as the board shall approve. 
(11)  See that all laws and ordinances are duly enforced. 
(12)  Investigate the affairs of any department or division under his jurisdiction. Investigate all complaints in relation to matters under his jurisdiction concerning the administration of the government of the village, and in regard to service maintained by the public utilities in the village, and see that all franchises, permits, and privileges granted by the village are faithfully observed. 
(13)  Devote his entire time to the discharge of his official duties. 
(14)  Perform such other duties as may be required by the board of trustees not inconsistent with the provisions of this Code or village ordinances. 
(15)  It is the intent of this section that the village administrator is the chief administrative officer and except for the purpose of inquiry, the board of trustees and its members shall deal through the village administrator. 
(16)  The village administrator shall furnish a surety bond in the amount of ten thousand dollars ($10,000.00) to be approved by the village board, such bond to be conditioned on the faithful performance of his duties. The premium of the bond shall be paid by the village. 
(17)  The village administrator shall receive such compensation as the village board shall determine from time to time by ordinance or resolution. 
(18)  Take or direct all actions necessary or appropriate to prevent, abate or redress any violations of any village code, ordinance or regulation, including without limitation the issuance of, or causing to be issued, citations to recover fines and impose penalties for any violation, which citation may encompass more than one day, and the institution of, or causing to be instituted, in the name of the village, any and all actions, legal or equitable, that may be required for the enforcement of any village code, ordinance or regulation, or to enforce penalties or fines imposed pursuant to the statutes of the state or any village code, ordinance or regulation. 
(19)  Appoint an assistant to the village administrator. 
(20)  Appoint an assistant to the village director of finance. 
(e)  Oath. The village administrator, before entering upon the duties of the office, shall take and subscribe the same oath or affirmation as is required of village officers and such oath or affirmation shall be filed and remain on file in the office of the village clerk. 
(f)  Absence or vacancy. If the village administrator shall be absent from the village or incapacitated so that he cannot perform the duties of his position, he, or in his absence the village president, shall designate an officer to act as village administrator during such absence or incapacity. In the event of any department head vacancy, the village administrator may serve ex officio in such position unless and until a separate appointment to fill such vacancy has been made. 
(Code 1977, § 2.8; Ord. No. 87-0-28, § 1, 7-7-87; Ord. No. 90-0-54, § 5, 12-11-90; Ord. No. 91-0-69, § 1, 12-17-91; Ord. No. 93-0-45, § 2, 9-28-93; Ord. No. 94-0-52, § 4, 10-11-94; Ord. No. 99-O-28, §§ 3, 4, 3-23-99; Ord. No. 10-O-80, § 2, 9-14-10; Ord. No. 17-O-85, § 2, 10-10-17; Ord. No. 18-O-26, § 2, 5-22-18) 
State Law reference- Oath and bond, 65 ILCS 5/3-14-3. 
Sec. 2-95. - Treasurer. 
(a)  Office created. There is hereby created the office of village treasurer. 
(b)  Appointment and term. The president shall, by and with the advice and consent of the board of trustees, at the first regular meeting in May of each year, appoint a village treasurer for the ensuing fiscal year. 
(c)  Qualifications. The village treasurer shall be, at the time of appointment, a person having knowledge and experience of accepted practices in respect of municipal finance, and particularly in respect of the functions and duties of the office as hereinafter specified. 
(d)  Oath, bond. The village treasurer, before entering upon the duties of the office, shall take the oath prescribed by law, and shall execute and file with the village clerk a surety bond to the village in a penal sum required by statute. The cost of such bond shall be paid by the village. 
(e)  Powers and duties. The village treasurer shall have the powers and duties provided by state law. 
(f)  Assistant to the village treasurer. The village director of finance or the assistant to the village director of finance, as designated by the village administrator, shall serve as the assistant to the village treasurer to perform any and all of the duties and obligations of the village treasurer in his absence, except to the extent prohibited by state law. 
(Code 1977, § 2.4; Ord. No. 90-0-4, § 1, 2-27-90; Ord. No. 90-0-54, § 1, 12-11-90; Ord. No. 94-0-47, § 2, 9-27-94) 
State Law reference- Treasurer authorized, 65 ILCS 5/3-8-1; oath and bond, 65 ILCS 5/3-14-3; duties of treasurer, 65 ILCS 5/3-10-1 et seq. 
Sec. 2-96. - Legal counsel. 
    No office of corporation counsel, municipal attorney or village attorney has been created hereunder and none shall exist for the village. The employment of any such title shall not be construed to create any office but may be used to indicate the type of legal service to be rendered for the village by the person that may be referred to by such terminology. The attorney, attorneys, and firm or firms of attorneys, employed from time to time respectively, to render legal services for the village, shall be regarded as an independent contractor or contractors. Such employment shall be by action of the corporate authorities of the village or may be effected as authorized by the corporate authorities, and may be upon such terms and conditions as the corporate authorities may stipulate or approve. 
(Code 1977, § 2.9) 
Sec. 2-97. - Director of finance. 
(a)  Position created. There is hereby created the position of village director of finance, a position of employment with the village. 
(b)  Appointment, term and removal. The president shall, by and with the advice and consent of the board of trustees, appoint a village director of finance, who shall serve for an indefinite term at the pleasure of the president and board of trustees. The village director of finance may be removed at any time, with or without cause, by the president and board of trustees, voting jointly. 
(c)  Qualifications. The village director of finance shall be, at the time of appointment, a person having knowledge and experience of accepted practices in respect of municipal finance, budgeting and accounting, and particularly in respect of the functions and duties of the office, as hereinafter specified. 
(d)  Oath, bond. The village director of finance, before entering upon the duties of the office, shall take the oath prescribed by law, and shall execute and file with the village clerk a surety bond to the village in a penal sum determined by the president and board of trustees at the time of appointment. The cost of such bond shall be paid by the village. 
(e)  Compensation. The compensation of the village director of finance shall be fixed from time to time by the president and board of trustees. 
(f)  Powers and duties. The village director of finance shall be subject to the authority and direction of the administrator and shall have the duties and responsibilities delegated to him by the village administrator. Subject to such authority, direction and delegation and subject to the statutory powers of the village treasurer and village budget officer, the village director of finance shall be responsible for developing, managing and maintaining all financial, budgeting and accounting plans, programs and functions of the village. 
(Ord. No. 90-0-54, § 2, 12-11-90; Ord. No. 91-0-67, § 2, 12-10-91) 
Sec. 2-98. - Budget officer. 
(a)  Office created. There is hereby created the office of budget officer. 
(b)  Designation, term and removal. The president shall, by and with the advice and consent of the board of trustees, designate a village budget officer, who shall serve for an indefinite term at the pleasure of the president. The village budget officer may be removed at any time, with or without cause, by the president. 
(c)  Qualifications. The village budget officer shall be, at the time of designation, a person having knowledge and experience of accepted practices in respect of municipal finance, budgeting and accounting, and, particularly, in respect of the functions and duties of the office, as specified in this section. The village budget officer may hold another village office or position, either elected or appointed. 
(d)  Oath; bond. The village budget officer, before entering upon the duties of the office, shall take the oath prescribed by law, and shall execute and file with the village clerk a surety bond to the village in a penal sum of five thousand dollars ($5,000.00). The cost of such bond shall be paid by the village. 
(e)  Powers and duties. The village budget officer shall have the powers and duties provided by state law, commencing with the preparation of the budget for the fiscal year. 
(Ord. No. 91-0-67, §§ 2, 4, 12-10-91) 
State Law reference- Budget officer, 65 ILCS 5/8-2-9.1 et seq.

ARTICLE V. - DEPARTMENTS AND SIMILAR AGENCIES[7] 

Footnotes: 
--- (7) --- 
Cross reference- Fire department, § 10-26 et seq.; police department, § 19-26 et seq. 

Sec. 2-116. - Department of public works. 
(a)  Established. There is hereby established a department of municipal government of the village which shall be known as the department of public works, and it shall consist of a director of public works, and such other employees, if any, as the board of trustees may from time to time provide by ordinance or resolution. Neither the director of public works nor any other employee of the department of public works shall be considered an officer of the village, but they shall be considered employees of the village. The director of public works and other employees shall be appointed as provided otherwise by ordinance or resolution. 
(b)  Duties. It shall be the duty of the department of public works to operate and care for the waterworks system, the sewer and sewage systems, the streets and alleys, public buildings and grounds, and all other public properties and systems of the village not under the control of some other department or some officer of the village. The department and the members thereof, respectively, shall perform such other duties as may be imposed upon it or them, respectively, by the ordinances of the village or the resolutions or other action of the board of trustees. 
(c)  Director of public works. Subject to the provisions of subsection (a) of this section, the director of public works shall direct the work of the department of public works, and the other employees of the department shall be under his supervision and control. The director of public works may exercise such powers, if any, and shall perform such other duties as may be provided for by the ordinances of the village or by the resolutions or other action of the board of trustees. Whenever any statute, ordinance or resolution refers to the "street commissioner" or any position of a public work or public utility character, it shall mean the director of public works. 
(Code 1977, §§ 2.22, 2.23; Ord. No. 84-0-19, §§ 1, 2, 4-24-84; Ord. No. 98-O-48, § 2, 5-26-98; Ord. No. 99-O-28, § 5, 3-23-99) 
Cross reference- Streets and sidewalks, Ch. 21; water, sewers and sewage disposal, Ch. 25. 
Sec. 2-117. - Emergency management agency (EMA) 
(a)  Establishment. There is hereby created the local municipal EMA organization to prevent, minimize, repair, and alleviate injury or damage resulting from disaster caused by enemy attack, sabotage, or other hostile action, or from natural disaster in accordance with the Illinois Emergency Management Agency Act (20 ILCS 3305/1 et seq.) as amended. 
(b)  Composition. The EMA organization shall consist of the coordinator and additional members to be selected by the coordinator. 
(c)  Coordinator. 
(1)  The coordinator of the municipal EMA organization shall be appointed by the president of the village, by and with the advice and consent of the board of trustees, and shall serve until removed by the same. 
(2)  The coordinator shall have direct responsibility for the organization, administration, training and operation of the EMA organization, subject to the direction and control of the president, as provided by statute. 
(3)  In the event of the absence, resignation, death or inability to serve of the coordinator, the village president or any person designated by him shall be and act as coordinator until a new appointment is made as provided in this section. 
(d)  Functions. The municipal EMA organization shall perform such EMA functions within the village as shall be prescribed in and by the state EMA plan and program prepared by the governor, and such orders, rules, and regulations as may be promulgated by the governor, and in addition shall perform such duties outside the corporate limits as may be required pursuant to any mutual aid agreement with any other political subdivision, municipality, or quasi-municipality entered into as provided by the Illinois Emergency Management Agency Act (20 ILCS 3305/1 et seq.), as amended. 
(e)  Service as mobile support team. (20 ILCS 3305/8) 
(1)  All or any members of the municipal EMA organization may be designated as members of a mobile support team created by the state director of EMA as provided by law. The leader of such mobile support team shall be designated by the director of the EMA organization. 
(2)  Any member of a mobile support team that is a municipal employee or officer, while service on call to duty by the governor, or the state director of EMA shall receive the compensation and have the powers, duties, rights, and immunities incident to such employment or office. Any such member who is not a paid officer or employee of this village, while so serving, shall receive from the state reasonable compensation as provided by law. 
(f)  Agreements with other political subdivisions. The coordinator of the EMA organization may negotiate mutual aid agreements with other municipal corporations or political subdivisions of the state, but no such agreement shall be effective until it has been approved by the board of trustees. 
(g)  Emergency action. If the governor declares that an emergency exists in the event of actual enemy attack upon the United States or the occurrence within the state of major disaster resulting from enemy sabotage or other hostile action or from natural disaster, it shall be the duty of the municipal EMA organization to cooperate fully with the state office of EMA and with the governor in the exercise of emergency powers as provided by law. 
(h)  Compensation. Members of the EMA organization who are paid employees or officers of the municipality, if called for training by the state director of ESDA, shall receive for time spent in such training the same rate of pay as is attached to the position held; members who are not such municipal employees or officers shall receive for such training time such compensation as may be established by the board of trustees. 
(i)  Purchases and expenditures. 
(1)  The board of trustees may, on recommendation of the municipal coordinator of the EMA, authorize any purchase or contracts necessary to place the municipality in a position to combat effectively any disaster resulting from the explosion of any nuclear or other bomb or missile, and to protect the public health and safety, protect property, and provide emergency assistance to victims to the case of such disaster, or from natural disaster. 
(2)  In the event of enemy-caused or natural disaster, the municipal coordinator of the EMA is authorized, on behalf of the municipality, to procure such services, supplies, equipment, or materials as may be necessary for such purposes, in view of the exigency, without regard to the statutory procedures or formalities normally prescribed by law pertaining to municipal contracts or obligations, as authorized by the Illinois Emergency Management Agency Act (20 ILCS 3305/1 et seq.); provided that, if the board of trustees meets at such time, he shall act subject to the directions and restrictions imposed by that body. 
(j)  Oath. Every person appointed to serve in any capacity in the municipal EMA organization shall, before entering upon his duties, subscribe to the following oath, which shall be filed with the director: 
"I, ___________________, of the EMA organization of the Village of Libertyville, Illinois, do solemnly swear (or affirm) that I will support and defend and bear true faith and allegiance to the Constitution of the United States and the Constitution of the State of Illinois, and the territory, institutions and facilities thereof, both public and private, against all enemies, foreign, and domestic; that I take this obligation freely, without any mental reservation or purpose of evasion; and that I will well and faithfully discharge the duties upon which I am about to enter, and I do further swear (or affirm) that I do not advocate, nor am I nor have I been a member of any political party or organization that advocates the overthrow of the government of the United States or of this state by force or violence; and that during such time as I am affiliated with the EMA Organization of the Village of Libertyville, Illinois, I will not advocate nor become a member of any political party or organization that advocates the overthrow of the government of the United States or of this state by force or violence." 
(k)  Office. The village president is authorized to designate space in the village or elsewhere, as may be provided for by the village board for the municipal EMA organization as its office 
(Ord. No. 18-O-14, § 1, 4-10-18) 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 18-O-14, § 1, adopted April 10, 2018, amended § 2-117 in its entirety to read as herein set out. Former § 2-117, pertained to emergency services and disaster agency (ESDA), and derived from Code 1977, § 2.14(A)-(G), (I)-(K); Ord. No. 86-0-26, 5-13-86). 
Cross reference- Emergency services, disasters, etc., ch. 8. 
State Law reference- Illinois Emergency Management Agency Act, 20 ILCS 3305/1 et seq.; mobile support teams, 20 ILCS 3305/8; local ESDA agencies, 20 ILCS 3305/10, mutual aid arrangements, 20 ILCS 3305/13; oath, 20 ILCS 3305/20. 
Sec. 2-118. - Department of community development. 
(a)  Established. There is hereby established a department of the municipal government of the village which shall be known as the department of community development, and it shall consist of a director of community development, director of building services and any other employees as the board of trustees may from time to time provide for by ordinance or resolution. The director of community development shall be appointed by the village administrator. 
(b)  Duties. It shall be the duty of the director of community development to perform such work as may be related to all phases of the planning and development of the community, establishment and enforcement of building codes, work with the plan commission, zoning board of appeals, appearance review commission and economic development commission, and such other agencies of the municipal government and to perform such other duties as may be imposed by ordinance, resolution or other action of the village board. 
(Ord. No. 98-O-48, § 3, 5-26-98) 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 98-O-48, § 3, adopted May 26, 1998, deleted the former § 2-118 and enacted a new § 2-118 as set out herein. The former § 2-118 pertained to the office of planning and derived from Ord. No. 84-0-18, § 1, adopted April 24, 1984. 
Secs. 2-119-2-130. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE VI. - FINANCE[8] 

Footnotes: 
--- (8) --- 
Cross reference- Licenses, taxation and miscellaneous business regulations, Ch. 13. 
State Law reference- Municipal finance generally, 65 ILCS 5/8-1-1 et seq.; local government finance, 50 ILCS 310/1 et seq. 

Sec. 2-131. - Fiscal year. 
    Commencing in 1991, the fiscal year of the village shall begin on May 1 of each calendar year and end on April 30 of the succeeding calendar year. 
(Code 1977, § 1.11; Ord. No. 89-0-37, § 1, 7-25-89) 
State Law reference- Fiscal year, 65 ILCS 5/1-1-2(5). 
Sec. 2-132. - Depositories. 
(a)  Designated depositories. The village treasurer is required to keep all funds and money of the village in the custody of the village treasurer in any one (1) or more of the following financial institutions: 
(1)  Amcore Bank. 
(2)  Associated Bank. 
(3)  Bank Financial. 
(4)  Fifth Third Bank. 
(5)  Harris Bank. 
(6)  JP Morgan/Chase. 
(7)  Libertyville Bank & Trust Co. 
(8)  National City Bank. 
(9)  Oakbrook Bank. 
(10)  Wayne Hummer Trust. 
(b)  Limit on initial deposits. No funds or money of the village shall be deposited for the first time in any of the depositories designated in subsection (a) of this section unless and until: 
(1)  The village clerk shall have notified the sureties of the village treasurer in writing of the identity of the designated depository that is to receive such initial deposit; 
(2)  Five days shall have elapsed following the delivery of such notice; and 
(3)  The designated depository that is to receive such initial deposit shall have furnished to the village copies of the last two (2) sworn statements of resources and liabilities that such depository is required to furnish to the commissioner of banks and trust companies or to the comptroller of currency in compliance with the statutory requirements referred to in section 3-10-3 of the Illinois Municipal Code [65 ILCS 5/3-10-3]. 
(c)  Limit on all deposits. No funds or money of the village shall be deposited in any one (1) of the depositories designated in subsection (a) of this section if the amount of such deposit, not collateralized or insured by an agency of the federal government, is in excess of seventy-five (75) percent of the capital stock and surplus of such depository. Deposits in excess of such amount are prohibited. 
(d)  Deposits. The village president, village treasurer, village administrator, senior trustee of the board of trustees, village director of finance, and each of them, are hereby authorized to endorse for deposit and collection in and with such depositories all checks, drafts and orders for the payment of money. Endorsements for deposit and collection may be effected in writing or in stamped endorsement of the village without designation of the person making the endorsement. 
(e)  Transfer or withdrawal. Funds or money deposited pursuant to this section may be transferred and withdrawn upon corporate warrants, checks and orders signed by any two (2) of the following: the village president, village treasurer, village administrator, senior trustee of the board of trustees, and village director of finance. No corporate warrant, check or other order drawn against funds or money of the village deposited pursuant to this section shall be valid unless so signed. Any of the required two (2) signatures may be by facsimile signature; provided that the facsimile signature complies with the requirements of the Uniform Facsimile Signature of Public Officials Act [30 ILCS 320/1 et seq.]. 
(f)  Certification of offices and signatures. The village clerk shall certify to the depositories designated in subsection (a) of this section, from time to time, the persons appointed or elected, qualified and then acting as the village president, village treasurer, village administrator, senior trustee of the board of trustees of the village and village finance director, and each of their respective signatures. 
(g)  Depository authority. The depositories designated in subsection (a) of this section are hereby authorized and directed to honor and pay any warrants, checks or other orders signed in accordance with subsection (e) of this section, including those drawn to the individual order of any such official signing the same, without further inquiry or regard to the authority of such officers to sign such warrants, checks or orders, or in their use or the proceeds thereof. The depositories may consider the facts concerning the holders of such offices and their signatures, respectively, to be and continue as set forth in the certificate of the village clerk delivered to such depositories, or in any similar subsequent certificate delivered to such depositories, until written notice to the contrary is duly served on such depositories. 
(h)  Required information. So long as each depository designated in subsection (a) of this section shall continue to serve as a designated depository pursuant to this section, it shall furnish to the village a copy of each statement of resources and liabilities furnished to the commissioner of banks or comptroller of currency in compliance with the statutory requirements referred to in section 3-10-3 of the Illinois Municipal Code [65 ILCS 5/3-10-3]. 
(Code 1977, § 4.2(a), (d); Ord. No. 81-0-13, § 1, 5-26-81; Ord. No. 91-0-11, § 1, 3-12-91; Ord. No. 94-0-47, § 3, 9-27-94; Ord. No. 06-O-43, § 2, 5-9-06) 
State Law reference- Depositories, 65 ILCS 5/3-10-3. 
Sec. 2-133. - Budget officer system adopted. 
    The village hereby adopts the budget officer system established in 65 ILCS 5/8-2-9.1-5/8-2-9.10. 
(Ord. No. 91-0-67, § 1, 12-10-91) 
Sec. 2-134. - Payment of bills. 
(a)  Preparation of warrants. The village treasurer shall prepare all warrants to be drawn on the village treasury for the payment of all sums due from the village and shall list the particular fund to which the warrant is chargeable and the person to whom the warrant is payable. 
(b)  Classification of warrants. Warrants are classified and defined as follows: 
(1)  Class A warrants are all warrants that are not Class B warrants. 
(2)  Class B warrants are warrants relating to payroll and payroll taxes; the reimbursement of imprest accounts established for the payment of health care and worker's compensation claims; and the return of funds from escrow accounts. 
(c)  Approval/ratification of warrants. 
(1)  All warrants shall be signed by the village president and countersigned by the village clerk upon approval or ratification of the same by the board of trustees. 
(2)  All Class A warrants shall require the board of trustees' approval, in connection with the warrants list procedure, prior to the issuance of the same. 
(3)  All Class B warrants may be issued by the village treasurer without prior approval of the board of trustees; provided, however, that the issuance of such Class B warrants shall be ratified by the board of trustees, in connection with the warrants list procedure, at the next regular or special meeting of the board of trustees. 
(d)  Warrants list procedure. A list of all Class A warrants to be paid, and all Class B warrants previously paid, shall be prepared by the village treasurer and submitted to the board of trustees for review on a biweekly basis, or a more or less frequent basis, as the village treasurer may deem necessary. Approval by the board of trustees of such warrants list by a roll call vote at a regular or special meeting of the board of trustees shall constitute approval of all Class A warrants and ratification of all Class B warrants; provided that the board of trustees may, in its sole discretion, except from such approval specific Class A warrants, in which case such Class A warrants shall not be issued. 
(e)  Method of payment. Warrants issued pursuant to this section shall be paid by the village treasurer only in the form of a check, wire or other electronic transfer. 
Sec. 2-135. - Advertising for bids. 
    Whenever the corporate authorities of the village direct the advertising for bids for the letting of a contract under the provisions of section 8-9-1 or 8-9-2 of the Illinois Municipal Code [65 ILCS 5/8-9-1, 5/8-9-2] or under any other requirement of the law making a like provision with reference to prescribing by ordinance the manner of advertising for bids of any contract to be let by the corporate authorities, such advertisement shall be given by the village clerk or village president by at least one (1) publication in a newspaper of general circulation published in the village, to be so published at least fifteen (15) days prior to the final date prescribed for the receipt of bids and to give a general description of the work, public improvement or of whatever is to be furnished to the village, and shall make adequate reference to the plans, specifications or other standards to be complied with by the successful bidder. 
(Code 1977, § 4.1; Ord. No. 93-0-45, § 3, 9-28-93) 
Sec. 2-136. - Fees. 
(a)  Development application fees. Every application or request for development approvals shall be accompanied by a fee determined in accordance with the annual fee ordinance. No development application fee shall be refunded regardless of whether the requested application was approved, disapproved or conditionally approved. 
(b)  Appearance review fees. Every application or request for the issuance of a certificate of approval, or amendment thereto, under the provisions of chapter 7, article III, of this Code shall be accompanied by a fee determined in accordance with the annual fee ordinance. No appearance review fee shall be refunded regardless of whether the requested certificate of approval, or amendment thereto, was approved, disapproved or conditionally approved. 
(c)  Ambulance transportation fees. An ambulance transportation fee shall be charged for the transportation of persons to area hospitals, which fee shall be determined in accordance with the annual fee ordinance (where "resident" refers to persons residing and maintaining a domicile within the corporate limits of the village or within the corporate limits of the village fire protection district as determined by the village administrator). 
(d)  Additional to other fees. The fees provided for in this section shall be in addition to, and not in limitation of, any other fee, charge, rate or other amount. 
(Ord. No. 91-0-32, § 1, 6-25-91; Ord. No. 97-O-29, § 5, 4-22-97) 
Secs. 2-137-2-150. - Reserved.

ARTICLE VIII. - BOARDS, COMMISSIONS, ETC.[10] 
Footnotes: 
--- (10) --- 
Cross reference- Zoning board of appeals, § 26-61 et seq.; architectural review board, § 26-278. 

DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 2-171. - Appointment. 
(a)  Unless otherwise expressly provided in this Code, the village president shall appoint, with the confirmation of a majority of the board of trustees, all members of all village boards and commissions. All vacancies shall be filled for the remainder of the unexpired terms in the same manner as original appointments. 
(b)  Unless otherwise expressly provided in this Code, if recommended by the president and confirmed by a majority of the board of trustees, members of boards and commissions may serve successive terms without limit. 
(c)  Unless otherwise expressly provided in this Code, the term of all members of boards and commissions shall not terminate or expire until successors have been appointed and qualified. 
(d)  Unless otherwise expressly provided in this Code, members of all boards and commissions shall be residents of the village. 
(e)  No appointment to any board or commission shall be made by the president within thirty (30) days prior to the expiration of the president's term of office. 
(Ord. No. 95-0-8, § 2, 2-28-95) 
Sec. 2-172. - Chairman, vice-chairman (president and vice-president). 
    Unless otherwise expressly provided in this Code, the chairman and vice-chairman or president and vice-president of all village boards and commissions shall be appointed by the village president, with confirmation by an affirmative vote of a majority of the board of trustees. In the absence of the chairman or president, the vice-chairman or vice-president or, in the absence of the vice-chairman or vice-president, a temporary chairman elected by and from among the applicable board or commission shall act as chairman and shall have all the powers of the chairman. 
Sec. 2-173. - Organization and bylaws. 
    All village boards and commissions shall adopt bylaws governing procedures to regulate their business as they deem necessary; provided, however, that such bylaws shall: 
(1)  Be consistent with the applicable provisions of this Code. 
(2)  Require a majority vote of the entire membership for adoption and amendment. 
(3)  Contain consistent selection standards for any nonappointive officers deemed necessary. 
(4)  Be subject to review and approval by the village attorney. 
(5)  Be ratified by the board of trustees. 
Sec. 2-174. - Compensation. 
    Unless otherwise expressly provided in this Code, all members of all village boards and commissions, with the exception of plan commission members and appearance review commission members shall serve without compensation. Each member of the plan commission shall receive fifty dollars ($50.00) per meeting payable semiannually, and each member of the appearance review commission shall receive twenty-five dollars ($25.00) per meeting payable semiannually. Authorized expenses, however, shall be reimbursed in accordance with applicable village regulations. 
(Ord. No. 05-O-37, § 3, 4-26-05) 
Sec. 2-175. - Removal of members. 
(a)  Unless otherwise expressly provided in this Code, all village boards and commissions may recommend to the board of trustees the removal of any member who fails to attend four (4) successive meetings or who fails to meet established membership requirements. 
(b)  Unless otherwise expressly provided by this Code or the Illinois Municipal Code (65 ILCS et seq.), the president may remove any officer appointed by the president, including all members of all village boards or commissions, on any written charge, whenever the president is of the opinion that the interests of the village demand removal. The president shall report the reasons for the removal to the corporate authorities at a meeting to be held not less than five (5) nor more than ten (10) days after the removal. If the president fails or refuses to report to the corporate authorities the reasons for the removal, or the corporate authorities by a two-third vote of all members authorized by law to be elected disapprove of the removal, the officer thereupon shall be restored to the office from which the officer was removed. 
(Ord. No. 99-O-28, § 6, 3-23-99) 
Secs. 2-176-2-185. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - SUSTAIN LIBERTYVILLE COMMISSION[11] 

Footnotes: 
--- (11) --- 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 14-O-01, adopted Jan. 14, 2014, changed the title of Div. 2 from "Keep Libertyville Beautiful Commission" to "Sustain Libertyville Commission." 
Cross reference- Community appearance, Ch. 7; solid waste, Ch. 20. 

Sec. 2-186. - Created. 
    There is hereby created the Sustain Libertyville Commission. 
(Code 1977, § 2.27(a); Ord. No. 14-O-01, § 2, 1-14-14) 
Sec. 2-187. - Objectives. 
(a)  The primary objectives of the commission created in this division shall be: 
(1)  To encourage property owners, builders and developers to protect the environment. 
(2)  Assist in the implementation of the Village Green Government Initiative. 
(3)  To make environmental information and resources readily available. 
(4)  To create partnerships with interested parties to help achieve mutually beneficial sustainability goals. 
(5)  To review and recommend sustainable initiatives which are fiscally responsible and enhance economic vitality. 
(6)  To provide recognition to those who have made exceptional contributions or have made an outstanding effort toward improving the sustainability of the village. 
(b)  The commission shall offer advice and recommendations to the village board, plan commission, and to individuals involved in constructing and developing property, landscaping, signing, and in the maintenance of existing buildings and grounds within its established objectives. 
(Code 1977, § 2.27(b), (f); Ord. No. 14-O-01, § 3, 1-14-14) 
Sec. 2-188. - Composition. 
    The commission created in this division shall consist of eight (8) members appointed by the village president and subject to the approval of the village board. 
(Code 1977, § 2.27(c); Ord. No. 84-0-20, § 1, 4-24-84; Ord. No. 15-O-12, § 2, 2-10-15) 
Sec. 2-189. - Chairman. 
    One (1) member of the commission created in this division shall be appointed by the village president to serve as chairman. 
(Code 1977, § 2.27(d)) 
Sec. 2-190. - Expiration of term. 
    The term of each member of the commission created in this division shall expire on April 30 of each year. 
(Code 1977, § 2.27(e)) 
Secs. 2-191-2-205. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 3. - ECONOMIC DEVELOPMENT COMMISSION 

Sec. 2-206. - Creation. 
    There is created the Libertyville Economic Development Commission, which shall consist of seven (7) members appointed by the president with the advice and consent of the board of trustees. 
(Ord. No. 83-0-6, § I, 4-19-83) 
Sec. 2-207. - Term of members, chairman. 
    The term of eight (8) members of the commission created in this division shall be four (4) years each. All terms shall end on April 30 of the designated year. One (1) member shall be designated chairman by the president with the advice and consent of the board of trustees and shall serve as chairman until April 30 of the ensuing year or until his successor has been designated. 
(Ord. No. 83-0-6, § II, 4-19-83; Ord. No. 14-O-45, § 2, 6-24-14) 
Sec. 2-208. - Organization. 
    The members of the economic development commission shall elect any other officers that they may deem necessary, and shall hold such meetings and establish such rules and regulations as the commission shall deem necessary and proper for carrying on its functions. 
(Ord. No. 83-0-6, § III, 4-19-83) 
Sec. 2-209. - Powers and duties. 
(a)  The economic development commission shall assist both existing and prospective industrial or commercial firms to expand, extend, locate or relocate in the village so as to coordinate and maximize business growth within the community. 
(b)  The commission shall cooperate with all other agencies of the village, county and state governments as well as such private organizations as will help further the goals of the commission. 
(c)  The commission shall render advice and recommendations to the president and village board as it may deem appropriate or as may be requested. 
(d)  No member of the commission shall enter into any contractual obligation, pay bills, or solicit or collect money without approval and consent of the president and board of trustees. 
(Ord. No. 83-0-6, § IV, 4-19-83) 
Sec. 2-210. - Budget. 
    The economic development commission shall prepare an operating budget for each fiscal year and shall submit such request to the village board for consideration annually. 
(Ord. No. 83-0-6, § V, 4-19-83) 
Secs. 2-211-2-225. - Reserved.
