    Place of employment means an area under the control of a public or private employer within the village that employees normally frequent during the course of employment, and includes, without limitation, common work areas, private offices, auditoriums, classrooms, conference and meeting rooms, cafeterias, elevators, employee lounges, staircases, hallways, restrooms, medical facilities, private clubs, and the interior of a vehicle of public conveyance. Place of employment also includes the home office portion of a private dwelling, but only if the home office is used by more than one employee or is frequented by business invitees. Place of employment includes a private dwelling unit used as a day care facility. 
Place of employment does not include that part of a private dwelling used as a home office by a single employee only who resides in that dwelling. 
    Park means a public park or recreation area that is open to and used by the general public. 
    Public entrance means the doorway or other entrance to a public place that is open to and intended for use by the general public for ingress and egress to the public place. 
Public entrance also means a doorway or other entrance for pedestrian ingress and egress to a place of employment: (i) that is open to and intended for use by the general public or business invitee's ingress and egress to the place of employment; and (ii) where employees are required or permitted to enter or exit the place of employment. 
    Public place means an area that is open to and used by the general public, or any area to which the public is invited or in which the public is permitted, including without limitation: 
(1)  Vehicles of public conveyance; 
(2)  Common or public areas (including without limitation lobbies, hallways, reception areas, public restrooms, elevators and staircases) of apartment buildings, condominiums, dormitory buildings, nursing home care facilities, and other multiple family residential structures; 
(3)  Common or public areas (including without limitation lobbies, hallways, reception areas, public restrooms, elevators and staircases) of any building or structure that is accessible to the public including without limitation office, commercial, and industrial buildings, banks and financial institutions, educational institutions, health care facilities such as hospitals, clinics and doctor's offices, museums, libraries, restaurants, polling places, government and village-owned buildings, food stores, cafeterias, theaters, auditoriums, train and bus stations, hotels, motels, and retail and service establishments; 
(4)  Rooms, chambers, halls, or other locations within which meetings, hearings, or gatherings are held, to which the public is invited or in which the public is permitted, including specifically, but without limitation, any enclosed area under the control of the village where there is in progress any public meeting. 
Public place shall not include: 
(1)  A private dwelling unit, unless said dwelling is also used as a day care facility for children or adults; provided that rooms in nursing homes or long-term care facilities occupied by one or more persons who have requested in writing a room where smoking is permitted shall be considered private dwelling units; or 
(2)  Hotel or motel rooms designated as smoking, provided that no more than fifteen (15) percent of the available rooms for rent in any single building shall be designated as smoking rooms. 
    Smoke or smoking means inhaling, exhaling, burning, or carrying any lighted cigar, cigarette, pipe, or other lighted tobacco product in any manner or in any form. 
    Village means the Village of Libertyville. 
(Ord. No. O6-O-81, § 2(11.2), 8-22-06) 
Sec. 14-123. - Prohibition in enclosed public places. 
(a)  It is unlawful to smoke in any enclosed area of any public place. 
(b)  It shall be unlawful for the owner, occupant or lessee, as the case may be, in control of a public place to knowingly permit smoking in any enclosed area in a public place. 
(Ord. No. O6-O-81, § 2(11.3), 8-22-06) 
Sec. 14-124. - Prohibition in unenclosed public places and outdoor venues. 
    It is unlawful to smoke in public parks and recreation areas. 
(Ord. No. O6-O-81, § 2(11.4), 8-22-06) 
Sec. 14-125. - Prohibition in places of employment. 
(a)  It is unlawful to smoke in any enclosed area of any place of employment. 
(b)  It shall be unlawful for any employer to knowingly permit smoking in any enclosed area of any place of employment. 
(Ord. No. O6-O-81, § 2(11.5), 8-22-06) 
Sec. 14-126. - Prohibition in open air dining areas. 
(a)  It is unlawful to smoke in any open air dining area. 
(b)  It shall be unlawful for the owner, occupant or lessee, as the case may be, in control of an open air dining area to knowingly permit smoking in the area available for open air dining. 
(c)  It is unlawful to smoke within twenty-five (25) feet of an open air dining area. 
(Ord. No. O6-O-81, § 2(11.6), 8-22-06) 
Sec. 14-127. - Prohibition at public entrances. 
(a)  It is unlawful to smoke within twenty-five (25) feet of a public entrance to a public place or to a place of employment. 
(b)  It is unlawful for any person or persons to gather or congregate for the purpose of smoking within twenty-five (25) feet of a public entrance. 
(Ord. No. O6-O-81, § 2(11.7), 8-22-06) 
Sec. 14-128. - Designation of other no-smoking areas. 
    Nothing in this article shall be deemed to limit the owner, occupant or lessee of a public place or a place of employment to further prohibit smoking by designating outdoor areas not subject to the restrictions in this article as a place where smoking is also prohibited, provided that the owner, occupant or lessee shall cause signs to be posted at appropriate locations advising persons that smoking is prohibited within the designated outdoor area. 
(Ord. No. O6-O-81, § 2(11.8), 8-22-06) 
Sec. 14-129. - No retaliation. 
    No person, business or employer shall discharge, refuse to hire, or in any manner retaliate against an employee or customer because that employee or customer reports a violation of this article or exercises any rights afforded by this article. 
(Ord. No. O6-O-81, § 2(11.9), 8-22-06) 
Sec. 14-130. - Signs. 
(a)  Each owner, lessor, lessee, employer, or other person in control of a public place or place of employment shall post conspicuous no smoking signs in the enclosed area of any public place where smoking is prohibited. Such no smoking signs shall have a white field with the words no smoking printed in red letters, four inches high with a one-half-inch face, or shall bear the international no smoking symbol, which consists of a pictorial representation of a cigarette enclosed in a circle with a bar across it or other such sign as approved by the village, that clearly states that smoking is prohibited. It shall be unlawful for any person to remove, deface or obscure any sign posted pursuant to the provisions of this article. 
(b)  Each owner, lessor, lessee, employer or other person in control of a public park or recreation area shall cause signs to be posted at appropriate locations advising persons that smoking is prohibited within the park, recreation area. 
(Ord. No. O6-O-81, § 2(11.10), 8-22-06) 
Sec. 14-131. - Exemptions. 
    The prohibition on smoking set forth in sections 14-123 and 14-125 shall not apply to a public place or place of employment of a tobacco dealer that permits customers to sample tobacco products on the premises of the tobacco dealer, provided that smoke generated by smoking on the premises of the tobacco dealer does not infiltrate any other enclosed public place or place of employment. For purposes of this exemption, a tobacco dealer is a retailer whose principal business is the sale at retail of tobacco and tobacco-related products, and does not sell any food or drink items. 
(Ord. No. O6-O-81, § 2(11.11), 8-22-06; Ord. No. 06-O-97, § 2, 10-10-06) 
Sec. 14-132. - Penalties. 
(a)  Any person who smokes in an area where smoking is prohibited under the provisions of this article shall be guilty of an offense punishable by a fine of fifty dollars ($50.00). 
(b)  Any person who owns, manages, operates or otherwise controls a public place, a place of employment or an open air dining area that permits smoking in an area where smoking is prohibited under the provisions of this article, or fails to post the signage as required under the provisions of this article, shall be guilty of an offense punishable by a fine of not less than one hundred dollars ($100.00) and not more than five hundred dollars ($500.00). 
(c)  Each day that any violation of this article shall continue shall constitute a separate offense. 
(Ord. No. O6-O-81, § 2(11.12), 8-22-06; Ord. No. 06-O-97, § 3, 10-10-06) 
Sec. 14-133. - Severability. 
    If any provision or part of this article or application thereof to any person or circumstance is held to be invalid, the remainder of the article and the application of the provision or part thereof to other persons not similarly situated or to other circumstances shall not be affected thereby. 
(Ord. No. O6-O-81, § 2(11.13), 8-22-06) 
Chapter 15 - NUISANCES[1] 
  
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference- Animals, Ch. 5; animal nuisances, § 5-6; buildings and building regulations, Ch. 6; environmental preservation, Ch. 9; solid waste, Ch. 20; water, sewers and sewage disposal, Ch. 25. 
State Law reference- Authority to define, prevent and abate nuisances, 720 ILCS 5/11-60-2. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 15-1. - Definition. 
    For the purposes of this chapter, a public nuisance is a thing, act, occupation, condition or use of property which shall continue for such length of time as to: 
(1)  Substantially annoy, injure or endanger the comfort, health, repose or safety of the public; or 
(2)  In any way render the public insecure in life or in the use of property; or 
(3)  Greatly offend the public morals or decency; or 
(4)  Unlawfully and substantially interfere with, obstruct or tend to obstruct or render dangerous for passage any street, alley, highway, navigable body of water or other public way. 
(Code 1977, § 12.2(a)) 
Cross reference- Definitions and rules of construction generally, § 1-2. 
Sec. 15-2. - Nuisances affecting health. 
    The following acts, omissions, places, conditions and things are hereby specifically declared to be public health nuisances, but shall not be construed to exclude other health nuisances coming within the definition of section 15-1: 
(1)  All decayed, harmfully adulterated or unwholesome food or drink sold or offered for sale to the public. 
(2)  Carcasses of animals, birds or fowl not buried or otherwise disposed of in a sanitary manner within twenty-four (24) hours after death. 
(3)  Accumulations of decayed animal or vegetable matter, trash, rubbish, rotting lumber, bedding, packing material, abandoned vehicles or machinery, scrap metal or any material in which flies, mosquitoes, disease-carrying insects, rats or other vermin may breed. 
(4)  All stagnant water in which mosquitoes, flies or other insects can multiply. 
(5)  Garbage cans which are not fly tight except as may be permitted by ordinance. 
(6)  The escape of smoke, soot, cinders, noxious acids, fumes, gases, fly ash or industrial dust within the village limits in such quantities as to endanger the health of persons of ordinary sensibilities or to threaten or cause substantial injury to property. 
(7)  The pollution of any public well or cistern, stream, lake, canal or body of water by sewage, creamery or industrial wastes or other substances. 
(8)  Any use of property, substances or things within the village emitting or causing any foul, offensive, noisome, nauseous, noxious, or disagreeable odors, effluvia or stenches extremely repulsive to the physical senses of ordinary persons which annoy, discomfort, injure or inconvenience the health of any appreciable number of persons within the village. 
(9)  All abandoned wells not securely covered or secured from public use. 
(10)  Any barn, stable or shed used for keeping animals. 
(11)  Any obstruction in or across any watercourse, drainage ditch or ravine. 
(12)  The deposit of garbage, rubbish, or any offensive substance on any street, sidewalk or public place, or on any private property, except as may be permitted by ordinance. 
(Code 1977, § 12.2(b); Ord. No. 15-O-07, § 4, 1-27-15) 
Sec. 15-3. - Nuisances offending morals and decency. 
    The following acts, omissions, places, conditions and things are hereby specifically declared to be public nuisances offending public morals and decency, but such enumeration shall not be construed to exclude other nuisances offending public morals and decency coming within the definition of section 15-1: 
(1)  All disorderly houses, bawdy houses, houses of ill fame, gambling houses and buildings or structures kept or resorted to for the purpose of prostitution, promiscuous sexual intercourse or gambling. 
(2)  All gambling devices and slot machines. 
(3)  All businesses where intoxicating liquor or fermented malt beverages are sold, possessed, stored, brewed, bottled, manufactured or rectified without a permit or license as provided for by this Code. 
(4)  Any place or premises within the village where ordinances or state laws relating to public health, safety, peace, morals or welfare are openly, continuously, repeatedly and intentionally violated. 
(Code 1977, § 12.2(c)) 
Sec. 15-4. - Nuisances affecting peace and safety. 
    The following acts, omissions, places, conditions and things are hereby declared to be public nuisances affecting peace and safety, but such enumeration shall not be construed to exclude other nuisances affecting public peace or safety coming within the provisions of section 15-1: 
(1)  All buildings erected, repaired or altered in violation of the provisions of the ordinances of the village relating to materials and manner of construction of buildings and structures. 
(2)  All unauthorized signs, signals, markings or devices which purport to be or may be mistaken as official traffic control devices placed or maintained upon or in view of any public highway or railway crossing. 
(3)  All trees, hedges, billboards or other obstructions which prevent persons driving vehicles on public streets, alleys or highways from obtaining a clear view of traffic when approaching an intersection or pedestrian crosswalk. 
(4)  All limbs of trees which project over a public sidewalk less than eight (8) feet above the surface thereof or less than ten (10) feet above the surface of a public street. 
(5)  All use or display of fireworks except as provided by the laws of the state and ordinances of the village. 
(6)  All buildings or structures so old, dilapidated or out of repair as to be dangerous, unsafe, insanitary or otherwise unfit for human use. 
(7)  All wires over streets, alleys or public grounds which are strung less than fifteen (15) feet above the surface of the street or ground. 
(8)  All loud and discordant noises or vibrations of any kind between 9:00 p.m. and 7:00 a.m. 
(9)  All obstructions of streets, alleys, sidewalks or crosswalks and all excavations in or under the same, except as permitted by the ordinances of the village or which, although made in accordance with such ordinances, are kept or maintained for an unreasonable length of time after the purpose thereof has been accomplished. 
(10)  All open and unguarded pits, wells, excavations or unused basements freely accessible from any public street, alley or sidewalk. 
(11)  All abandoned refrigerators or iceboxes from which the doors and other covers have not been removed or which are not equipped with a device for opening from the inside by pushing only with the strength of a small child. 
(12)  Any unauthorized or unlawful use of property abutting on a public street, alley or sidewalk or of a public street, alley or sidewalk which causes large crowds of people to gather, obstructing traffic and free use of the streets or sidewalks. 
(13)  Any advertisements or signs affixed to any building, wall, fence, sidewalk, street or other private or public property without permission of the owner thereof. 
(14)  Any sign, marquee or awning which is in an unsafe condition, or which overhangs any roadway, or which overhangs any sidewalk less than eight (8) feet above the sidewalk surface. 
(15)  Any structure, material or condition which constitutes a fire hazard or will impair the extinguishing of any fire. 
(16)  Any nuisance so defined by law. 
(17)  Graffiti resulting from the willful damage, mutilation, or defacement of any exterior surface of any structure or building on any private or public property, by the placing of any marking, carving, or deposit of substance, but not limited to markings made by paint, spray paint, markers and writing implements. All such graffiti shall be removed within five (5) business days of notice to do so by the village. 
(18)  Public urination and defecation prohibited. It shall be unlawful to urinate or defecate on any street, alley, sidewalk, parkway, public parking lot, or other public place. 
(Code 1977, § 12.2(d); Ord. No. 04-O-62, § 2, 9-28-04; Ord. No. 10-O-20, § 2, 2-23-10; Ord. No. 13-O-65, § 2, 11-12-13) 
Sec. 15-5. - Nuisances prohibited. 
    No person shall erect, contrive, cause, continue, maintain or permit to exist any public nuisance within the village or within the police jurisdiction of the village. 
(Code 1977, § 12.1) 
State Law reference- Extraterritorial jurisdiction, 65 ILCS 5/7-4-1, 5/7-4-2, 5/7-4-4. 
Sec. 15-6. - Inspection of premises. 
    The village administrator or his designee may inspect or cause to be inspected premises upon which it is believed that a public nuisance exists and shall make a written report of the inspection. Whenever practicable, the inspecting officer shall cause photographs to be made of the premises and shall file the same in the office of the village clerk. 
(Code 1977, § 12.3(a)) 
Sec. 15-7. - Summary abatement. 
(a)  Notice to owner. If the inspecting officer shall determine that a public nuisance exists on private property and that there is great and immediate danger to the public health, safety, peace, morals or decency, the village administrator may direct the chief of police, or a deputy sheriff, to serve a notice on the owner, or, if the owner cannot be found, on the occupant or person causing, permitting or maintaining such nuisance and to post a copy of the notice on the premises. Such notice shall direct the owner, occupant or person causing, permitting or maintaining such nuisance to abate or remove such nuisance within twenty-four (24) hours and shall state that unless such nuisance is so abated, the village will cause the same to be abated and will charge the cost thereof to the owner, occupant or person causing, permitting or maintaining the same, as the case may be. 
(b)  Abatement by village. If the nuisance is not abated within the time provided, or if the owner, occupant or person causing the nuisance cannot be found, the director of public works, or some other village official whom the village administrator shall designate, shall cause the abatement or removal of such public nuisance. 
(Code 1977, § 12.3(b)) 
Sec. 15-8. - Abatement by court action. 
    If the inspecting officer shall determine that a public nuisance exists on private premises but that the nature of such nuisance is not such as to threaten great and immediate danger to the public health, safety, peace, morals or decency, he shall file a written report of his findings with the village administrator, who shall cause an action to abate such nuisance to be commenced in the name of the village. 
(Code 1977, § 12.3(c)) 
Sec. 15-9. - Cost of abatement. 
    In addition to any other penalty imposed by this chapter for the erection, contrivance, creation, continuance or maintenance of a public nuisance, the cost of abating a public nuisance by the village shall be collected as a debt from the owner, occupant or person causing, permitting or maintaining the nuisance, and if notice to abate the nuisance has been given to the owner, such cost shall be assessed against the real estate as other special taxes. 
(Code 1977, § 12.4) 
Secs. 15-10-15-25. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - DEAD, DISEASED OR NUISANCE VEGETATION[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 11-O-58, § 2, adopted Sept. 27, 2011, amended Art. II in its entirety to read as set out herein. Former Art. II, §§ 15-26-15-33, pertained to Dutch elm disease and derived from the Code of 1977, § 12.5(a)-(i). 

Sec. 15-26. - Declared nuisance. 
(a)  All species and varieties of elm trees (trees of genus Ulmus) infected with the fungus disease of elms caused by Graphium ulmi, commonly known as Dutch elm disease, or elm blight, as determined by laboratory analysis by a village board of trustees approved laboratory. 
(b)  All species and varieties of elm trees that are dead or substantially dead and all dead elm wood to which the bark is still attached, which because of their condition, may serve as a breeding place for infestation of the European elm bark beetle (Scolytus multistriatus) are hereby declared to be public nuisances. 
(c)  All species and varieties of ash trees (trees of genus Fraxinus) infected with the wood-boring beetle Agrilus plannipennis or Agrilus marcopoli, commonly known as emerald ash borer as determined by laboratory analysis by a village board of trustees approved laboratory. 
(d)  All species and varieties of ash trees that are dead or substantially dead and all dead ash wood to which the bark is still attached, which because of their condition, may serve as a breeding place for infestation of the emerald ash borer beetle (Agrilus plannipennis or Agrilus marcopoli) are hereby declared to be public nuisances. 
(e)  All species and varieties of chestnut trees (trees of Castenaea dentate) infected with the fungus of chestnut trees caused by Cryphonectria parasitica, commonly known as chestnut blight fungus as determined by laboratory analysis by a village board of trustees approved laboratory. 
(f)  All species and varieties of chestnut trees that are dead or substantially dead and all dead chestnut wood to which the bark is still attached, which because of their condition, may serve as a breeding place for infestation of the chestnut blight fungus (Cryphonectria parasticia) are hereby declared to be public nuisances. 
(g)  All vegetation or other obstructions which prevent person driving vehicles of public streets, alleys or highways from obtaining a clear view of traffic when approaching an intersection or pedestrian walk. 
(h)  All limbs of trees which project over a public sidewalk less than eight (8) feet above the surface thereof or less than ten (10) feet above the surface of a public street. 
(i)  Any dead tree or dead wood declared a nuisance or hazard not in a naturalized setting shall be removed per the direction of the director of public works or designee. 
(Ord. No. 11-O-58, § 2, 9-27-11) 
Sec. 15-27. - Removal of infected trees. 
    It shall be unlawful for any owner of any lot or land in the village to permit or maintain on any such lot or land, any elm tree or dead elm wood, ash tree or dead ash wood and chestnut tree or dead chestnut wood which is a public nuisance. It shall be the duty of any such owner promptly to remove or cause to be removed and dispose of in accordance with state and federal agency guidelines any such elm tree or dead elm wood, ash tree or dead ash wood and chestnut tree or dead chestnut wood under the supervision and direction of the director of public works or designee. 
(Ord. No. 11-O-58, § 2, 9-27-11) 
Sec. 15-28. - Entry on private property. 
    In order to carry out the purposes of this article and to implement the enforcement thereof, the director of public works or designee is hereby authorized and empowered to enter upon any lot or land in the village at all reasonable hours for the purpose of inspecting any elm, ash or chestnut tree situated thereon. The director of public works or designee may remove such specimens from any such tree as are required for the purposes of the laboratory analysis, or to determine whether such tree because it is dead or substantially dead, may serve as a breeding place for the disease or infestation of elm, ash or chestnut trees. It shall be unlawful for any person to take any action to prevent the director of public works or designee from entering on any lot or land in the village for the purpose of such inspection, or to interfere with the director of public works or designee in the performance of any of their duties provided for under the provisions of this section. 
(Ord. No. 11-O-58, § 2, 9-27-11) 
Sec. 15-29. - Notice to owner. 
    If, on laboratory analysis of any specimen removed from any elm, ash or chestnut tree on any lot or land in this village by the director of public works or designee, it is determined that such tree is a public nuisance, or if the director of public works or designee determines that any dead or substantially dead elm tree or dead elm wood ash tree or dead ash wood and chestnut tree or dead chestnut tree on any such lot or land is a public nuisance, the director of public works shall serve notice with reference thereto or cause notice to be served as herein provided. Such notice shall be personally served upon the person to whom was sent the tax bill for the general taxes for the last preceding year on such lot or land or shall be sent by registered mail to such person. Such notice shall advise that the owner will have thirty (30) days from and after the date of the service of the notice within which to remove such tree, trees or dead wood and have same destroyed. In case of the failure of the owner to do the same or have same done within the thirty-day period, the village will do so or cause same to be done at the cost and expense of the owner. The notice otherwise shall contain the substance of section 11-20-12 of the Illinois Municipal Code [65 ILCS 5/11-20-12] as amended. 
(Ord. No. 11-O-58, § 2, 9-27-11) 
Sec. 15-30. - Removal by village; lien. 
    In case the owner of a lot or land refuses or neglects to remove any tree, trees or dead wood under this article within thirty (30) days after the notice is served, the director of public works or designee shall proceed to remove or have same removed and duly destroyed, and to collect from the property owner the reasonable cost thereof. This cost is a lien upon the real estate affected, superior to all other liens and encumbrances, except tax liens; provided that notice has been given as herein described; and further provided that within sixty (60) days after such cost and expense is incurred the village, or person performing the service by authority of the village in his own name, files notice of lien in the office of the county recorder of deeds. The notice shall consist of a sworn statement setting out: 
(1)  A description of the real estate sufficient for identification thereof. 
(2)  The amount of money representing the cost and expense incurred or payable for the service. 
(3)  The date or dates when such cost and expense was incurred by the village. 
    However, the lien of the village shall not be valid as to any purchaser whose rights in and to such real estate have arisen subsequent to the tree removal and prior to the filing of such notice, and the lien of the village shall not be valid as to any mortgagee, judgment creditor or other lienor whose rights in and to such real estate arise prior to the filing of such notice. Upon payment of the cost and expense by the owner of or persons interested in such property after notice of lien has been filed, the lien shall be released by the village or person in whose name the lien has been filed and the release may be filed of record as in the case of filing notice of lien. 
(Ord. No. 11-O-58, § 2, 9-27-11) 
Sec. 15-31. - Cost of removal in addition to penalties. 
    If the village removes from any lot or land in the village any infected elm, ash or chestnut tree which is a public nuisance, or any dead or substantially dead elm tree or dead elm wood, ash tree or dead ash wood and chestnut tree or dead chestnut wood, the assessment of the cost of the work done by the village against the owner of the lot or land involved shall be in addition to the penalties imposed in this article for any violation or noncompliance with any provision of this article. 
(Ord. No. 11-O-58, § 2, 9-27-11) 
Sec. 15-32. - Property owned by village. 
    Any elm tree or dead elm wood, ash tree or dead ash wood and chestnut tree or dead chestnut wood on property owned by the village which is a public nuisance shall be removed promptly and disposed under the supervision of the director of public works or designee at the expense of the village. 
(Ord. No. 11-O-58, § 2, 9-27-11) 
Sec. 15-33. - Violations. 
    Any person violating any of the provisions of this article by failing, neglecting or refusing to comply with the provisions of any notice herein provided for, within thirty (30) days after the service thereof, or who shall resist or obstruct the director of public works or designee in carrying out the provisions of this article is guilty of an offense. 
(Ord. No. 11-O-58, § 2, 9-27-11) 
Secs. 15-34-15-50. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - WEEDS[3] 

Footnotes: 
--- (3) --- 
State Law reference- Weed destruction and abatement, 65 ILCS 5/11-20-6, 5/11-20-7. 

Sec. 15-51. - Nuisance. 
(a)  All noxious weeds, including, but not limited to, burdock, ragweed (giant), ragweed (common), thistle, cockleburr, jimson, blue vervain, wild carrot, poison ivy, wild mustard, rough pigweed, lambsquarter, wild lettuce, curled dock, smartweeds (all varieties), poison hemlock, wild hemp, deadly nightshade (atropa belladonna) and weeds which due to pollination are a menace to health and weeds otherwise injurious to public health or welfare, are hereby declared to be a public nuisance. 
(b)  It shall be unlawful for any person owning or controlling any plot of ground to permit the growth of such weeds thereon. 
(Code 1977, § 12.6(a); Ord. No. 17-O-46, § 2, 5-9-17; Ord. No. 17-O-70, § 2, 8-8-17) 
Sec. 15-52. - Removal. 
(a)  All such weeds shall be cut, pulled, destroyed or chemically sprayed with 2-4-D sprays or other equally efficient chemical weed killer by the owner or person in control of the plot of ground at least twice a year, once between May 1 and June 15 and once between July 15 and August 1 of each year. 
(b)  The failure to destroy such weeds within the designated periods shall constitute a violation of this section. 
(c)  In addition to liability for the cost of destruction of such weeds by the village, the owner or person in control of any such plot of ground in the village failing to destroy the weeds thereon within the designated periods of time shall upon conviction be subject to the fine provided for violation of this Code. 
(Code 1977, § 12.6(b), (f)) 
Sec. 15-53. - Destruction by village. 
    When the owner or person in control of any plot of ground fails to destroy or spray weeds growing thereon as provided herein, the director of public works shall destroy or cause to be destroyed such weeds, and any expense incurred by the village or under the authority of the director of public works in so doing shall be a charge against the owner or other person so failing, which may be recovered in an appropriate action at law to be instituted on behalf of the village or the person performing the service by authority of the village. 
(Code 1977, § 12.6(c)) 
Sec. 15-54. - Notice of lien. 
(a)  If weeds are cut by this village or by someone directed to cut them on behalf of the village, a notice of lien of the cost and expense thereof incurred by this village shall be recorded in the following manner: the village or the person performing the service by authority of the village, in its or his own name, may file notice of lien in the office of the county recorder of deeds. The notice of lien shall consist of a sworn statement setting out: 
(1)  A description of the real estate sufficient for identification thereof; 
(2)  The amount of money representing the cost and expense incurred or payable for the service; 
(3)  The date or dates when such cost and expense was incurred by the village; 
and shall be filed within sixty (60) days after the cost and expense is incurred. 
(b)  Upon payment of the cost and expense after notice of lien has been filed, the lien shall be released by the village or person in whose name the lien has been filed and the release shall be filed of record in the same manner as filing notice of the lien. 
(Code 1977, § 12.6(d), (e)) 
Secs. 15-55-15-70. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE IV. - JUNKED VEHICLES[4] 

Footnotes: 
--- (4) --- 
Cross reference- Traffic, Ch. 23; parking and storage on private property in residential districts, § 26-351 et seq. 

Sec. 15-71. - Definition. 
    For the purposes of this article, the words "junked motor vehicle" or "disabled motor vehicle" shall mean any vehicle, including trailers, which is without currently valid license plates, and/or in either wrecked, discarded, dismantled, inoperative, or abandoned condition. 
(Code 1977, § 12.7(a)) 
Cross reference- Definitions and rules of construction generally, § 1-2. 
Sec. 15-72. - Prohibited acts. 
(a)  Parking and storing. Junked or disabled motor vehicles may not be parked, stored, or left in the open, on private property within the village unless it is necessary for the operation of a business enterprise lawfully conducted thereon. 
(b)  Motor vehicle parts. The storing, placing, or allowing to remain in the open on private property within the village of motor vehicle bodies, parts, equipment, motors, and materials for a period of more than forty-eight (48) hours in any one (1) calendar month is hereby prohibited, unless necessary for the operation of a business enterprise lawfully conducted thereon. 
(c)  Nuisance. The parking or storing of junked or disabled motor vehicles and the storing or allowing to remain in the open of motor vehicle bodies, parts, equipment, motors, and materials, in violation of subsections (a) and (b), is declared to constitute a public nuisance. 
(Code 1977, § 12.7(b)-(d)) 
Sec. 15-73. - Notice to abate. 
(a)  The village shall notify the person in control of any private property to relocate any junked or disabled vehicle parked or stored in violation of this article to a completely enclosed location on the property or otherwise to remove the same from the premises. 
(b)  The village shall also notify the person in control of any private property to relocate any motor vehicle bodies, parts, equipment, motors, and materials stored, placed, or allowed to remain in the open, in violation of this article, to a completely enclosed location on the property, or otherwise to remove the same from the premises. Such notice shall be given by certified or registered mail addressed to the residence or usual place of business of such person. 
(c)  No person shall fail to comply with such a notice. 
(Code 1977, § 12.7(e), (h)) 
Sec. 15-74. - Action on noncompliance. 
    After the expiration of five (5) days from the receipt of the notice to abate a nuisance under this article, if the person so notified has failed, neglected or refused to comply with the directions of such notice, the village shall pay for the removal and disposal of such vehicles, bodies, parts, etc., or order the removal and disposal by the village. 
(Code 1977, § 12.7(f)) 
Sec. 15-75. - Liability for expense of disposal. 
    If the village is required to remove and dispose of vehicles, bodies, parts, etc., under this article, the person in control of the premises shall be liable to the village for the expense incurred by the village. A statement shall be rendered to the person liable for the cost thereof, and if not paid, suit shall be instituted. 
(Code 1977, § 12.7(g)) 
Chapter 16 - PARKS AND RECREATION[1] 
  
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference- Park and recreation advisory commission, § 2-366 et seq. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 16-1. - System. 
(a)  Created. There is hereby created a playground and recreation system for the village. 
(b)  Duties and responsibilities. The corporate authorities shall have power to maintain, equip and operate playgrounds and recreation centers, programs thereof and the buildings thereon, and for that purpose may employ play leaders, playground directors, supervisors, recreation superintendents, or such other officers or employees as they may deem proper, and in general, shall possess all of the powers and be subject to all of the responsibilities of the corporate authorities under article 11, division 95 of the Illinois Municipal Code [65 ILCS 5/11-95-1 et seq.]. 
(Code 1977, § 2.24(a), (c); Ord. No. 81-0-16, § 1, 6-23-81) 
Secs. 16-2-16-45. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - PARK RULES 

Sec. 16-46. - Scope. 
    This article governs the use of the public parks of the village. 
(Code 1977, § 2.21.1) 
Sec. 16-47. - Park permits. 
    All groups in excess of twenty-five (25) people using village parks are required to secure a park permit no less than five (5) days prior to the park use. Residents can secure permits any time after January 1 of the year of the use. Nonresidents can secure permits no sooner then two (2) weeks prior to the date of use. Users must have their permits with them during the park use and must show them if requested. 
(Ord. No. 99-O-16, § 2, 2-23-99) 
Sec. 16-48 - Butler Lake fishing permits. 
    Any person fishing in and around Butler Lake must first obtain a permit from the village. The permit will allow the permit holder to fish from designated fishing areas. Fishing from the Lake Street bridge and in the native prairie plant areas along the shore is prohibited. Fishing is limited to the use of hook and line, while fishing with spears, bow and arrow or nets is prohibited. 
(1)  Any person fishing in the waterways and tributaries of Butler Lake must comply with the village catch and release fishing regulations which will be published on an annual basis. 
(2)  The permits are for fishing only and shall not be construed to authorize the use of outboard or inboard motors on Butler Lake or other waters connected therewith which are situated in the village. The use of outboard and inboard motors thereon is expressly prohibited. 
(3)  Butler Lake fishing permits shall be sold at the parks and recreation office and at the village hall during regular business hours. 
(4)  Butler Lake fishing permits shall be issued on an annual basis commencing on May 1 and expiring on April 30. Butler Lake fishing permits will be provided at no cost for Village of Libertyville residents, and will be ten dollars ($10.00) for nonresidents as established by the annual fee ordinance. 
(5)  Each applicant for a Butler Lake fishing permit, on completion of an application form and payment of fee, if required, shall be provided a permit in the form of a card or taken of such design and material as may be approved by the village which shall be carried by the applicant whenever fishing around Butler Lake. 
(6)  Section 1-12 general penalties will apply to any violations. Such violations may include a minimum of a fifteen dollar ($15.00) and maximum five hundred dollar ($500.00) penalty. Violations will be issued by the village under a village ordinance ticket. 
(Code 1977, § 2.21.3; Ord. No. 08-O-33, § 2, 5-27-08; Ord. No. 10-O-56, § 2, 5-25-10) 
Sec. 16-49. - Animals. 
    No person shall lead or allow to be loose upon park premises any animal, except that horses may be ridden by the persons in charge thereof, or driven before a vehicle attached thereto, on such portions of the park system as may be designated for riding and driving and that dogs may be taken into the park system provided they are held by a suitable line, chain or strap and provided, the person removes any and all feces deposited by the animal; provided, however, that no one shall lead or allow any dog to be upon any portion of the park premises where dogs are prohibited by direction of the corporate authorities as indicated by sign or notice. 
(Code 1977, § 2.21.1(a); Ord. No. 96-0-33, § 2, 6-13-96) 
Sec. 16-50. - Games and sports. 
    No person shall engage in any sport, game or amusement in the park system except such portions thereof as may be designated by the board of trustees and then only under such rules and regulations as may be prescribed by the board. No person or group shall bring into any park premises any carnival ride, moon walk, dunk tank, animal rides, petting zoos or similar amusement devices except by special permission of the corporate authorities. 
(Code 1977, § 2.21.1(b); Ord. No. 96-0-33, § 6, 6-13-96) 
Sec. 16-51. - Firearms and fireworks. 
    No person shall carry or discharge firearms or things containing any substance of an explosive nature in the park system except by special permission of the corporate authorities. 
(Code 1977, § 2.21.1(c)) 
Sec. 16-52. - Throwing stones. 
    No person shall throw or cast any stone or other projectile within the park system, except as authorized pursuant to section 16-50. 
(Code 1977, § 2.21.1(d); Ord. No. 96-0-33, § 3, 6-13-96) 
Sec. 16-53. - Hindering employees. 
    No person shall interfere with, or in any manner hinder, any employee of the village while engaged in construction, repairing or caring for any park property. 
(Code 1977, § 2.21.1(f)) 
Sec. 16-54. - Offering articles for sale. 
    No person shall offer for sale any article, thing or service, or do any hawking, peddling or soliciting, or buy or offer to buy any article or thing, or take any collection or solicit or receive contributions of money or anything of value in the park system, except when authorized to do so by permit from or contract with the corporate authorities. 
(Code 1977, § 2.21.1(g)) 
Sec. 16-55. - Driving. 
    No person shall operate any motor vehicle, including (without limitation) any automobile, truck, motorcycle, motorbike, minibike, or snowmobile, on any public park within the village except upon a paved driveway or paved parking area. This prohibition shall not apply to village maintenance vehicles operated by those employed by or under contract with the village to provide maintenance or other services in any such public park and this prohibition shall not apply to the operating of a vehicle upon any such public park pursuant to special permit granted by the village board incidental to the holding of some public event or for some other public purpose, subject, however, to such supervision and conditions, if any, as may be prescribed by the village board in granting such special permit. 
(Code 1977, § 41.2.86) 
Sec. 16-56. - Public meetings. 
    No person shall call or hold any public meeting or give any concert or public entertainment of any kind in the park system without the express consent of the corporate authorities. 
(Code 1977, § 2.21.1(h)) 
Sec. 16-57. - Restricted period. 
    No person shall be or remain in any public park of the village at any time during the period between 9:30 p.m. of any day and 6:00 a.m. of the immediately succeeding day, except when authorized to do so by permit from or contract with the corporate authorities, except officials and employees of the village making inspections or on village business, and except that this shall not prohibit anyone from passing through a park on a public sidewalk or public thoroughfare. 
(Code 1977, § 2.21.1(l)) 
Sec. 16-58. - Use of playground equipment by adults. 
    No adult person shall in any manner use any of the playground apparatus or devices meant exclusively for the use of children. 
(Code 1977, § 2.21.1(m)) 
Sec. 16-59. - Obstructing travel. 
    No person shall set or place or cause to be set or placed any goods, wares or merchandise or property of any kind so as to obstruct travel in the park system. 
(Code 1977, § 2.21.1(n)) 
Sec. 16-60. - Fires. 
    No person shall light or make use of any fire in the park system, except such portions thereof as may be designated by the corporate authorities for such purpose and then only under such regulations as are prescribed by the corporate authorities. 
(Code 1977, § 2.21.1(o)) 
Sec. 16-61. - Drunkenness; intoxicating liquors. 
    No person shall bring within, sell, give away or drink any intoxicating liquors in the park system; provided, however, alcoholic liquors may be consumed in buildings and upon golf courses owned by the village in such areas as shall from time to time be designated by the corporate authorities. 
(Code 1977, § 2.21.1(p); Ord. No. 82-0-17, § 1, 3-23-82) 
Sec. 16-62. - Dumping articles. 
    No person shall deposit, dump, throw or place any coal, ashes, dust, manure or rubbish in or upon any part of the park system, except as authorized by the corporate authorities. Paper, garbage, or refuse matter shall not be so deposited except in receptacles provided for that purpose. 
(Code 1977, § 2.21.1(q)) 
Sec. 16-63. - Advertisements. 
    No person shall display any placard or advertisement of any kind in the park system, nor shall any person distribute, cast, throw or place any handbill, pamphlet, circular, advertisement or notice of any kind, nor post, stencil or otherwise affix any notice, or bills, advertisement or other papers upon any structure or thing in or about the park premises, except as authorized by the corporate authorities. 
(Code 1977, § 2.21.1(r)) 
Sec. 16-64. - Protection of birds, animals. 
    No person shall trap, catch, wound or kill, or treat cruelly, or attempt to trap, catch, wound or kill any bird or animal, or molest or rob any nest of any bird or animal in the park system. 
(Code 1977, § 2.21.1(s)) 
Sec. 16-65. - Bringing plants, shrubs or trees. 
    No person shall bring into or upon the park system any tree, shrub or plant or any newly plucked branch or portion of a tree, shrub or plant, except as authorized by the corporate authorities. 
(Code 1977, § 2.21.1(t)) 
Sec. 16-66. - Damage to park property. 
    No person shall remove, cut, break or in any way injure or deface any tree, shrub, plant, turf, or any of the buildings, fences, bridges, lamps or posts or other structure or property within the park system. 
(Code 1977, § 2.21.1(u); Ord. No. 96-0-33, § 4, 6-13-96) 
Sec. 16-67. - Resisting or interfering with officer. 
    No person shall resist any village trustee or police officer of the village in the discharge of his duty, or fail or refuse to obey any lawful command of any such village trustee or police officer or in any way interfere with or hinder or prevent any such village trustee or police officer from discharging his duty, or in any manner assist or give aid to any person in custody to escape or to attempt to escape from custody, or rescue or attempt to rescue any person when in such custody. 
(Code 1977, § 2.21.1(w)) 
Sec. 16-68. - Golf. 
    No person shall golf, or hit golf balls in the park system, except for those areas that are specifically designated by the village for golf. 
(Ord. No. 96-0-33, § 5, 6-13-96) 
Sec. 16-69. - Camping on public parks or other public property. 
(a)  For purposes of this section, camping is defined to include any of the following acts when occurring on any public property: 
(1)  Placement or erection of a temporary structure for use as a shelter or other form of temporary housing; 
(2)  Building a fire upon public property other than with a village-owned barbecue or fire pit device; 
(3)  Residing within a vehicle which includes one or more living unit systems; 
(4)  Placement of personal possessions on public property, including, but not limited to, baggage, luggage, carts and clothing; 
(5)  Sleeping on public property in such a manner as to indicate an intention to utilize such public property as an alternative to an indoor sleeping location. 
(b)  Except as otherwise provided in this section, it shall be unlawful for any person or organization of persons to camp on a public street, public sidewalk, public highway, public building or public parking lot. 
(c)  It shall be unlawful for any person or organization of persons to camp within any public park, except within public parks designated by this section and only upon having first received a permit issued by the village administrator. Said permit shall designate the names of the persons or organizations seeking to utilize a public park for camping purposes and shall be valid for a period of not more than twenty-four (24) hours. 
(d)  Camping within public parks shall only be allowed by persons or organizations holding valid permits issued by the village administrator, during the dates and times which may be designated upon such permits, and only within the following public parks: Butler Lake Park, Adler Park and the Libertyville Sports Complex. 
(e)  Every person who engages in camping activities in violation of this section shall be guilty of a misdemeanor and upon a finding of guilty such person shall be punished by a fine of not less than two hundred fifty dollars ($250.00) and not in excess of seven hundred fifty dollars ($750.00) or by imprisonment for a period which shall not exceed six (6) months or by both such fine and imprisonment. A separate offense shall be deemed to occur on each day during or upon which a violation occurs or continues. 
(Ord. No. 02-O-92, § 2, 8-13-02) 
Chapter 17 - PEDDLERS, SOLICITORS, ETC.[1] 
  
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference- Licenses, taxation and miscellaneous business regulations, Ch. 13. 
State Law reference- Authority to license, tax, regulate and prohibit hawkers and peddlers, 65 ILCS 5/11-42-5. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Secs. 17-1-17-25. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - HAWKERS AND PEDDLERS 

Sec. 17-26. - Exceptions. 
    The provisions of this article shall not apply to any person selling the products of his farm or to any wholesale dealer or to any public officer in the necessary discharge of his duty. 
(Code 1977, § 21.3(f)) 
Sec. 17-27. - License. 
(a)  Required. It shall be unlawful for any person to engage in the business of hawker or peddler within the village without a license for such business. 
(b)  Application. The application for a license required by this section shall be made in writing to the village clerk, shall set forth the residence address of the applicant, and shall set forth such additional information requested by the officials charged with the issuance of the license which will reasonably show whether the license should or should not be granted to the applicant and will aid in the enforcement of and in checking on the compliance with this article. 
(c)  Term; fee. Only one (1) type of license shall be issued under this section. Such license shall be a yearly license and shall expire on April 30 following the date of issuance. A license fee in the amount established by the annual fee ordinance shall be paid to the village for each license issued hereunder. 
(d)  Issuance. Upon the filing of an application for a license under the provisions of this section with the village clerk, together with the amount of the license fee herein provided, the village clerk shall examine the application. If he finds the same satisfactory and that all conditions for the issuance of a license have been complied with, the clerk shall thereupon submit the same to the president of the board of trustees. If the president shall be satisfied that all requirements for the issuance of the license have been complied with, he shall cause a license to be issued in accordance with such application. 
(Code 1977, § 21.3(a)-(d)) 
Sec. 17-28. - Leaving premises upon request. 
    No person soliciting business under a license issued under this article shall force his way into a home or place of solicitation against the will of the person in charge thereof nor make of himself a nuisance to the occupant or occupants thereof. Anyone soliciting business under a license issued hereunder shall, in case of being requested to leave a place where he is doing any such solicitation by the person in charge thereof, leave such premises promptly upon such request being made. 
(Code 1977, § 21.3) 
Sec. 17-29. - Fraud; misrepresentation. 
    No person soliciting business under any license under this article shall resort to any fraud, cheating or misrepresentation in connection with such solicitation. 
(Code 1977, § 21.3) 
Sec. 17-30. - Violation of laws. 
    No person soliciting business under this article shall violate any of the provisions of this Code, ordinances of the village or laws of the state or of the United States in connection with such solicitation. 
(Code 1977, § 21.3) 
Secs. 17-31-17-45. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - TRANSIENT MERCHANTS AND ITINERANT MERCHANTS[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 14-O-39, § 2, adopted June 10, 2014, repealed Art. III in its entirety and enacted a new Art. III to read as set out herein. Former Art. III, §§ 17-46-17-48, pertained to similar subject matter and derived from the Code of 1977, §§ 21.4(a)-(d); Ord. No. 08-O-32, § 2, adopted May 27, 2008. 

Sec. 17-46. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Itinerant merchant means any person engaging temporarily in selling at wholesale or retail any goods, wares or merchandise, including the selling of photographs, regardless of whether such goods, wares, merchandise or photographs are sold from house to house or sold from any room, building or other structure or lot, rented or leased, in whole or in part, for the purpose of carrying on such business. 
    Mobile vendor means any person who offers for sale and immediate delivery any food, goods or merchandise from any motorized vehicle or any trailer, cart or other container attached to or intended to be attached to any motorized vehicle. 
    Transient vendor of merchandise means any person who engages in, does or transacts any temporary or transient business in the village by selling goods, wares or merchandise and who or which for the purpose of carrying on such business, hires, leases, or occupies in whole or in part, any room, building or other structure, vehicle, store, shop, vacant lot or parking lot for the exhibition and sale of goods, wares and merchandise. Mobile vendors and anyone conducting business as above set forth within the village for the period of less than one hundred eighty (180) days shall be deemed a transient vendor of merchandise. 
(Ord. No. 14-O-39, § 2, 6-10-14) 
Sec. 17-47. - Exceptions. 
    The provisions of this article shall not apply to the sales made directly to businesses, retail establishments or service companies. These provisions will also not apply to business by commercial travelers or selling agents in the usual course of business, nor to sales by producers of vegetables, fruit or perishable farm products, where such produce was raised or produced on the premises of the seller. Anyone engaged in the business of hawker or peddler who has a hawker's or peddler's license issued by the village shall not be required to secure a license hereunder for any period of time during which such hawker's or peddler's license remains in force if he does not engage in any business covered by this other than that which is construed as that of hawker or peddler. 
(Ord. No. 14-O-39, § 2, 6-10-14) 
Sec. 17-48. - License. 
(a)  License required. No person whether for himself or agent for someone else, or as agent or officer of a corporation shall engage in the business of a transient vendor of merchandise or itinerant merchant nor sell any article, thing or merchandise without a license therefor. Application for such license shall state the name of the person desiring the license, the residence, room, building, store, shop, vacant lot or parking lot, tent or other structure in which he expects to do business or whether it is desired to pass from place to place in the village, the make and character of the goods, wares and merchandise intended to be sold, the length of time desired to do business in the village. In the event that the person seeking the license desires to operate as a mobile vendor, the application shall so state and shall include: 
(1)  The model, make, vehicle license number and vehicle identification number of the vehicles which the applicant intends to use in connection with the license; 
(2)  The name, address and copy of driver's license of any person who will be operating the vehicle; 
(3)  A waiver signed by the owner and any driver of any vehicle intended to be used in connection with the license authorizing the village to conduct a background check on each driver and each individual doing business under the license and the owner which is satisfactory to the village; 
(4)  A copy of all required health department permits; and 
(5)  Such additional information requested by the officials charged with the issuance of the license which will reasonably show whether the license should be granted to the applicant and will aid in the enforcement of and in checking on the compliance with this article. 
(b)  Restriction on licenses for mobile vendors. All licenses issued to mobile vendors shall be subject to the following restrictions: 
(1)  Except in connection with special events which are specifically approved by the village board or block parties which have been authorized and permitted by the village, the sale and delivery of food, goods and merchandise shall only take place upon private zoning lots, with the permission of the owner of such zoning lot, within residential, commercial, industrial or office districts, and shall not be permitted upon any public streets within the village. 
(2)  Except in connection with special events which are specifically approved by the village board or block parties authorized and permitted by the village, the sale and delivery of food, goods and merchandise by a mobile vendor shall not take place within the C-1 downtown core commercial district. 
(3)  Mobile vendors shall at all times maintain a commercial general liability insurance policy with limits of liability of not less than one million dollars ($1,000,000.00) per occurrence and two million dollars ($2,000,000.00) in the aggregate as well as business or commercial automobile liability coverage, including non-owned and hired automobile liability coverage, with limits of liability in an amount not less than three hundred thousand dollars ($300,000.00). 
(4)  Mobile vendors shall remove and properly dispose of any trash generated by the mobile vendor operation. 
(5)  A mobile vendor shall not operate upon a single zoning lot for a period in excess of one (1) hour on more than four (4) calendar days during any twelve-month period. The four (4) calendar days that a mobile vendor elects to operate upon a single zoning lot for a period in excess of one (1) hour must be separated by not less than fourteen (14) days. 
(6)  Mobile vendors shall only operate on zoning lots within residential zoning districts between the hours of 9:00 a.m. and 9:00 p.m. 
(7)  Mobile vendors shall not operate upon any zoning lot for a period of more than eight (8) hours during any twenty-four-hour period. 
(8)  Licenses issued to mobile vendors must be displayed and visible to customers of the mobile vendors at all times. 
(9)  Only such signage which is painted upon the vehicle may be displayed by the mobile vendor upon the zoning lot on which the mobile vendor is operating. 
(10)  No external speakers shall be utilized by a mobile vendor during its operation. 
(11)  No outdoor seating surfaces shall be provided by a mobile vendor for use by employees or customers of the mobile vendor during its operation. 
(12)  Mobile vendors shall only park within zoning lots in a manner which does not block aisle for vehicular traffic or interfere with the flow of vehicular or pedestrian traffic. 
(13)  At any time not more than five (5) licenses shall be issued for mobile vendors within the village. Not more than one (1) vehicle may be operated in connection with the license issued to a mobile vendor and not more than one (1) license shall be issued to any person, firm, corporation or other entity. 
(c)  The fee for a license under this article is as established by the annual fee ordinance. 
(d)  No license shall be good for more than one (1) person, unless there is a partnership, nor for more than one (1) place of business. 
(Ord. No. 14-O-39, § 2, 6-10-14) 
Secs. 17-49-17-65. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE IV. - SOLICITORS 
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 17-66. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Authorized employee means the business owner or manager, or such person empowered by the business owner or manager to make the determination as provided for in section 17-67. 
    Business establishment means any stationary structure which is in use for commercial, retail, office or professional purposes. 
    Registered solicitor means any person who has obtained a valid certificate of registration, as provided in this article, and which certificate is worn by the solicitor, while engaged in soliciting in the manner provided in this division. 
    Residence means any separate living unit occupied for residential purposes by one (1) or more persons, contained within any type of building or structure, and the yard area upon which such residence is located. 
    Soliciting means any one (1) or more of the following activities: 
(1)  Seeking to obtain orders for the purchase of goods, wares, merchandise, foodstuffs, services of any kind, character or description whatever, for any kind of consideration whatever. 
(2)  Seeking to obtain prospective customers for application or purchase of insurance of any type, kind or character. 
(3)  Seeking to obtain subscriptions to books, magazines, periodicals, newspapers and every other type or kind of publications. 
(4)  Seeking to obtain gifts or contributions of money, clothing or any other valuable thing for the support or benefit of any charitable or nonprofit association, organization, corporation or project. 
(Code 1977, § 25.1; Ord. No. 06-O-82, § 2, 9-12-06) 
Cross reference- Definitions and rules of construction generally, § 1-2. 
Sec. 17-67. - Policy on soliciting. 
    It is hereby declared to be the policy of the board of trustees that the occupant of a residence, or authorized employee of a business establishment in this village shall make the determination of whether solicitors shall be, or shall not be, invited to a residence or business establishment. If no determination is made as is provided in section 17-68, registration under this article is not required. 
(Code 1977, § 25.3; Ord. No. 06-O-82, § 3, 9-12-06) 
Sec. 17-68. - Notice refusing solicitations. 
    Every person desiring to secure the protection intended to be provided by the regulations pertaining to soliciting contained in this article shall comply with the following directions: 
(1)  Notice of the determination by the occupant of giving invitation to solicitors, or the refusal of invitation to solicitors, to any residence, shall be given in the manner following: 
a.  A weatherproof card, approximately three (3) inches by four (4) inches in size, shall be exhibited upon or near the main entrance door to the residence, indicating the determination by the occupant, containing the applicable words, as follows: 
"ONLY SOLICITORS 
REGISTERED IN 
LIBERTYVILLE INVITED" 
or 
"NO SOLICITORS INVITED" 
b.  The letters shall be at least one-third inch in height. For the purpose of uniformity, the cards shall be provided by the chief of police to persons requesting at the cost thereof. 
(2)  Such card so exhibited shall constitute sufficient notice to any solicitor of the determination by the occupant of a resident or authorized employee of a business establishment of the information contained thereon. 
(Code 1977, § 25.4; Ord. No. 06-O-82, § 4, 9-12-06) 
Sec. 17-69. - Obedience to notice. 
    It shall be the duty of every solicitor upon going onto any premises in the village upon which a residence or business establishment is located to first examine the notice provided for in section 17-68, if any is attached, and be governed by the statement contained on the notice. 
(1)  If the notice states "Only Solicitors Registered in Libertyville Invited," then the solicitor not possessing a valid certificate of registration as herein provided shall immediately and peacefully depart from the premises. 
(2)  If the notice states "No Solicitors Invited," the solicitor, whether registered or not, shall immediately and peacefully depart from the premises. 
(Code 1977, § 25.5; Ord. No. 06-O-82, § 5, 9-12-06) 
Sec. 17-70. - Departure upon request. 
    Any solicitor, whether invited or not, shall immediately and peacefully depart from the premises when requested to do so by the occupant or authorized employee. 
(Code 1977, §§ 25.5, 25.6; Ord. No. 06-O-82, § 6, 9-12-06) 
Sec. 17-71. - Uninvited soliciting. 
    It is unlawful and shall constitute a nuisance for any person to go upon any premises and ring the doorbell upon or near any door, or create any sound in any other manner calculated to attract the attention of the occupant thereof and engage in soliciting in defiance of the notice exhibited in accordance with the provisions of section 17-68. 
(Code 1977, § 25.7) 
Sec. 17-72. - Hours of operation. 
    Permitted hours of operation are from 9:00 a.m. to 9:00 p.m. daily. It is unlawful for anyone to solicit at any residence in the village except during the permitted hours of operation. 
(Ord. No. 00-O-12, § 2, 3-14-00) 
Secs. 17-73-17-85. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - REGISTRATION 

Sec. 17-86. - Required; display. 
    No person without a valid certification of registration issued under this division by the chief of police shall engage in soliciting from persons in a residence within this village on premises where a notice is posted as provided in section 17-68 containing the following words "Only Solicitors Registered in Libertyville Invited." The certificate of registration shall be displayed conspicuously on the front of the outer garment of the solicitor at all times when the person is engaged in soliciting in the village. On or before the expiration date of the certificate of registration, the certificate shall be surrendered to the chief of police. 
(Code 1977, § 25.2(a)) 
Sec. 17-87. - Application. 
    Application for a certificate of registration shall be made upon a form provided by the village and shall be filed with the chief of police. The applicant shall state in full the information requested on the application, which shall include the following: 
(1)  Name and address of present place of residence and length of residence at such address; also business address, if other than residence address. 
(2)  Address of place of residence during the past three (3) years if other than present address. 
(3)  Age of applicant and marital status; and, if married, the name of spouse, date of birth, and social security number. 
(4)  Physical description of the applicant. 
(5)  Name and address of the person by whom the applicant is employed or represents, and the length of time of such employment or representation. In case the employer or principal is operating for a charitable, political, religious or other nonprofit purpose, evidence thereof shall be furnished with the application, which in the case of a charitable organization required by law to be registered with the attorney general of the state shall include evidence of such registration, including a copy of the then latest annual written report required to be filed with the attorney general, along with the financial statement to be included as a part thereof, and in the case of any other such nonprofit purpose then satisfactory evidence thereof shall also be furnished, which may be in the form of a copy of a current tax exempt certificate issued by the United States Internal Revenue Service. 
(6)  Name and address of employer during the past three (3) years if other than the present employer. 
(7)  Description sufficient for identification of the subject matter of the soliciting in which the applicant will engage. 
(8)  Period of time during which the soliciting will be conducted. 
(9)  The date, or approximate date, of the latest previous application for certificate under this division, if any. 
(10)  Whether a certificate of registration issued to the applicant under this division has ever been revoked. 
(11)  Whether the applicant has ever been convicted of a violation of any of the provisions of this division or of the ordinance of any other municipality in this state regulating soliciting. 
(12)  Whether the applicant has ever been convicted of the commission of a felony under the laws of the state or any other state or federal law of the United States. 
(13)  Such additional information as the chief of police may deem necessary to process the application; provided, however, if the applicant is soliciting for or representing an employer or principal operating for a charitable, religious, political or other nonprofit purpose, then the provisions of this paragraph shall not apply upon evidence being furnished of such nonprofit purpose pursuant to paragraph (5) above. 
(Code 1977, § 25.2(b)) 
State Law reference- Registration of charitable organizations that solicit contributions, 225 ILCS 460/1 et seq. 
Sec. 17-88. - Fingerprinting; photograph. 
    The chief of police shall require every applicant to submit to fingerprinting and photographing by the police department in connection with the application for a certificate hereunder; provided, however, that if the applicant is soliciting for or representing an employer or principal operating for a charitable, religious, political or other nonprofit purpose and evidence thereof is furnished, the applicant shall be exempt from fingerprinting and may, in lieu of being photographed by the police department, furnish a recent photograph of himself. 
(Code 1977, § 25.2(c)) 
Sec. 17-89. - Records. 
    The chief of police shall cause to be kept in his office an accurate record of every application received and acted upon together with all other information and data pertaining thereto, of all certificates of registration issued under the provisions of this division and of the denial of applications. Applications for certificates shall be numbered in consecutive order as filed. Every certificate issued shall have the number of the application endorsed thereon and each renewal thereof, if any, shall include thereon the number of the original application upon which it is issued. 
(Code 1977, § 25.2(d)) 
Sec. 17-90. - Issuance or denial. 
    The chief of police, after examination of the application, may deny the application and not issue a certificate of registration if the applicant has been convicted of the commission of a felony under the laws of the state or any other state or federal law of the United States within five (5) years before the date of the application; or has been convicted of a violation of any of the provisions of this division; or if applicant's certificate of registration issued hereunder has previously been revoked. Endorsement shall be made by the chief of police upon the application in the event of the denial of the application. When the applicant is found to be qualified, the certificate of registration shall be issued forthwith and be in effect immediately. Every certificate of registration shall state the expiration date thereof. 
(Code 1977, § 25.2(e)) 
Sec. 17-91. - Expiration date. 
    A certificate of registration (permit) shall expire ten (10) days from the date of issuance. 
(Code 1977, § 25.2(g); Ord. No. 00-O-12, § 3, 3-14-00) 
Sec. 17-92. - Suspension or revocation. 
(a)  Any certificate of registration issued under this division may be suspended by the chief of police if the holder of the certificate is arrested and booked in court for a violation of any of the provisions of this division, pending the final disposition by the court. 
(b)  Any certificate of registration issued hereunder shall be revoked by the chief of police if the holder of the certificate is convicted of a violation of any of the provisions of this division, or has made a false material statement in the application, or otherwise becomes disqualified for the issuance of a certificate of registration under the terms of this division. Immediately upon such revocation, written notice thereof shall be given by the chief of police to the holder of the certificate in person or by certified U.S. mail addressed to his legal address and business address set forth in the application. Thereupon, the certificate of registration shall become void. 
(Code 1977, § 25.2) 
Sec. 17-93. - Maximum number of solicitor permits to be issued. 
    A maximum of thirty (30) permits shall be issued to individual solicitors within each fiscal year. Individual solicitors shall be limited to one (1) permit per fiscal year. Solicitor-sponsoring organizations shall be limited to a maximum of ten (10) individual permits within each fiscal year. 
(Ord. No. 00-O-12, § 4, 3-14-00) 
Sec. 17-94. - Penalty for violation of sections 17-68 through section 17-86. 
    Any person, firm or corporation violating section 17-68 through section 17-86 of Chapter 17 of the Municipal Code shall be guilty of a misdemeanor punishable by a fine of not less than two hundred fifty dollars ($250.00), and not more than seven hundred fifty dollars ($750.00), and/or incarceration in a penal institution other than the penitentiary for a period not to exceed six (6) months, and/or being required to perform reasonable public service work, such as, but not limited to, the picking up of litter in the public parks or along public highways or the maintenance of public facilities. Any person, firm or corporation violating other sections of Chapter 17 of the Municipal Code shall be fined not less than ten dollars ($10.00) nor more than five hundred dollars ($500.00) for each offense. Separate offenses shall be deemed committed for each and every one-hour period during which a violation continues or exists. 
(Ord. No. 00-O-12, § 5, 3-14-00) 
ARTICLE V. - SOLICITATION ON HIGHWAYS 

Sec. 17-95. - When prohibited. 
(a)  No person shall stand in a roadway for the purpose of soliciting a ride from the driver of any vehicle. 
(b)  No person shall stand on a highway for the purpose of soliciting employment or business from the occupant of any vehicle. 
(c)  No person shall stand on or in the proximity of a highway for the purpose of soliciting the watching or guarding of any vehicle while parked or about to be parked on a highway. 
(Ord. No. 09-O-53, § 2, 6-23-09) 
Sec. 17-96. - Permit. 
    No person shall stand on a highway for the purpose of soliciting contributions from the occupant of any vehicle except after receiving a permit from the village. The names and date of birth of all persons soliciting shall be provided to the village before any village permit is issued. No more than one (1) permit per year, and each permit will be limited to a maximum of three (3) consecutive days, may be issued by the village. The location of the solicitation must be approved by the police chief. If more than one (1) application for a permit has been received by the village for the same intersection and date, then applications shall be reviewed on a first come first served basis. 
(Ord. No. 09-O-53, § 2, 6-23-09) 
Sec. 17-97. - Soliciting agency or person. 
(a)  A soliciting person or agency shall be registered with the attorney general as a charitable organization as provided by "An Act to regulate solicitation and collection of funds for charitable purposes, providing for violations thereof, and making an appropriation therefor," approved July 26, 1963, as amended (225 ILCS 460/1 et seq.). 
(b)  A soliciting person or agency shall be engaged in a statewide fund raising activity. 
(Ord. No. 09-O-53, § 2, 6-23-09) 
Sec. 17-98. - Liability. 
    The soliciting person and/or agency shall be liable for any injuries to any person or property during the solicitation which is casually related to an act of ordinary negligence of the soliciting agent, and will provide the village with a certificate of insurance for not less than one million dollars ($1,000,000.00) and naming the village as an additional insured. 
(Ord. No. 09-O-53, § 2, 6-23-09) 
Sec. 17-99. - Requirements. 
(a)  Any person engaged in the act of soliciting shall: 
(1)  Be sixteen (16) years of age or more; 
(2)  Be wearing a high visibility vest in accordance with village safety requirements; 
(3)  Be wearing visible identification of the organization undertaking the solicitation. 
(b)  Solicitation on highways within the village shall be allowed only at traffic control signal intersections when all traffic has come to a full stop and only on highways with a posted speed limit of thirty-five (35) mph or less, and only during daylight hours between 7:00 am. and 7:00 p.m. 
(Ord. No. 09-O-53, § 2, 6-23-09) 
Chapter 19 - POLICE[1] 
  
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
State Law reference- Board of police and fire commissioners, 65 ILCS 5/10-2.1-1 et seq. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Secs. 19-1-19-25. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - POLICE DEPARTMENT[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Cross reference- Officers and employees generally, § 2-76 et seq.; departments generally, § 2-116 et seq.; board of fire and police commissioners, § 2-226 et seq. 

Sec. 19-26. - Established; members. 
    There is hereby established an executive department of the municipal government of the village which shall be known as the police department. The department shall consist of a chief of police, and as many police officers and such other employees, if any, as the corporate authorities of the village may from time to time determine. The chief of police and all regular members of the police department are hereby made village officers. Employees that do not have general police duties shall not be considered regular members of the police department even though police powers may be conferred upon them, and shall not be considered village officers, but shall be considered employees of the village unless otherwise possessing some other status. 
(Code 1977, § 2.16.1(a)) 
Sec. 19-27. - Chief of police. 
    The chief of police shall be appointed by the president with the consent of the board of trustees and not by the board of fire and police commissioners. The chief of police shall superintend the work of the police department, and the police and other employees of the department, if any, as well as special police, if any, shall be under his command. The chief of police may exercise such powers, and shall perform such other duties as may be provided for by the ordinances of the village or by the resolutions or other action of the corporate authorities.
