Whenever any statute, ordinance or resolution refers to the "village marshal," "village constable" or similar title, it shall mean the chief of police. 
(Code 1977, § 2.16.5) 
Sec. 19-28. - Oath of police officers. 
    Each regular member of the police department, before entering upon his duties as a member of the department or before assuming to act as a special police officers as the case may be, shall take and subscribe the following oath or affirmation: 
"I do solemnly swear (or affirm) that I will support the Constitution of the United States, the Constitution of the State of Illinois, and the ordinances of the Village of Libertyville, and that I will faithfully discharge the duties of ___________ of (or appointed by) the village, according to the best of my ability." 
This oath or affirmation, so subscribed, shall be filed in the office of the village clerk. 
(Code 1977, § 2.16.3) 
Sec. 19-29. - Compensation and duties. 
    The compensation and duties of the chief of police, sergeants and other officers that are regular members of the police department shall be fixed and prescribed by the corporate authorities of the village. 
(Code 1977, § 2.16.1(c)) 
Sec. 19-30. - Rules; regulations. 
    The rules and regulations of the police department as heretofore adopted and amended by the board of trustees are adopted by reference. 
State Law reference- Adoption by reference, 65 ILCS 5/1-3-1 et seq., 50 ILCS 220/1 et seq. 
Sec. 19-31. - Police pension fund. 
    There is established a police pension fund, which fund is governed by the provisions of article 3 of the Illinois Pension Code [40 ILCS 5/3-101 et seq.]. 
(Code 1977, § 2.17(a)) 
Cross reference- Police pension board, § 2-401 et seq. 
State Law reference- Police pension fund required, 40 ILCS 5/3-101 et seq. 
Sec. 19-32. - Deputy chief of police. 
    The position of deputy chief of police is hereby established, pursuant to 65 ILCS 5/10-2.1-4 of the Illinois Compiled Statutes. The chief of police may appoint up to two (2) officers to the deputy chief of police position, provided that each deputy chief of police position has been authorized in accordance with the village budget process. Each such appointment by the chief of police shall be subject to the concurrence by the village administrator. Any person appointed to the position of deputy chief of police shall have served a minimum of five (5) years with the Libertyville Police Department and may be appointed from any rank within said department. 
    Any deputy chief of the police department may be removed from that position within the discretion of the chief of police, subject only to the concurrence of the village administrator. In the event that a deputy chief is removed from that position, he or she will be returned to the rank held by that individual immediately prior to the appointment to the position of deputy chief, regardless of whether a vacancy at that rank exits. 
(Ord. No. 04-O-06, § 2, 1-14-04) 
Chapter 20 - SOLID WASTE[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference- Keep Libertyville Beautiful Commission, § 2-186 et seq.; nuisances, Ch. 15; water, sewers and sewage disposal, Ch. 25. 
State Law reference- Disposal of refuse, garbage and ashes, 65 ILCS 5/11-19-1 et seq.; Local Solid Waste Disposal Act, 415 ILCS 10/1 et seq.; Solid Waste Planning and Recycling Act, 415 ILCS 15/1 et seq.; Solid Waste Management Act, 415 ILCS 20/1 et seq. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 20-1. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this chapter, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Aircraft means any contrivance used or designated for navigation or for flight in the air. 
    Authorized private receptacle means a litter storage and collection receptacle as required under this chapter. 
    Biodegradable paper bags means paper bags that, in the determination of the village administrator, are capable of being broken down by the action of microorganisms. 
    Collector means a contractor licensed by the village to perform solid waste, landscape waste or recyclables collection and disposal services in the village pursuant to this chapter. 
    Co-mingled recyclables means source separated, co-mingled and/or presorted materials delivered to a recycling facility consisting of ferrous metal cans, aluminum containers, glass and plastic, which shall include HDPE, PET ridged household containers, and plastics 3 through 5. 
    Commercial collection contractor means any person or firm engaged in providing commercial collection service. 
    Commercial collection service means municipal waste, landscape waste or recyclables collection and disposal services rendered to any building or other structure other than a single-family home, townhouse, duplex condominium or co-op residential and multifamily residential premises with four (4) or less individual residential units in the village. 
    Commercial handbill means any printed or written matter, any sample or device, dodger, circular, leaflet, pamphlet, paper, booklet or any other printed or otherwise reproduced original or copies of any matter of literature: 
(1)  Which advertises for sale any merchandise, product, commodity or thing. 
(2)  Which directs attention to any business or mercantile or commercial establishment, or other activity, for the purpose of either directly or indirectly promoting the interest thereof by sales. 
(3)  Which directs attention to or advertises any meeting, theatrical performance, exhibition, or event of any kind for which an admission fee is charged for the purpose of private gain or profit. 
(4)  Which, while containing reading matter other than advertising matter, is predominantly and essentially an advertisement, and is distributed or circulated for advertising purposes, or for the private benefit and gain of any person so engaged as advertiser or distributor. 
    Commercial resident means any person, firm, corporation or association maintaining a place of business in the village. 
    Composting means the biological process by which microorganisms decompose the organic fraction of waste under aerobic conditions, producing a humus-like product that may be used as a soil conditioner. 
    Contractor means any person engaged in providing services for the collection and disposal of solid waste, landscape waste or recyclables. 
    Exclusive residential collection services agreement means the agreement entered into between the residential collection contractor and the village, which agreement shall set forth the schedule of fees for residential collection of municipal waste, landscape waste and recyclables. 
    Garbage means any rejected or waste household food, offal, swill or carrion and every accumulation of animal, fruit or vegetable matter that attends the preparation, use, cooking, and dealing in, or storage of, meats, fish, fowl, fruits or vegetables and any other matter of any nature that is subject to decay, putrefaction and the generation of noxious or offensive gases or odor, or that, during or after decay, may serve as a breeding or feeding material for rodents, flies or other germ-carrying insects or animals. 
    Landscape waste means all accumulations of grass or shrubbery cuttings, leaves, tree limbs (as stated below), aquatic weeds, and other material accumulated as the result of the care of lawns, shrubbery, vines and trees, and as otherwise described at 415 ILCS 5/3.20. Landscape waste shall also include dead trees which have fallen within property located in residential neighborhoods and which have not been removed from such property or properly included within a compost pile. 
    Litter means garbage, refuse and rubbish as defined herein and all other waste material which, if thrown or deposited as herein prohibited, tends to create a danger to public health, safety and welfare. 
    Municipal waste means garbage, refuse, rubbish, industrial, lunchroom or office waste, and other material resulting from operation of residential, municipal, commercial or institutional establishments and from community activities and as otherwise described in 415 ILCS 5/3.21 which are not defined as recyclables or landscape waste. 
    Noncommercial handbill means any printed or written matter, any sample, or device, dodger, circular, leaflet, pamphlet, newspaper, magazine, paper, booklet or any other printed or otherwise reproduced original or copies of any matter of literature not included in the definition of a commercial handbill or newspaper. 
    Paper recyclables means source separated, co-mingled and/or pre-sorted paper products delivered to a recycling facility consisting of newsprint corrugated paper, junk mail, magazines, office paper, box board. 
    Private premises means any dwelling, house, building or other structure designed or used either wholly or in part for private residential purposes, whether inhabited or temporarily or continuously uninhabited or vacant, and shall include any yard, grounds, walk, driveway, porch, steps, vestibule or mailbox belonging or appurtenant to such dwelling, house, building or other structure. 
    Public place means any and all streets, sidewalks, boulevards, alleys or other public ways and any and all public squares, spaces, grounds and buildings. 
    Recyclable material or recyclables means single stream, co-mingled recyclables and/or paper recyclables. 
    Refuse means all putrescible and nonputrescible solid wastes (excepted body wastes), including garbage, rubbish, ashes, street cleanings and solid market and industrial wastes. 
    Resident means any person residing in the village. 
    Residential collection contractor means the person or firm designated by village ordinance to serve as the exclusive provider of residential collection services within the village. 
    Residential collection service means solid waste, landscape waste or recyclables collection and disposal services rendered to any single-family, townhouse, duplex condominium or co-op residential and multifamily residential premises with four (4) or less individual residential units in the village. 
    Rubbish means nonputrescible waste materials and refuse of every character other than landscape waste, consisting of both combustible and noncombustible wastes, collected or accumulated within the village, including without limitation paper, wrappings, cigarettes, cardboard, tin cans, wood, glass, stone, concrete, old boards, bedding, crockery, used furniture, household appliances and similar materials. 
    Solid waste means garbage and rubbish. 
    Vehicle means any device in, upon, or by which any person or property is or may be transported or drawn upon a highway. 
(Code 1977, §§ 12.8.1, 21.5(a); Ord. No. 89-0-31, § 1, 7-11-89; Ord. No. 89-0-32, § 1, 7-11-89; Ord. No. 90-0-25, § 1, 6-26-90; Ord. No. 91-0-28, § 1, 6-11-91; Ord. No. 93-0-3, § 2(8.1), 1-12-93; Ord. No. 04-O-30, § 2, 4-28-04; Ord. No. 06-O-28, § 2, 3-14-06; Ord. No. 12-O-01, § 2, 1-10-12) 
Cross reference- Definitions and rules of construction generally, § 1-2. 
Sec. 20-2. - Accumulations declared nuisance. 
    All accumulations of garbage, refuse and waste are declared a nuisance and shall be handled under the supervision of the board of trustees. 
(Code 1977, § 21.5; Ord. No. 89-0-31, § 1, 7-11-89) 
State Law reference- Authority to define nuisances, 65 ILCS 5/11-60-2. 
Sec. 20-3. - Findings. 
    It is hereby found and declared that the placement and maintenance of garbage in a container or containers, refuse or rubbish for pick-up and disposal purposes, or of garbage, refuse or refuse containers (whether filled, partially filled and/or empty during a part or parts of a period of time other than the twenty-four-hour exempt period specified in this section), upon a public parkway in this village, or upon the area of any premises in this village between a public street and a street side of any building located on such premises and the line of such side of such building extended to the property lines of the premises, for a continuous period of time exceeding twenty-four (24) hours during any weekly period, shall be deemed a public nuisance and a violation of the provisions hereof; provided, however, that this shall not apply to receptacles authorized by the corporate authorities of this village upon public places of the village for the receipt of litter. Notwithstanding anything to the contrary contained in this chapter, the owner or occupant in control of any premises within this village is hereby authorized to place and maintain within the public parkway adjacent to such premises, or within that part of such premises hereinbefore mentioned, for pick-up and disposal purposes, garbage in a container or containers, refuse or rubbish during any one (1) continuous twenty-four-hour period within any one (1) weekly period but not otherwise. The term "twenty-four-hour exempt period," as employed in this section, means the twenty-four-hour period specified in the sentence contained in this section, which immediately precedes this sentence. Any person that places or causes to be placed or maintained any garbage, refuse, or rubbish, or any such container or containers, upon any public parkway, or who places, causes to be placed, maintained or suffered to be placed or maintained any garbage, refuse or rubbish or any such container or containers, upon the above specified part of premises in this village under his control, other than as hereinbefore authorized, shall be deemed to have created a public nuisance in violation of the provisions hereof. No ashes, broken glass or other material, which cannot quickly and readily be picked up or raked up for disposal purposes without leaving some unsafe or unhealthful debris or an appreciable or undesirable amount of debris, shall be set out upon any parkway or area referred to herein, without being in a container or containers. It is hereby found that conditions prohibited under the provisions hereof are detrimental to the public health or safety, and/or jeopardize property values in the community, and thereby impair taxable values. 
(Code 1977, § 12.11) 
Sec. 20-4. - Deposit restrictions. 
(a)  Improper deposits prohibited. It shall be unlawful for any person to deposit anywhere in the village, or permit to be deposited on any premises under his control, any solid waste, landscape waste or recyclables except in accordance with the provisions of this chapter and all other codes, ordinances, resolutions, rules and regulations of the village, including without limitation chapter 15, pertaining to nuisances, and section 6-341 et seq., pertaining to the property maintenance code. 
(b)  Deposits in other containers prohibited. It shall be unlawful for any person to deposit any solid waste, landscape waste or recyclables in any container owned or lawfully controlled by another person without the consent of that other person. 
(c)  Deposits on other property prohibited. It shall be unlawful for any person to deposit any solid waste, landscape waste or recyclables of any kind, whether or not in a container, on any premises owned or lawfully controlled by another person without the consent of that other person. 
(d)  Deposits on rights-of-way prohibited. It shall be unlawful to deposit or permit to fall any solid waste, ashes, landscape waste or recyclables on any public street, alley or other right-of-way anywhere in the village; provided, however, that this subsection shall not be construed to prohibit the placement of solid waste, landscape waste or recyclables for collection in the manner provided in this chapter. 
(Ord. No. 93-0-3, § 2(8.2.2), 1-12-93) 
Sec. 20-5. - Theft and scavenging prohibited. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person knowingly to obtain, or exert by threat, deception, or other means, unauthorized control over any solid waste, landscape waste or recyclables or their containers. 
(Ord. No. 93-0-3, § 2(8.2.3), 1-12-93) 
Sec. 20-6. - Incineration. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to incinerate solid waste or landscape waste anywhere in the village. 
(Ord. No. 93-0-3, § 2(8.2.5), 1-12-93) 
Sec. 20-7. - Location of containers. 
    All containers used for solid waste or landscape waste shall be kept in an approved trash container area in accordance with the requirements of sections 6-341 and 6-342 et seq. pertaining to the property. 
(Ord. No. 93-0-3, § 2(8.2.4), 1-12-93; Ord. No. 15-O-07, § 4, 1-27-15) 
Sec. 20-8. - Payment of costs. 
(a)  Fees for commercial collection services. All residents shall pay directly to the commercial collection contractor providing services to such residents all fees in accordance with the terms of the contracts for such services between such residents and the commercial collection contractor. 
(b)  Fees for residential collection services. All residents shall pay directly to the residential collection contractor all fees in accordance with the terms of the exclusive residential collection services agreement. 
(c)  Use of stickers for residential collection services. Except to the extent that a resident pays a flat fee for residential collection services pursuant to the exclusive residential collection services agreement, all cans, bags or bundles placed for collection shall have properly affixed to them all required solid waste or landscape waste stickers. 
(Ord. No. 93-0-3, § 2(8.2.1), 1-12-93; Ord. No. 06-O-28, § 2, 3-14-06) 
Secs. 20-9-20-25. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - LITTER CONTROL[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
State Law reference- Litter Control Act, 415 ILCS 105/1 et seq. 

Sec. 20-26. - In public places. 
(a)  No person shall throw or deposit litter in or upon any street, sidewalk or other public place within the village, except in public receptacles or in authorized private receptacles for collection. Persons placing litter in public receptacles or in authorized private receptacles shall do so in such a manner as to prevent it from being carried or deposited by the elements upon any street, sidewalk or other public place. 
(b)  No person shall sweep into or deposit in any gutter, street or other public place within the village, the accumulation of litter from any building or lot or from any public or private sidewalk or driveway. Persons owning or occupying property shall keep the sidewalk in front of their premises free of litter. 
(Code 1977, § 12.8.2) 
State Law reference- Authority to prevent litter in streets, 65 ILCS 5/11-80-10. 
Sec. 20-27. - From vehicles. 
(a)  No person, while a driver or passenger in a vehicle, shall throw or deposit litter upon any street or other public place within the village. 
(b)  No person shall drive or move any truck or other vehicle within the village unless such vehicle is so constructed or loaded as to prevent any load or contents of litter from being blown or deposited upon any street, alley or other public place. Nor shall any person drive or move any vehicle or truck within the village, the wheels or tires of which carry onto or deposit in any street, alley or other public place, mud, dirt, sticky substances or foreign matter of any kind. 
(Code 1977, § 12.8.3) 
State Law reference- Litter from vehicle, 625 ILCS 5/15-109. 
Sec. 20-28. - From aircraft. 
    No person in an aircraft shall throw out, drop or deposit within the village any litter, handbill or any other object. 
(Code 1977, § 12.8.4) 
Sec. 20-29. - Protection of asphalt pavement. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to spill any turpentine, kerosene, gasoline, benzine, naphtha, coal oil, or any product thereof, or any oil used for lubricating, illuminating or fuel purposes; or to allow any of such fluids to escape to or upon any asphalt pavement of the village; or to operate or permit to be operated any tank, wagon or other vehicle from which any of such fluids are permitted to escape. 
(Code 1977, § 12.8.6) 
Sec. 20-30. - Handbills. 
(a)  Distribution in public places. No person shall throw or deposit any handbill in or upon any sidewalk, street or other public place within the village. It shall not be unlawful on any sidewalk, street, or other public place within the village for any person to hand out or distribute, without charge to the receiver thereof, any handbill to any person willing to accept it. 
(b)  Placing on vehicles. No person shall throw or deposit any commercial or noncommercial handbill in or upon any vehicle. It shall not be unlawful in any public place for a person to hand out or distribute without charge to the receiver thereof a handbill to any occupant of a vehicle who is willing to accept it. 
(c)  Depositing on vacant premises. No person shall throw or deposit any handbill in or upon any private premises which are temporarily or continuously uninhabited or vacant. 
(d)  Distributing at private premises. No person shall throw, deposit or distribute any handbill in or upon private premises which are inhabited, except by handing or transmitting any such handbill directly to the owner, occupant, or other person then present in or upon such private premises. In case of inhabited private premises, such person, unless requested by anyone upon such premises not to do so, may place or deposit any such handbill in or upon such inhabited private premises if such handbill is so placed or deposited as to secure or prevent such handbill from being blown or drifted about such premises or sidewalks, streets, or other public places, and except that mailboxes may not be so used when so prohibited by federal postal law or regulations. 
(Code 1977, § 12.8.7) 
Sec. 20-31. - On private property. 
(a)  Vacant lots. No person shall throw or deposit litter on any open or vacant private property within the village whether owned by such person or not. 
(b)  Occupied premises. No person shall throw or deposit litter on any occupied private premises within the village, whether owned by such person or not, except in authorized private receptacles for collection. 
(c)  Maintaining premises free of litter. The owner or person in control of any private premises or vacant property shall at all times maintain the private premises or vacant property free of litter. This subsection shall not prohibit the storage of litter in authorized private receptacles for collection nor prohibit the burial or composting of litter on a small scale when covered by soil in a gardening plot or rear yard in a manner so as to prevent offensive odors. 
(Code 1977, § 12.8.9) 
Sec. 20-32. - Clearing litter by village. 
(a)  The village may notify the owner of any open or vacant private property within the village or the agent of such owner to properly dispose of litter located on such owner's property which is dangerous to public health, safety or welfare. Such notice shall be by certified or registered mail, addressed to such owner, at his last known address. 
(b)  Upon the failure, neglect or refusal of any owner or agent so notified to properly dispose of litter dangerous to the public health, safety or welfare within five (5) days after receipt of written notice provided for in this section or within five (5) days after the date of such notice if the same is returned to the village by the post office because of its inability to make delivery thereof, provided the same was properly addressed to the last known address of such owner or agent, the village may pay for the disposing of such litter or order its disposal by the village. 
(c)  If the village is required to remove such dangerous litter, the owner of the premises shall be liable to the village for expense incurred by the village in removing and disposing of such litter. A statement shall be rendered to the owner of the premises for the cost thereof, and if not paid, suit shall be instituted. 
(Code 1977, § 12.8.10) 
Secs. 20-33-20-43. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - COLLECTION AND DISPOSAL 
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 20-44. - Findings. 
    It is hereby found and declared that the regulation of the collection of municipal waste, recyclables and landscape waste bears a reasonable relationship to the village's goal of protecting the health safety and welfare of the residents of the village and that the designation of a single residential waste collector will further this goal as it allows for more efficient handling of such items because obedience to the rules laid down for their handling is more easily compelled and enforced, and because, proper control can only be served by close and careful inspection, which becomes more and more difficult as the number of places and persons to be watched increase. 
(Ord. No. 06-O-28, § 2, 3-14-06) 
Sec. 20-45. - Designation of residential collection contractor. 
    The village board of trustees may designate by ordinance a private scavenger service to serve as the exclusive provider of residential collection services within the village. Said private scavenger service shall comply with all standards applicable to a commercial collection contractor seeking licensure pursuant to section 20-74 of this Code and shall enter into an exclusive residential collection service agreement with the village in a form to be approved by the village board of trustees. 
(Ord. No. 06-O-28, § 2, 3-14-06) 
Sec. 20-46. - Exclusivity; exemption. 
    The village may enter into an exclusive contract for the collection of solid waste and/or recyclable materials from non-residential premises within the village. Notwithstanding any exclusive contract that the village may enter into for the collection of solid waste and/or recyclable materials from non-residential premises within the village, a non-residential customer may petition the village board to be released from the services of any such exclusive hauling contractor, and the village board may grant such petition provided that the customer establishes to the reasonable satisfaction of the village board that either: 
(1)  The customer is a party to a national contract that cannot be terminated during the period of the exemption; or 
(2)  The customer has unique service requirements that the exclusive hauling contractor cannot provide. 
(Ord. No. 14-O-84, § 2(d), 12-9-14) 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 14-O-84, § 2(d), adopted Dec. 9, 2014, renumbered §§ 20-46-20-51 as 20-47-20-52. 
Sec. 20-47. - Collectors. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any resident to knowingly hire any private scavenger service to provide residential collection services in the village other than the residential collection contractor. All residential collection services shall be performed exclusively by the residential collection contractor designated by the village board of trustees. 
(b)  It shall be unlawful for any resident to knowingly hire any private scavenger service to provide commercial collection services in the village other than a contractor licensed by the village pursuant to this article. 
(Ord. No. 93-0-3, § 2(8.3.1), 1-12-93; Ord. No. 04-O-30, § 3, 4-28-04; Ord. No. 06-O-28, § 2, 3-14-06; Ord. No. 14-O-84, § 2(d), 12-9-14) 
Editor's note- See editor's note, § 20-46. 
Sec. 20-48. - Containers. 
    Except as provided for toters in section 20-48, for bulk items in section 20-49 and for residential trash for one- and two-family dwellings and townhomes as provided in section 308.6 of section 6-342 all municipal solid waste placed by residents for residential collection service shall be contained in metal or plastic cans equipped with handles and completely closing covers. No such container shall exceed thirty-four (34) gallons in capacity or fifty (50) pounds in weight. 
(Ord. No. 93-0-3, § 2(8.3.2), 1-12-93; Ord. No. 04-O-30, § 4, 4-28-04: Ord. No. 14-O-84, § 2(d), 12-9-14; Ord. No. 15-O-07, § 5, 1-27-15) 
Editor's note- See editor's note, § 20-46. 
Sec. 20-49. - Optional use of toter. 
    Solid waste may be placed for residential collection service in a toter provided by the residential collection contractor. 
(Ord. No. 93-0-3, § 2(8.3.3), 1-12-93; Ord. No. 06-O-28, § 2, 3-14-06; Ord. No. 14-O-84, § 2(d), 12-9-14) 
Editor's note- See editor's note, § 20-46. 
Sec. 20-50. - Bulk items. 
    Bulk items may be placed for residential collection service without containers; provided, however, that all unsecured or loose parts of any bulk item shall be securely affixed to the bulk item or removed from it so that no such part or other debris remains after the bulk item is collected. 
(Ord. No. 93-0-3, § 2(8.3.4), 1-12-93; Ord. No. 14-O-84, § 2(d), 12-9-14) 
Editor's note- See editor's note, § 20-46. 
Sec. 20-51. - Disposal from other dwellings and buildings. 
    The owners or persons in charge of commercial and industrial buildings and of multifamily residential premises of more than four (4) individual residential units, including without limitation condominiums and co-ops in buildings containing more than four (4) individual residential units, shall properly collect, remove and dispose of their own solid waste. 
(Ord. No. 93-0-3, § 2(8.3.6), 1-12-93; Ord. No. 14-O-84, § 2(d), 12-9-14) 
Editor's note- See editor's note, § 20-46. 
Sec. 20-52. - Location. 
    All solid waste containers and bulk items shall be placed for residential collection service at curbside or alley, as applicable, on the day scheduled for collection or not earlier than 6:00 p.m. on the immediately preceding day; provided, however, that any resident who, by reason of disability certified by a doctor, is unable to place his solid waste at curbside or alley, as applicable, may place such solid waste for residential collection service at the back door of each such resident's residential premises. 
(Ord. No. 93-0-3, § 2(8.3.5), 1-12-93; Ord. No. 14-O-84, § 2(d), 12-9-14) 
Editor's note- See editor's note, § 20-46. 
Secs. 20-53-20-70. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - LICENSES FOR COMMERCIAL COLLECTION CONTRACTORS[3] 

Footnotes: 
--- (3) --- 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 06-O-28, adopted March 14, 2006, amended Div. 2, Licenses for Collectors, to read as herein set out. 
Cross reference- Licenses, taxation and miscellaneous business regulations, Ch. 13. 

Sec. 20-71. - Required. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person or firm to engage in the business of commercial collection service in the village without first obtaining a license therefor from the village and paying the required fee. After February 1, 2015, no license shall be issued except to a hauling contractor with whom the village has entered into a contract for such waste hauling and/or recycling services. 
(Ord. No. 93-0-3, § 2(8.6.1), 1-12-93; Ord. No. 06-O-28, § 2, 3-14-06; Ord. No. 14-O-84, § 2(a), 12-9-14) 
Sec. 20-72. - Application. 
    A response to any request for proposal issued by the village shall also be deemed an application for licenses pursuant to this section. All such applications shall be maintained on file with the village clerk. 
(Ord. No. 93-0-3, § 2(8.6.2), 1-12-93; Ord. No. 14-O-84, § 2(b), 12-9-14) 
Sec. 20-73. - Fee. 
    The annual license fee for a license pursuant to this division shall be as established by the annual fee ordinance for each commercial collection contractor providing commercial collection services within the village. There shall be no prorating of fees if a license is issued during a license period, or in the event of a suspension or revocation of a license. 
(Ord. No. 93-0-3, § 2(8.6.2), 1-12-93; Ord. No. 06-O-28, § 2, 3-14-06) 
Sec. 20-74. - Standards. 
(a)  Indemnification. Every contractor seeking a license pursuant to this division shall indemnify, save and keep harmless the village from any and all loss, cost, damage, expense or liability whatsoever arising out of, resulting from, or relating to the services performed by such contractor, including without limitation acts and omissions of such contractor's employees, agents, officers, subcontractors and independent contractors arising out of, resulting from, or relating to the services performed, and every license issued by the village shall include such an indemnification agreement signed by the licensee. 
(b)  Insurance. Every licensed contractor shall furnish and maintain insurance for general liability, motor vehicle liability and other coverages in forms and amounts satisfactory to the village, and shall provide copies of policies and certificates of such insurance to the village. 
(1)  Motor vehicle liability insurance: The collector shall carry in its own name a policy under a comprehensive form to insure the entire motor vehicle liability for its operation with limits not less than three million dollars ($3,000,000.00) each person and five million dollars ($5,000,000.00) each accident bodily injury and death liability and one million dollars ($1,000,000.00) each accident for property damage liability. 
(2)  General liability: The collector shall carry in its own name a comprehensive liability policy for its operations other than motor vehicle with limits of at least three million dollars ($3,000,000.00) each person and five million dollars ($5,000,000.00) each accident bodily injury and death liability, one million dollars ($1,000,000.00) each accident for property damage liability. 
    Said insurance policies shall not be cancelable without thirty (30) days prior written notice to the village. The collector shall furnish the village with certificates evidencing that the insurance provided for herein is maintained by the collector within seven (7) days of the date of any request by the village. 
    The insurance coverage specified herein constitutes the minimum requirements and said requirements shall in no way lessen or limit the liability of the collector. The collector shall procure and maintain at its own cost and expense, any additional kinds and amounts of insurance which, in the collector's own judgement, may be necessary for its proper protection in the prosecution of the work. 
(c)  Evidence of performance capabilities. Every contractor seeking a license shall provide evidence satisfactory to the village that such contractor is capable of providing the services for which a license is sought in a good, workmanlike, competent and efficient manner in compliance with all applicable statutes, laws, codes and regulations and without any adverse impacts on the village or any of its residents, including without limitation complete financial statements and references as to financial responsibility. 
(d)  Operations, service options and rate structure. Every contractor shall submit to the village, prior to the issuance or renewal of any license, a detailed description of its operations, management and ownership, a detailed description of all services and options offered by the contractor for collection and disposal services in the village and a detailed description of all rates and charges for all such services and options. Each licensed contractor shall advise the village promptly in writing of all changes to such operations, management, ownership, services, options, rates and charges. A description of such services and options and of all charges for such services and options may be published annually by the village in its community newsletter. The collector shall offer to collect recyclables from commercial and industrial buildings and of multi-family residential premises of more than four (4) individual residential units including without limitation condominiums and co-ops. 
(e)  Penalties. Every contractor seeking a license shall be solely liable for any and all fines and civil penalties that are imposed by any governmental or quasi-governmental agency or body arising out of, resulting from or relating to the services performed by such contractor, including without limitation acts and omissions of such contractor's employees, agents, officers, subcontractors and independent contractors, and every license issued by the village shall include an agreement to this effect signed by the licensee. 
    Any hauling contractor licensed to provide non-residential waste hauling and/or recycling services shall comply with the licensing and service standards set forth in its contract with the village. For purposes of any hauling contractor that does not have a contract with the village, the performance standards set forth in the existing contract shall be deemed the license standards. Notwithstanding any license issued to a hauling contractor for the collection of solid waste and/or recyclable materials from non-residential premises within the village after February 1, 2015, such license shall be of no force or effect except to the extent that such hauling contractor has a valid contract with the village to provide such collection services. 
(Ord. No. 93-0-3, § 2(8.6.4), 1-12-93; Ord. No. 04-O-30, § 5, 4-28-04; Ord. No. 14-O-84, § 2(c), 12-9-14) 
Sec. 20-75. - Issuance. 
    Upon payment of the license fee specified in section 20-73, and upon receipt of all the documentation required by section 20-74, and if such documentation shows that the contractor seeking a license pursuant to this division meets all of the standards set forth in section 20-74, the village administrator shall issue the license. 
(Ord. No. 93-0-3, § 2(8.6.5), 1-12-93) 
Sec. 20-76. - Term; renewal. 
    Each collector's license issued pursuant to this division shall expire at the end of the day of April 30 next following the date of issuance. Any collector may renew a license at the expiration thereof, provided that the collector is then qualified to receive a license. The renewal privilege provided for in this section shall not be construed as a vested right. 
(Ord. No. 93-0-3, § 2(8.6.6), 1-12-93) 
Sec. 20-77. - Transfer restrictions. 
    A license issued under this division shall be purely a personal privilege, shall expire on April 30 next after issuance unless sooner revoked, and shall not constitute property, nor shall it be subject to attachment, garnishment or execution, nor shall it be alienable or transferable, voluntarily or involuntarily, or subject to being encumbered or hypothecated. For the purposes of this section, to "alienate" or "transfer" a license shall mean to give, sell or convey a license or fifty (50) percent or more of the total number of shares of stock or securities convertible into stock of a corporation or entity that holds a license. 
(Ord. No. 93-0-3, § 2(8.6.7), 1-12-93) 
Sec. 20-78. - Denial; revocation. 
(a)  Any license issued under this division may be temporarily suspended or revoked, or an application for issuance or renewal of a license required by this division may be refused by the village administrator if he determines: 
(1)  That the application of the contractor or collector contains any false, fraudulent or misleading material statement; or 
(2)  That the contractor or collector has made any false, fraudulent or misleading material statement, or has been convicted of perpetrating a fraud upon any person or that the contractor or collector has committed a felony; or 
(3)  That the contractor or collector has conducted any activities directly related to the solid waste, landscape waste or recyclables collection and disposal business in the village in an unlawful manner or in such manner as to constitute a breach of the peace or a menace to the health, safety or general welfare of the public; or 
(4)  That the contractor or collector has violated any of the provisions of this chapter or of any other code, ordinance, resolution, rule or regulation of the village. 
(b)  A contractor or collector aggrieved by the action of the village administrator in refusing to issue any license or in suspending or revoking any license already issued shall have the right to appeal such decision to the village board of trustees in accordance with, and as provided by, section 20-79. 
(Ord. No. 93-0-3, § 2(8.6.8), 1-12-93) 
Sec. 20-79. - Administrative appeal. 
    If any application for a license under this division is denied, or if any license already issued shall have been suspended or revoked, the contractor or the collector, as the case may be, shall be notified in writing of the reasons for such denial, suspension or revocation by the village administrator. Within ten (10) days thereafter, the contractor or the collector, as the case may be, may request a hearing before the village board or trustees to appeal the denial, suspension or revocation. The contractor or the collector, as the case may be, shall be given ten (10) days' advance notice of the hearing date. At the hearing, the contractor or the collector, as the case may be, may be present and submit evidence and witnesses to rebut the reasons cited for denial, suspension or revocation of the license. 
(Ord. No. 93-0-3, § 2(8.6.9), 1-12-93) 
Sec. 20-80. - Violations. 
    Any violation of any provision of this chapter shall be grounds for the immediate revocation of any license issued pursuant to this division and for the imposition of the penalties set forth in section 1-12. 
(Ord. No. 93-0-3, § 2(8.8), 1-12-93) 
Secs. 20-81-20-100. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 3. - STANDARDS 

Sec. 20-101. - Reporting. 
    Each licensed contractor must prepare and submit to the village reports detailing solid waste disposal, recycling and landscape waste collection activities for the previous month, including without limitation, recycling participation rate, the amount of solid waste, recyclables or landscape waste collected. Reports shall be submitted quarterly no later than thirty (30) days following the end of the quarter. 
(Ord. No. 93-0-3, § 2(8.7.15), 1-12-93; Ord. No. 04-O-30, § 6, 4-28-04) 
Sec. 20-102. - Vehicles and equipment. 
    Each collector shall use only vehicles and equipment that are modern, neat, clean and in a sanitary condition. All such vehicles and equipment shall be cleaned and disinfected when not in use. All disposal equipment shall be watertight, completely enclosed by metal, except for an opening sufficient to permit loading, and all containers shall be equipped with airtight covers. It shall be unlawful for any vehicle used by a collector for disposal services without necessity to park before any premises for any unreasonable length of time in loading or unloading or to remain in an open condition or parked along any public or private street within the village when not in use. 
(Ord. No. 93-0-3, § 2(8.7.3), 1-12-93) 
Sec. 20-103. - Cleanliness. 
    All services by all licensed contractors shall be performed in a clean and orderly fashion. No licensed contractor shall deposit, or permit to remain, any municipal solid waste, landscape waste or recyclables on any property except only as provided in this chapter. Every licensed contractor shall replace all containers in their proper locations. 
(Ord. No. 93-0-3, § 2(8.7.4), 1-12-93; Ord. No. 04-O-30, § 7, 4-28-04) 
Sec. 20-104. - Safety; risk of loss. 
    Each licensed contractor shall be solely and completely responsible for the safety of its personnel and equipment and of all persons and property affected by such contractor's services. All services shall be performed safely. All services shall be performed at the sole risk and cost of the licensed contractor. 
(Ord. No. 93-0-3, § 2(8.7.5), 1-12-93) 
Sec. 20-105. - Damage to property. 
    Each licensed contractor shall immediately repair all damage inflicted on any property by such contractor and shall restore such property to a condition equal to that existing before the damage was inflicted and satisfactory to the village. 
(Ord. No. 93-0-3, § 2(8.7.6), 1-12-93) 
Sec. 20-106. - Storage. 
    No licensed contractor shall store any materials or equipment anywhere in the village except in strict compliance with all codes, ordinances, resolutions, rules and regulations of the village. 
(Ord. No. 93-0-3, § 2(8.7.7), 1-12-93) 
Sec. 20-107. - Service options. 
    Each licensed solid waste or landscape waste contractor shall offer both optional flat monthly fee and volume-based collection options to its customers. 
(Ord. No. 93-0-3, § 2(8.7.10), 1-12-93) 
Sec. 20-108. - Collection times; frequency; periods. 
    No collection services shall commence before 7:00 a.m. on any day nor continue beyond 7:00 p.m. on any day unless specifically approved by the village administrator. Residential collection services shall be provided once per week only and shall be conducted only in the locations and on the days prescribed by the village. Landscape waste collection services shall be made available, at a minimum, during the week including April 1 through the week including November 30 each year. No solid waste, landscape waste or recyclables collection services shall be made on Saturdays or Sundays, except as provided in section 20-109. 
(Ord. No. 93-0-3, § 2(8.7.1), 1-12-93; Ord. No. 06-O-28, § 2, 3-14-06) 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 06-O-28, adopted March 14, 2006, repealed §§ 20-108, 20-109, 20-112 and 20-113, which pertained to toters, back door service, bulk items, and Christmas trees, respectively, and derived from Ord. No. 93-O-3, as amended. Ord. No. 06-O-28 further provided for the amendment and renumbering of the remaining sections of this division. 
Sec. 20-109. - Holidays. 
    No solid waste, landscape waste or recyclables collection services shall be made on the following holidays: New Year's Day, Memorial Day, Independence Day, Labor Day, Thanksgiving Day and Christmas Day. When any such holiday falls on a weekday, then collections for the week within which such holiday falls shall be delayed by one (1) day for the remainder of the week after the holiday. 
(Ord. No. 93-0-3, § 2(8.7.2), 1-12-93; Ord. No. 06-O-28, § 2, 3-14-06) 
Note- See editor's note, § 20-108 
Sec. 20-110. - Construction waste. 
    Nothing in this article shall prevent a hauling contractor from obtaining a temporary permit for the purpose of collecting and removing construction debris in connection with a building or demolition permit issued for a particular non-residential property. Any temporary permit issued hereunder shall be subject to insurance, indemnity, and performance standards comparable to those provided for in any contract referenced in this Section, and such standards may be incorporated as specific conditions of and applying to any such temporary permit. 
(Ord. No. 14-O-84, § 2(e), 12-9-14) 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 14-O-84, § 2(e), adopted Dec. 9, 2014, renumbered §§ 20-110, 20-111 as §§ 20-111, 20-112. 
Sec. 20-111. - Recyclables collection. 
    Each licensed commercial collection contractor shall provide recyclables collection service for customers upon request. 
(Ord. No. 93-0-3, § 2(8.7.12), 1-12-93; Ord. No. 04-O-30, § 12, 4-28-04; Ord. No. 06-O-28, § 2, 3-14-06; Ord. No. 14-O-84, § 2(e), 12-9-14) 
Editor's note- See editor's note, § 20-110. 
Sec. 20-112. - Processing of recyclables. 
    All recyclables shall be delivered to an appropriate facility for recycling. No recyclables shall be delivered to any landfill or other facility for disposal. 
(Ord. No. 93-0-3, § 2(8.7.13), 1-12-93; Ord. No. 04-O-30, § 13, 4-28-04; Ord. No. 06-O-28, § 2, 3-14-06; Ord. No. 14-O-84, § 2(e), 12-9-14) 
Editor's note- See editor's note, § 20-110 
Secs. 20-113-20-135. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE IV. - RECYCLABLES 

Sec. 20-136. - Participation encouraged. 
    All residential collection service customers and commercial collection services customers are encouraged to participate in recycling programs offered and conducted by licensed contractors. 
(Ord. No. 93-0-3, § 2(8.5.1), 1-12-93; Ord. No. 06-O-28, § 2, 3-14-06) 
Sec. 20-137. - Containers. 
    Except as provided for newspapers in section 20-138, all recyclables placed by residents for residential collection service shall be contained in a suitable container approved by the licensed contractor. No such container shall exceed eighteen (18) gallons in capacity. All such containers shall be made of post-consumer recyclable plastics. Recyclables shall be placed within such a recycling container in a manner that will inhibit their being blown out of the container by the wind and elements. If the village provides the recycling container, the village shall maintain ownership thereof; provided, however, that each such resident shall be responsible for the reasonable care of a recycling container placed in its possession. Residents are not required to equip recycling containers with covers. If the village provides the recycling container, residents relocating away from an area subject to the program are obligated to return the container to the village. Abuse, theft or misuse of the recycling containers provided by the village is prohibited and such conduct shall constitute a violation of the provisions of this section. Recyclables may be placed for residential collection service in a toter provided by the residential collection contractor. 
(Ord. No. 93-0-3, § 2(8.5.2), 1-12-93; Ord. No. 04-O-30, § 14, 4-28-04; Ord. No. 06-O-28, § 2, 3-14-06) 
Sec. 20-138. - Reserved. 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 04-O-30, § 15, adopted April 28, 2004, deleted § 20-139, which pertained to newspapers and derived from Ord. No. 93-0-3, § 2(8.5.4), adopted Jan. 12, 1993. 
Sec. 20-139. - Location. 
    All recycling containers shall be placed for residential collection service at curbside or alley, as applicable, on the day scheduled for collection, or not earlier than 6:00 p.m. on the immediately preceding day; provided however that any resident who, by reason of disability certified by a doctor, is unable to place his recyclables at curbside or alley, as applicable, may place such recyclables for residential collection service at the back door of each such resident's residential premises. 
(Ord. No. 93-0-3, § 2(8.5.4), 1-12-93; Ord. No. 04-O-30, § 16, 4-28-04) 
Sec. 20-140. - Recycling from other dwellings and buildings. 
    The owners or persons in charge of multifamily residential premises of more than four (4) individual residential units, including without limitation condominiums and co-ops in buildings containing more than four (4) individual residential units, are encouraged to participate in recycling programs conducted by licensed commercial collection contractors or in any other available recycling program. 
(Ord. No. 93-0-3, § 2(8.5.5), 1-12-93; Ord. No. 06-O-28, § 2, 3-14-06) 
Secs. 20-141-20-160. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE V. - LANDSCAPE WASTE 

Sec. 20-161. - Separation required. 
    Landscape waste shall not be mixed or combined with garbage, rubbish or refuse of any other kind but shall be either properly composted or properly disposed of in accordance with the provisions of this article. 
(Ord. No. 93-0-3, § 2(8.4.1), 1-12-93) 
Sec. 20-162. - Collectors. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any resident to knowingly hire any private scavenger service to provide residential collection service of landscape waste in the village other than the residential collection contractor and, unless composting will be utilized, all residential collection service of landscape waste shall be performed exclusively by the residential collection contractor designated by the village board of trustees. This section shall not prohibit any landscaping service provider from removing landscape waste from any premises within the village for disposal in accordance with applicable statutes, laws, codes and regulations. 
(b)  It shall be unlawful for any resident to knowingly hire any private scavenger service to provide commercial collection service of landscape waste in the village other than a licensed commercial collection contractor and, unless composting will be utilized, all commercial collection service of landscape waste shall be performed exclusively by a licensed commercial collection contractor. This section shall not prohibit any landscaping service provider from removing landscape waste from any premises within the village for disposal in accordance with applicable statutes, laws, codes and regulations. 
(Ord. No. 93-0-3, § 2(8.4.2), 1-12-93; Ord. No. 06-O-28, § 2, 3-14-06) 
Sec. 20-163. - Containers. 
    Except as provided for toters in section 20-164, and unless properly composted, all landscape waste placed by residents and residential collection service shall be contained in metal or plastic cans, equipped with handles and tightly sealing covers, not exceeding thirty-four (34) gallons in capacity or fifty (50) pounds in weight, or tightly closed biodegradable paper bags not exceeding thirty-three (33) gallons in capacity, or shall be tightly tied with biodegradable string or twine, in bundles not exceeding four (4) feet in length or fifty (50) pounds in weight; provided, however, that this section shall not prohibit any landscaping service provider from removing landscape waste from any premises within the village for composting or disposal in accordance with applicable statutes, laws, codes and regulations. 
(Ord. No. 93-0-3, § 2(8.4.3), 1-12-93; Ord. No. 04-O-30, § 17, 4-28-04) 
Sec. 20-164. - Optional use of toter. 
    Landscape waste may be placed for residential collection service in a toter provided by a licensed contractor. 
(Ord. No. 93-0-3, § 2(8.4.4), 1-12-93) 
Sec. 20-165. - Location. 
    All landscape waste containers and bundles shall be placed for residential collection service at curbside or alley, as applicable, on the day scheduled for collection or not earlier than 6:00 p.m. on the immediately preceding day; provided, however, that any resident who, by reason of disability certified by a doctor, is unable to place his landscape waste at curbside or alley, as applicable, may place such landscape waste for residential collection service at the back door of each such resident's residential premises. 
(Ord. No. 93-0-3, § 2(8.4.5), 1-12-93) 
Sec. 20-166. - Composting. 
    All residents are encouraged to leave clippings on the ground where they can decompose and return nutrients to the soil. Landscape wastes can be composted in ways that protect the health, safety, and welfare of the residents of the village. The following standards shall apply to composting: 
(1)  Compost piles shall not be located in front yards and shall be set back from every property line a minimum of five (5) feet or the setback required for accessory buildings in the applicable zoning district, whichever is greater. 
(2)  Compost piles shall contain only landscape waste and food waste generated by the occupant of a single family home. 
(3)  Compost piles shall contain landscape waste only from the property on which the compost pile is located. This standard shall not apply to any compost pile operated by the village. 
(4)  Compost piles shall be maintained to prevent offensive odors. 
(5)  Compost piles shall be located so as to minimize conflicts with neighboring residences, patios and swimming pools. 
(6)  The presence of insects in and around a compost pile is part of the natural decomposition process and is not in itself an indication of improper care. 
(7)  All compost piles shall be contained within a wire, wood or masonry or similar structure the maximum dimension of which shall not exceed five (5) feet. Or similar structure designed and manufactured for use as a composting device. 
(8)  Failure to properly maintain and care for a compost pile is an offense. 
(Ord. No. 93-0-3, § 2(8.4.6), 1-12-93; Ord. No. 04-O-30, § 18, 4-28-04) 
Sec. 20-167. - Disposal from other dwellings and buildings. 
    The owners or persons in charge of commercial and industrial buildings and of multifamily residential premises of more than four (4) individual residential units, including without limitation condominiums and co-ops in buildings containing more than four (4) individual residential units, shall properly compost, in accordance with section 20-166, or properly collect and remove their own landscape waste. 
(Ord. No. 93-0-3, § 2(8.4.7), 1-12-93) 
Chapter 20.5 - STORMWATER MANAGEMENT[1]

    The Lake County Watershed Development Ordinance, as most recently amended by the County of Lake on June 11, 2013, is hereby adopted by reference and is in full force and effect within the Village of Libertyville and is found in its own compilation. 
(Ord. No. 14-O-20, § 2, 3-25-14)
