Sec. 20.5-26 - Adoption of stormwater management program plan. 
    The stormwater management program plan, as approved by Village Ordinance 14-O-19, is hereby adopted by reference as the stormwater management program plan for the Village of Libertyville and is in full force and effect within the village and is found in its own compilation. 
(Ord No. 14-O-20, § 3, 3-25-14) 
Secs. 20.5-27-20.5-50. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - ILLICIT DISCHARGE ORDINANCE 

Sec. 20.5-51. - Purpose; objective. 
    The purposes of this article are to provide for the health, safety, and general welfare of the citizens of the Village of Libertyville through the regulation of non-stormwater discharges to the storm drainage system to the maximum extent practicable as required by federal and state law. This article establishes methods for controlling the introduction of pollutants into the municipal separate storm sewer system (MS4) in order to comply with requirements of the National Pollutant Discharge Elimination System (NPDES) permit process. The objectives of this article are: 
(1)  To regulate the contribution of pollutants to the municipal separate storm sewer system (MS4) by stormwater discharges by any user; 
(2)  To prohibit illicit connections and discharges to the municipal separate storm sewer system; and 
(3)  To establish legal authority to carry out all inspection, surveillance and monitoring procedures necessary to ensure compliance with this article. 
(Ord No. 14-O-20, § 3, 3-25-14) 
Sec. 20.5-52. - Definitions. 
    For the purposes of this article, the following shall mean: 
    Authorized enforcement agency means enforcement officer or designees of the village engineer of the Village of Libertyville designated to enforce this article. 
    Best management practices (BMPs) means schedules of activities, prohibitions of practices, general good housekeeping practices, pollution prevention and educational practices, maintenance procedures, and other management practices to prevent or reduce the discharge of pollutants directly or indirectly to stormwater, receiving waters, or stormwater conveyance systems. BMPs also include treatment practices, operating procedures, and practices to control site runoff, spillage or leaks, sludge or water disposal, or drainage from raw materials storage. 
    Clean Water Act means the Federal Water Pollution Control Act (33 U.S.C. 1251 et seq.), and any subsequent amendments thereto. 
    Construction activity means activities subject to NPDES construction permits. These include construction projects resulting in land disturbance of one (1) acre or more. Such activities include, but are not limited to, clearing and grubbing, grading, excavating, and demolition. 
    Hazardous materials means any material, including any substance, waste, or combination thereof, that because of its quantity, concentration, or physical, chemical, or infectious characteristics may cause, or significantly contribute to, a substantial present or potential hazard to human health, safety, property, or the environment when improperly treated, stored, transported, disposed of, or otherwise managed. 
    Illegal discharge means any direct or indirect non-stormwater discharge to the storm drainage system, except as exempted in section 20.5-57 of this Code. 
    Illicit connections means either of the following: Any drain or conveyance, whether on the surface or subsurface, which allows an illegal discharge to enter the storm drainage system including, without limitation, any conveyances that allow any non-stormwater discharge including sewage, process wastewater, and wash water to enter the storm drainage system; and any connections to the storm drainage system from indoor drains and sinks, regardless of whether said drain or connection had been previously allowed, permitted, or approved by an authorized enforcement agency; or any drain or conveyance connected from a commercial or industrial land use to the storm drainage system that has not been documented in plans, maps, or equivalent records and approved by an authorized enforcement agency. 
    Industrial activity means activities subject to NPDES industrial permits as defined in 40 CFR, Section 122.26 (b)(14). 
    National Pollutant Discharge Elimination System (NPDES) stormwater discharge permit means a permit issued by EPA (or by a state under authority delegated pursuant to 33 USC 1342(b) that authorizes the discharge of pollutants to waters of the United States, whether the permit is applicable on an individual, group, or general area-wide basis. 
    Non-stormwater discharge means any discharge to the storm drainage system that is not composed entirely of stormwater. 
    Person means any individual, association, organization, partnership, firm, corporation or other entity recognized by law and acting as either the owner or as the owner's agent. 
    Pollutant means anything that causes or contributes to pollution. Pollutants may include, without limitation: paints, varnishes, and solvents; oil and other automotive fluids; nonhazardous liquid and solid wastes and yard wastes; refuse, rubbish, garbage, litter, or other discarded or abandoned objects, ordinances, and accumulations, so that same may cause or contribute to pollution; floatables; pesticides, herbicides, and fertilizers; hazardous substances and wastes; sewage, fecal coliform and pathogens; dissolved and particulate metals; animal wastes; wastes and residues that result from constructing a building or structure; and noxious or offensive matter of any kind. 
    Premises means any building, lot, parcel of land, or portion of land whether improved or unimproved including adjacent sidewalks and parking strips. 
    Storm drainage system means publicly-owned facilities by which stormwater is collected and/or conveyed, including, without limitation, any roads with drainage systems, municipal streets, gutters, curbs, inlets, piped storm drains, pumping facilities, retention and detention basins, natural and human-made or altered drainage channels, reservoirs, and other drainage structures. 
    Stormwater means any surface flow, runoff, and drainage consisting entirely of water from any form of natural precipitation, and resulting from such precipitation. 
    Stormwater pollution prevention plan means a document that describes the best management practices and activities to be implemented by a person or business to identify sources of pollution or contamination at a site and the actions to eliminate or reduce pollutant discharges to stormwater, stormwater conveyance systems, and/or receiving waters to the maximum extent practicable. 
    Wastewater means any water or other liquid, other than uncontaminated stormwater, discharged from a facility. 
(Ord No. 14-O-20, § 3, 3-25-14) 
Sec. 20.5-53. - Applicability. 
    This article shall apply to all water entering the storm drainage system generated on any developed and undeveloped lands unless explicitly exempted by an authorized enforcement agency. 
(Ord No. 14-O-20, § 3, 3-25-14) 
Sec. 20.5-54. - Administration. 
    Any powers granted or duties imposed upon the authorized enforcement agency may be delegated in writing by the director of the authorized enforcement agency to persons or entities acting in the beneficial interest of or in the employ of the Village of Libertyville. 
(Ord No. 14-O-20, § 3, 3-25-14) 
Sec. 20.5-55. - Severability. 
    If any provision of this article, or the application of any provision of this article, is held unconstitutional or otherwise invalid, such occurrence shall not affect, impair, or invalidate other provisions of this article, or their application, that can be given effect without the unconstitutional or invalid provision or its application. Each unconstitutional or invalid provision, or application of such provision, is severable, unless otherwise provided by this article. 
(Ord No. 14-O-20, § 3, 3-25-14) 
Sec. 20.5-56. - Minimum standards. 
    The standards set forth herein and promulgated pursuant to this article are minimum standards; therefore, this article does not intend nor imply that compliance by any person will ensure that there will be no contamination, pollution, nor unauthorized discharge of pollutants. 
(Ord No. 14-O-20, § 3, 3-25-14) 
Sec. 20.5-57. - Prohibitions on discharges. 
(a)  Prohibition of illegal discharges. No person shall discharge or cause to be discharged into the municipal storm drainage system or watercourses any materials, including, but not limited to, pollutants or waters containing any pollutants, that cause or contribute to a violation of applicable water quality standards, other than stormwater. The commencement, conduct, or continuance of any illegal discharge to the storm drainage system is prohibited except as follows: 
(1)  Water line flushing or other potable water sources, landscape irrigation or lawn watering, diverted stream flows, rising groundwater, groundwater infiltration to storm drains, uncontaminated pumped groundwater, foundation or footing drains (not including active groundwater dewatering systems), crawl space pumps, air conditioning condensation, springs, noncommercial washing of vehicles, natural riparian habitat or wetland flows, swimming pools (if dechlorinated - typically less than one (1) PPM chlorine), firefighting activities, and any other water source not containing pollutants. 
(2)  Discharges specified in writing by the authorized enforcement agency as being necessary to protect public health and safety. 
(3)  Dye testing, but only with prior oral notification to the authorized enforcement agency prior to the time of the test. 
(4)  Non-stormwater discharge permitted under an NPDES permit, waiver, or waste discharge order issued to the discharger and administered under the authority of the United States Environmental Protection Agency, provided that the discharger is in full compliance with all requirements of the permit, waiver, or order and other applicable laws and regulations, and provided that written approval has been granted for any discharge to the storm drainage system. 
(b)  Prohibition of illicit connections. 
(1)  The construction, use, maintenance, or continued existence of illicit connections to the storm drainage system is prohibited. 
(2)  This prohibition expressly includes, without limitation, illicit connections made in the past, regardless of whether the connection was permissible under law or practices applicable or prevailing at the time of connection. 
(3)  A person is considered to be in violation of this article if the person connects a line conveying sewage to the MS4, or allows such a connection to continue. 
(Ord No. 14-O-20, § 3, 3-25-14) 
Sec. 20.5-58. - Suspension of MS4 access. 
(a)  Suspension due to illicit discharges in emergency situations. The authorized enforcement agency may suspend, without prior notice, MS4 discharge access to a person when such suspension is necessary to stop an actual or threatened discharge that presents or may present imminent and substantial danger to the environment, or to the health or welfare of persons, or to the MS4 or waters of the United States. If the violator fails to comply with a suspension order issued in an emergency, the authorized enforcement agency may take such steps as deemed necessary to prevent or minimize damage to the MS4 or waters of the United States, or to minimize danger to the public. 
(b)  Suspension due to the detection of illicit discharge. Any person discharging to the MS4 in violation of this article may have MS4 access terminated if such termination would abate or reduce an illicit discharge. The authorized enforcement agency will notify a violator of the proposed termination of its MS4 access. The violator may petition the authorized enforcement agency for a reconsideration and hearing. A person commits an offense if the person reinstates MS4 access to premises terminated pursuant to this section without the prior approval of the authorized enforcement agency. 
(Ord No. 14-O-20, § 3, 3-25-14) 
Sec. 20.5-59. - Industrial or construction discharges. 
    Any person subject to an industrial or construction activity NPDES stormwater discharge permit shall comply with all provisions of such permit. Proof of compliance with said permit may be required in a form acceptable to the authorized enforcement agency prior to the allowing of discharges to the MS4. 
(Ord No. 14-O-20, § 3, 3-25-14) 
Sec. 20.5-60. - Monitoring of discharges. 
(a)  Applicability. This section applies to all facilities that have stormwater discharges associated with industrial activity, including construction activity. 
(b)  Access to facilities. 
(1)  The authorized enforcement agency shall be permitted to enter and inspect facilities subject to regulation under this article as often as maybe necessary to determine compliance with this article. If a discharger has security measures in force that require proper identification and clearance before entry into its premises, then the discharger shall make the necessary arrangements to allow access to representatives of the authorized enforcement agency. 
(2)  Facility operators shall allow the authorized enforcement agency ready access to all parts of the premises for the purposes of inspection, sampling, examination, and copying of records that must be kept under the conditions of an NPDES permit to discharge stormwater, and the performance of any additional duties as defined by state and federal law. 
(3)  The authorized enforcement agency shall have the right to set up on any permitted facility such devices as are necessary in the opinion of the authorized enforcement agency to conduct monitoring and/or sampling of the facility's stormwater discharge. 
(4)  The authorized enforcement agency has the right to require the discharger to install monitoring equipment as necessary. The facility's sampling and monitoring equipment shall be maintained at all times in a safe and proper operating condition by the discharger at its own expense. All devices used to measure stormwater flow and quality shall be calibrated to ensure their accuracy. 
(5)  Any temporary or permanent obstruction to safe and easy access to the facility to be inspected and/or sampled shall be promptly removed by the operator at the written or oral request of the authorized enforcement agency and shall not be replaced. The costs of clearing such access shall be borne by the operator. 
(6)  Unreasonable delays in allowing the authorized enforcement agency access to a permitted facility is a violation of a stormwater discharge permit and of this article. A person who is the operator of a facility with a NPDES permit to discharge stormwater associated with industrial activity commits an offense if the person denies the authorized enforcement agency reasonable access to the permitted facility for the purpose of conducting any activity authorized or required by this article. 
(7)  If the authorized enforcement agency has been refused access to any part of the premises from which stormwater is discharged, and he/she is able to demonstrate probable cause to believe that there may be a violation of this article, or that there is a need to inspect and/or sample as part of a routine inspection and sampling program designed to verify compliance with this article or any order issued hereunder, or to protect the overall public health, safety, and welfare of the community, then the authorized enforcement agency may seek issuance of a search warrant from any court of competent jurisdiction. 
(Ord No. 14-O-20, § 3, 3-25-14) 
Sec. 20.5-61. - Best management practices required. 
    The authorized enforcement agency will adopt requirements identifying best management practices for any activity, operation, or facility that may cause or contribute to pollution or contamination of stormwater, the storm drainage system, or waters of the United States. The owner or operator of a commercial or industrial establishment shall provide, at its own expense, reasonable protection from accidental discharge of prohibited materials or other wastes into the municipal storm drainage system or watercourses through the use of these structural and non-structural BMPs. Further, any person responsible for a property or premise, which is, or may be, the source of an illicit discharge, may be required to implement, at said person's expense, additional structural and non-structural BMPs to prevent the further discharge of pollutants to the municipal separate storm sewer system. Compliance with all terms and conditions of a valid NPDES permit authorizing the discharge of stormwater associated with industrial activity, to the extent practicable, shall be deemed compliance with the provisions of this section. These BMPs shall be part of a stormwater pollution prevention plan (SWPP) as necessary for compliance with requirements of the NPDES permit. 
(Ord No. 14-O-20, § 3, 3-25-14) 
Sec. 20.5-62. - Watercourse protection. 
    Every person owning property through which a watercourse passes, or such person's lessee, shall keep and maintain that part of the watercourse within the property free of trash, debris, excessive vegetation, and other obstacles that would pollute, contaminate, or significantly retard the flow of water through the watercourse. In addition, the owner or lessee shall maintain existing privately-owned structures within or adjacent to a watercourse, so that such structures will not become a hazard to the use, function, or physical integrity of the watercourse. 
(Ord No. 14-O-20, § 3, 3-25-14) 
Sec. 20.5-63. - Notification of spills. 
    Notwithstanding other requirements of law, as soon as any person responsible for a facility or operation, or responsible for emergency response for a facility or operation has information of any known or suspected release of materials that are resulting or may result in illegal discharges or pollutants discharging into stormwater, the storm drainage system, or water of the United States said person shall take all necessary steps to ensure the discovery, containment, and cleanup of such release. In the event of such a release of hazardous materials said person shall immediately notify emergency response agencies of the occurrence via emergency dispatch services. In the event of a release of non-hazardous materials, said person shall notify the authorized enforcement agency in person or by phone or facsimile no later than the next business day. Notifications in person or by phone shall be confirmed by written notice addressed and mailed to the authorized enforcement agency within three (3) business days of the phone notice. If the discharge of prohibited materials emanates from a commercial or industrial establishment, the owner or operator of such establishment shall also retain an on-site written record of the discharge and the actions taken to prevent its recurrence. Such records shall be retained for at least three (3) years. 
(Ord No. 14-O-20, § 3, 3-25-14) 
Sec. 20.5-64. - Enforcement. 
    Whenever the authorized enforcement agency finds that a person has violated a prohibition or failed to meet a requirement of this article, the authorized enforcement agency may order compliance by written notice of violation to the responsible person. Such notice may require without limitation: 
(1)  The performance of monitoring, analyses, and reporting; 
(2)  The elimination of illicit connections or discharges; 
(3)  That violating discharges, practices, or operations shall cease and desist; 
(4)  The abatement or remediation of stormwater pollution or contamination hazards and the restoration of any affected property; 
(5)  Payment of a fine to cover administrative and remediation costs; and 
(6)  The implementation of source control or treatment BMPs. 
    If abatement of a violation and/or restoration of affected property is required, the notice shall set forth a deadline within which such remediation or restoration must be completed. Said notice shall further advise that, should the violator fail to remediate or restore within the established deadline, the work will be done by a designated governmental agency or a contractor and the expense thereof shall be charged to the violator. 
(Ord No. 14-O-20, § 3, 3-25-14) 
Sec. 20.5-65. - Appeal of notice violation. 
    Any person receiving a notice of violation may appeal the determination of the authorized enforcement agency. The notice of appeal must be received within fifteen (15) days from the date of the notice of violation. Hearing on the appeal before the appropriate authority or his/her designee shall take place within fifteen (15) days from the date of receipt of the notice of appeal. The decision of the municipal authority or their designee shall be final. 
(Ord No. 14-O-20, § 3, 3-25-14) 
Sec. 20.5-66. - Enforcement measures after appeal. 
    If the violation has not been corrected pursuant to the requirements set forth in the notice of violation, or, in the event of an appeal, within days of the decision of the municipal authority upholding the decision of the authorized enforcement agency, then representatives of the authorized enforcement agency shall enter upon the subject private property and are authorized to take any and all measures necessary to abate the violation and/or restore the property. It shall be unlawful for any person, owner, agent, or person in possession of any premises to refuse to allow the government agency or designated contractor to enter upon the premises for the purposes set forth above. 
(Ord No. 14-O-20, § 3, 3-25-14) 
Sec. 20.5-67. - Cost of abatement. 
    Within fifteen (15) days after abatement of the violation, the owner of the property will be notified of the cost of abatement, including administrative costs. The property owner may file a written protest objecting to the amount of the assessment. If the amount due is not paid within a timely manner as determined by the decision of the municipal authority or by the expiration of the time in which to file an appeal, the charges shall become a special assessment against the property and shall constitute a lien on the property for the amount of the assessment. 
    Any person violating any of the provisions of this article shall become liable to the village by reason of such violation. The liability shall be paid in not more than twelve (12) equal payments. Interest at the rate of one (1) percent per annum shall be assessed on the balance beginning on the first day following the discovery of the violation. 
(Ord No. 14-O-20, § 3, 3-25-14) 
Sec. 20.5-68. - Injunctive relief. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to violate any provision or fail to comply with any of the requirements of this article. If a person has violated or continues to violate the provisions of this article, the authorized enforcement agency may petition a court of competent jurisdiction for a preliminary or permanent injunction restraining the person from activities that would create further violations or compelling the person to perform abatement or remediation of the violation. 
(Ord No. 14-O-20, § 3, 3-25-14) 
Sec. 20.5-69. - Compensatory action. 
    In lieu of enforcement proceedings, penalties, and remedies authorized by this article, the authorized enforcement agency may impose upon a violator alternative compensatory actions, such as storm drain stenciling, attendance at compliance workshops, creek cleanup, etc. 
(Ord No. 14-O-20, § 3, 3-25-14) 
Sec. 20.5-70. - Violations deemed public nuisance. 
    In addition to the enforcement processes and penalties provided, any condition caused or permitted to exist in violation of any of the provisions of this article is a threat to public health, safety, and welfare, and is declared and deemed a nuisance, and may be summarily abated or restored at the violator's expense, and/or a civil action to abate, enjoin, or otherwise compel the cessation of such nuisance may be taken. 
(Ord No. 14-O-20, § 3, 3-25-14) 
Sec. 20.5-71. - Remedies not exclusive. 
    The remedies listed in this article are not exclusive of any other remedies available under any applicable federal, state, or local law and it is within the discretion of the authorized enforcement agency to seek cumulative remedies. 
(Ord No. 14-O-20, § 3, 3-25-14) 
Secs. 20.5-72-20.5-100. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE IV. - FERTILIZER CONTAINING PHOSPHORUS 

Sec. 20.5-101. - Definitions. 
    For purposes of this article, the followings words and phrases shall have the meaning ascribed to them: 
    Commercial applicator means a person who is engaged in the business of applying fertilizer for hire. 
    Fertilizer means a substance containing nitrogen, phosphorus, potash or any other recognized plant nutrient element or compound which is used primarily for its plant nutrient content. Fertilizer shall not include the following natural products: agricultural limestone, sea solids, and unprocessed manure, which have not been manipulated so as to alter or change them chemically, burnt or hydrated lime, and sewage sludge produced by any sanitary treatment facility and shall not be subject to the provisions of this article. 
    Non-commercial applicator means a person who applies fertilizer but who is not a commercial applicator. 
(Ord. No. 15-O-15, § 1(1-4), 2-10-15) 
Sec. 20.5-102. - Prohibition. 
    No Commercial or non-commercial applicator, including homeowners and renters, shall apply to any area within the village any fertilizer, whether liquid, granular, or solid, which contains any amount of phosphorus or other compound containing phosphorus, such as phosphate, except: 
(1)  The naturally occurring phosphorus in unadulterated natural or organic fertilizing products such as yard waste or compost; or 
(2)  As otherwise provided in section 20.5-104 of this article. 
(Ord. No. 15-O-15, § 1(5), 2-10-15) 
Sec. 20.5-103. - Impervious surfaces, drainageways, and buffer zones. 
    No commercial or non-commercial applicator shall apply any fertilizer to: 
(1)  Impervious surfaces; 
(2)  Areas within drainage ditches; 
(3)  Waterways or within twenty (20) feet thereof; and 
(4)  Any delineated wetland and any area established as a natural buffer zone therefore. 
(Ord. No. 15-O-15, § 1(6), 2-10-15) 
Sec. 20.5-104. - Exemptions. 
    The following are exemptions to the prohibitions described in this article: 
(1)  The prohibition against the use of fertilizer containing phosphorus shall not apply to turf and lawn areas for which soil tests confirm the ambient phosphorus content is below median phosphorus levels for typical area soils. The scope of this exemption shall only be for such volume or concentration of phosphorus necessary to permit such turf or lawn area to contain phosphorus levels equal to the median phosphorus levels for typical area soils. Phosphorus applied as fertilizer pursuant to this exemption shall be integrated into the soil where it is immobilized and generally protected from loss by stormwater runoff. 
(2)  The prohibition against the use of fertilizer containing phosphorus shall not apply to flower beds and vegetable gardens and establishing newly seeded, sodded, sprigged or plugged turf/lawn areas. 
(3)  The prohibition contained in section 20.5-102 shall not apply to any farming or agricultural business, provided the use of fertilizers is related to the growth of a product or maintenance of growing fields. Appropriate steps shall be taken to integrate the fertilizer into the soil where it is immobilized and generally protected from loss by stormwater runoff. This exemption shall not apply to the standard lawn area of said farm or agricultural business. 
(Ord. No. 15-O-15, § 1(7), 2-10-15) 
Sec. 20.5-105. - Signs. 
    Any person, firm, corporation or partnership which sells any fertilizer at retail shall be required to post a sign or signs at the point of sale for fertilizer containing the following legend: 
"THE VILLAGE OF LIBERTYVILLE PROHIBITS THE APPLICATION OF FERTILIZER CONTAINING PHOSPHORUS TO ANY LAWN OR TURF AREA EXCEPT FOR THE USE IN THE ESTABLISHMENT OF NEWLY SEEDED, SODDED, SPRIGGED OR PLUGGED LAWN OR TURF AREAS AND ANY IMPERVIOUS SURFACE, DRAINAGEWAY, WETLAND, OR BUFFER ZONE". 
    Such sign or signs shall be clearly readable and shall be conspicuously posted on each aisle containing fertilizer. 
(Ord. No. 15-O-15, § 1(8), 2-10-15) 
Sec. 20.5-106. - Penalty. 
    In addition to any other sanctions and remedies provided by statute, any person who shall be convicted of violating any provisions of this Code of Ordinances shall be fined not less than $100.00 nor more than $1,000.00 for each offense; and a separate offense shall be deemed committed on each day during which a violation occurs or continues. 
(Ord. No. 15-O-15, § 1(9), 2-10-15) 
ARTICLE V. - GRADING OF LAND 

Sec. 20.5-107. - Interference of drainage. 
    It shall be unlawful to undertake or cause any alteration of any existing land grade, contour or drainage pattern in the village which, in the village engineer's professional opinion, will cause surface water to be unreasonably diverted onto or detained on abutting or nearby property or unreasonably alter natural or existing drainage patterns or unreasonably increase or concentrate runoff of stormwater onto abutting or nearby property. 
(Ord. No. 17-O-96, § 2(Exh. C), 11-28-17) 
Sec. 20.5-108. - Downspouts. 
    All roof downspouts shall discharge on grade in the front, rear, or corner side yard direction as defined by the Libertyville Zoning Code with a maximum extension of five (5) feet from the structure and no closer than five (5) feet from any property line. Any modifications to requirements shall be approved by the village engineer. 
(Ord. No. 17-O-96, § 2(Exh. C), 11-28-17) 
Chapter 21 - STREETS AND SIDEWALKS[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference- Department of public works, § 2-116; local improvements, § 2-151 et seq.; traffic, Ch. 23. 
State Law reference- General powers over streets and public ways, 65 ILCS 5/11-80-1 et seq. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 21-1. - Signs on streets. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to print, paint, fasten or suspend any sign or any other advertising device, or cause the same to be done, on any curbstone, flagstone, or any part of any sidewalk or street, or upon any tree, electric light standard, telegraph, telephone or electric power pole, hydrant, bridge, pier, or upon any other structure on any street within the village unless he is the owner thereof, or unless written permission from the owner is first obtained, and there is compliance with this chapter. 
(Code 1977, § 21.7.8) 
Sec. 21-2. - House numbering. 
(a)  All houses and other buildings in the village shall be numbered as hereinafter provided, and the decimal system of numbering is hereby adopted as the system for numbering such residences and buildings in the village. 
(b)  Park Avenue shall be the initial or starting point for numbering all north and south streets, and Milwaukee Avenue shall be the initial or starting point for numbering all east and west streets, and the word "street" shall include avenue, place and court. 
(c)  One hundred (100) numbers shall be assigned on each street to each block or square not exceeding four hundred (400) feet. To all blocks and squares exceeding four hundred (400) feet in length, an additional one hundred (100) numbers shall be assigned to each four hundred (400) feet provided the range of the numbers of blocks is maintained as nearly as the same as possible, so that the numbers of a block will show its range east or west of Milwaukee Avenue or north and south of Park Avenue. Twenty-two (22) feet shall be the standard length of a single number. The intervening narrow streets and alleys shall not be taken or considered as the boundaries of blocks and squares. The first squares on each street running east and west and diagonally from Milwaukee Avenue shall commence each with the number "100," and the first square on each street running north or south and diagonally from Park Avenue shall each commence with number "100" and each succeeding square shall commence with an even hundred as aforesaid, and in all respects shall adhere to the decimal system of numeration. Also on all streets running at right angles, but not extending to the initial points, the same order of numeration shall be observed as though such street did actually extend to such point. 
(d)  On the streets running east and west, the even numbers shall be on the north side and the odd numbers on the south side of the streets, and on the streets running north and south, the even numbers shall be on the east side and the odd numbers on the west side on such streets. 
(e)  Each of the figures of every number shall be not less than three (3) inches in length, being so marked as to be distinctly and easily read. The numbers shall be placed in a conspicuous place on the side of or above the front door of the building to which the same are attached. 
(f)  The village clerk shall furnish any owner or occupant of a building a proper number for the building according to the above plan, on application being made to such clerk, but each owner or occupant must furnish his own number to be placed on such building. 
(g)  Any owner or occupant of any building in the village who, after being notified by the village clerk, to number any building owned or occupied by him, in conformity with the provisions of this section, shall be guilty of an offense. 
(Code 1977, § 5.1) 
State Law reference- Authority to regulate numbering of buildings and lots, 65 ILCS 5/11-80-18. 
Sec. 21-3. - Snow, leaves, landscape or other waste. 
    It shall be unlawful to throw, push or remove snow, leaves, landscape or other waste from any private property so as to cast, place or deposit such waste upon the right-of-way of any state or county highway or upon the right-of-way of any public street that is within one hundred (100) feet of any intersection of streets, or upon that part of any public street between the two (2) curbs of the street where curbs exist, or upon the regularly traveled part of any public street within the village where curbs do no exist, or upon any public sidewalk of any public street. 
(Code 1977, § 5.2(b); Ord. No. 02-O-115, § 2, 11-26-02) 
Sec. 21-4. - Encroachments in streets and other public property. 
(a)  Encroachments prohibited without permit. Except as otherwise specifically provided by this Code or by ordinance or resolution of the board of trustees, no person shall plant any tree, shrub or other perennial, or place, install or maintain any fixture or other encroachment, within the boundaries of any public street, alley, sidewalk or other public right-of-way or ground within the village without the prior express written authorization of the board of trustees. 
(b)  Trimming of overhanging trees and removal of encroachments. Except when otherwise expressly authorized by action of the board of trustees, the owners, tenants and occupants of property adjoining the public streets, alleys, sidewalks and other public grounds of the village shall keep trees, shrubs and other perennials growing upon their respective parcels of land, sufficiently trimmed so as to prevent such trees and shrubs or other perennials from overhanging or extending into any public street, alley or sidewalk or other public grounds in a manner which will interfere with the use thereof or visibility, or will endanger the proper use thereof, and shall remove other encroachments or obstructions extending from their respective parcels of land into or over the boundaries of any public street, alley, sidewalk or other public ground, as well as any tree or limb of tree which becomes likely to fall on or across any public place or way. 
(c)  Failure to remove obstructions. Whenever any property owner, tenant or other occupant fails to comply with any of the provisions of this section, the director of public works shall, if practicable, give or cause to be given to any such person written notice detailing the breach or breaches and demanding compliance with the provisions hereof within such reasonable time, not exceeding twenty (20) days, as the director of public works may designate. Whenever any person fails to comply with any of the provisions of this section after notice in accordance with the foregoing, or without notice if such person or his agent cannot be readily found for the purpose of such notice, the department of public works, on the direction of the board of trustees, shall remedy the condition constituting the breach or breaches of the provisions hereof. 
(Code 1977, § 5.5; Ord. No. 96-O-60, § 4, 10-22-96) 
Sec. 21-5. - Driveways. 
(a)  Definition. The term "public parkway," as used in this section, shall refer to the area between the curb or regularly traveled portion of a public street and the public sidewalk, if one exists, or the adjoining property line if there is no public sidewalk. 
(b)  Construction of driveways. No person shall construct a driveway on any public parkway in the village without a permit being issued pursuant to authority granted by the corporate authorities of the village in accordance with the following provisions: 
(1)  The person desiring to construct such a driveway shall first file with the building commissioner an application in writing for such a permit, together with a sketch or drawing showing the location of the proposed driveway, setting forth the nature of the title or interest of the applicant in the premises to be serviced and such other details and information as may be reasonably required by the building commissioner for processing the application, and also setting forth an express agreement whereby the applicant, on behalf of himself and his successors in title or interest, agrees to maintain the driveway in good condition at his own expense. 
(2)  No one shall be personally liable under such agreement for the maintenance of such driveway in good condition after he ceases to have any right, title or interest in or to the premises serviced by the driveway. 
(3)  The building commissioner shall have power to authorize the issuance of a permit for the construction of a driveway on a public parkway, at a specific location, when the building commissioner finds that the applicant has title to the premises to be serviced by the proposed driveway or such right to use such premises as will make such driveway reasonably necessary for the enjoyment thereof, and finds that the proposed location will not constitute a hazard to traffic or interfere with public improvements, and when the proposed construction meets the requirements in section 21-36. 
(4)  Each driveway so authorized shall be properly maintained in good condition so long as it remains in use, by the owner of the abutting property. If the building commissioner at any time finds that any such driveway is not in good condition, he shall post a notice at or near same condemning and prohibiting the use thereof; and thereafter no person shall drive any vehicle across such driveway unless and until the building commissioner finds that it is restored to good condition. It shall be unlawful for anyone other than the building commissioner or someone duly authorized by him to remove any notice posted as aforesaid. 
(5)  Whenever the building commissioner finds that any such driveway is not in good condition, he shall endeavor to give personal notice thereof to the owner or occupant of the abutting property which has been serviced by the driveway. Failure of the building commissioner to give such personal notice shall in no way impair the validity of any action taken by him hereunder. Neither shall it validate the use of the driveway in violation of any of the provisions hereof nor relieve anyone from any responsibility therefor or from the imposition of any penalty hereunder. 
(c)  Existing driveways. Driveways existing on September 10, 1957, and which substantially meet the construction requirements specified under subsection (b), will be considered as having been duly authorized. Use of existing driveways not constructed substantially as specified under subsection (b) shall be terminated. 
(Code 1977, § 5.4) 
Sec. 21-6. - Newsracks. 
(a)  Definitions. The term "newsrack" shall mean, for the purposes of this section, any self-service or coin-operated box, container, storage unit, or other dispenser designed, intended, used, placed, installed, or maintained for the display and sale or distribution of newspapers, periodicals, or other publications. 
    The term "Central Business District" or "CBD" shall be the geographic area of the village with the same boundaries as the Village of Libertyville Tax Increment Finance District as set forth in Ordinance No. 89-O-53. 
(b)  Applications for permit. Applications for a newsrack permit shall be filed with the village administrator or designee on a form as provided by the village, and which form shall, at a minimum, include information sufficient to confirm that the placement and design of the newsrack will conform to the standards set forth in this Code. A permit granted hereunder shall apply only to the location provided for in the permit, and no newsrack permitted hereunder shall be relocated without application for an issuance of a new permit. 
    Every person who places or maintains a newsrack within the public right-of-way in the village shall provide the name, address and telephone numbers of such person in a place on the newsrack where it can be easily seen. 
(c)  Application fee. Every application for a newsrack permit shall include a fee in the amount of twenty-five dollars ($25.00) as payment for the costs of review and administration of the application, and inspection of the newsrack. The village administrator or designee shall, within ten (10) days after a properly completed application is submitted, either issue a permit for the newsrack or deny the application for permit for a newsrack that does not comply with any one (1) or more of said regulations. 
(d)  Newsrack regulations in the Central Business District (CBD). To ensure uniformity and to preserve the historic and aesthetic appearance of the village and CBD, and to ensure an appearance complimentary to the streetscape design of the CBD, all newsracks intended by their owner to be placed within the CBD shall be located within structures designed, placed, and provided by the village. To the extent that the all of the village provided structures have reached their capacity and cannot accommodate further requests for the placement of a newsrack within the CBD, the regulations pertaining to newracks located outside the CBD as set forth in subsection (e) below shall govern the placement of such newsracks. In the event a newsrack is placed outside of a village provided structure within the CBD pursuant to the foregoing sentence, such newsrack shall be relocated within a village provided structure within ten (10) days of notice by the village to the owner of the newsrack that space within the village provided structure has become available. 
(e)  Regulations for newsracks outside the CBD. All newsracks located outside the CBD shall conform to the following location standards: 
(1)  Not more than six (6) newsracks may be located at any one (1) location/intersection. 
(2)  No newsrack shall project on to any part of the roadway or public street. 
(3)  No newsrack shall be placed in a manner so that its installation, use or maintenance endangers the safety of persons or property, or unreasonably interferes with, or impedes the flow of pedestrian or vehicular traffic, ingress or egress to any residence, business, or legally parked vehicle. At least five (5) feet of continuous, unobstructed clear paved space shall be maintained for the passage of pedestrians on any sidewalk. 
(4)  No newsrack shall be placed in a manner so that it interferes with the operation and maintenance of poles, posts, traffic signs or signals, hydrants, mailboxes, or other objects permitted at or near such placement. 
(5)  No newsrack shall be placed in a manner so that it interferes with the cleaning of any sidewalk by the use of mechanical sidewalk cleaning machinery. 
(6)  No newsrack shall be placed closer than eighteen (18) inches to the edge of any curb, nor placed further than twenty-four (24) inches from the edge of any curb, or adjacent to and less than six (6) inches from the wall of a building, provided that the village administrator or designee may authorize and direct that a newsrack may be placed near the wall of a building if the village determines that public safety considerations preclude placement of the newsrack near the curb at or near the location requested in the application. All newsracks placed near the curb shall be placed parallel to, and facing away from, the curb. 
(7)  No newsrack shall be placed, installed, used or maintained in any of the following locations: 
a.  Within five (5) feet of any designated crosswalk or within ten (10) feet of any intersection where no crosswalk is designated; 
b.  Within ten (10) feet of any fire hydrant, fire call box, police call box, or any other emergency facility; 
c.  Within five (5) feet of any bus bench, plaza bench, doorway to any commuter passenger station or any sign or other marking designating a bus stop; 
d.  Within five (5) feet of any doorway; 
e.  Within three (3) feet of any area improved with lawn, flowers, shrubs, or trees; or 
f.  Within three (3) feet of any display window of any building abutting the sidewalk, or parkway, or in such manner as to impede or interfere with the reasonable use of such window for display purposes; 
g.  No newsrack shall be placed on any handicap access ramp. 
(8)  No newsrack shall be chained, bolted or otherwise attached to any property not owned by the owner of the newsrack, to any pole, bench, traffic signal, hydrant, mailbox or other object or structure in the public right-of-way, or to another newsrack, provided that no more than three (3) newsracks may be joined together in this manner so long as there is space of not less than eighteen (18) inches separating each group of three (3) newsracks from any other group. 
(9)  No newsrack shall be placed facing another newsrack. 
(10)  No newsrack shall be placed in a sight triangle described by the edge of pavement lines of two (2) intersecting streets in a line connecting said edge of pavement lines, and any leg of such triangle shall be an angle of twenty-five (25) feet in length. 
(11)  Each newsrack shall be maintained in a clean, neat and attractive condition and in good repair at all times. The owner shall remove any graffiti within forty-eight (48) hours of notice to do so by the village. 
(12)  No newsrack shall be used for advertising signs or publicity purposes other than advertising dealing directly with the display, sale or purchase of the newspaper or publication contained therein. 
(13)  All newsracks shall be constructed from materials which are weather-resistant, and which have either sufficient wight or are weighted to ensure the stability of the newsrack. 
(14)  All newsracks shall conform with a standard size not to exceed fifty (50) inches in height, eighteen (18) inches in depth and twenty-four (24) inches in width. 
(f)  Nonconforming newsracks. Within sixty (60) days after the effective date of the ordinance from which this section derives, any newsrack that does not comply with any regulation of this section shall be brought immediately into compliance, and thereafter all newsracks shall at all times be maintained in compliance, with all of the regulations of this section or shall be removed. Any newsrack not so brought into, or maintained in, compliance or removed shall be removed by the village administrator, subject to the provisions of subsection (h) of this section. 
(g)  Nuisance declared. Any newsrack that is placed, affixed, erected, constructed, installed, or maintained on any public street, highway, sidewalk, parkway, alley, or other public right-of-way in violation of any provision of this section is hereby declared a public nuisance and may be removed at any time by the village administrator, subject to the provisions of subsection (i) of this section. 
(h)  Notice of removal for noncompliance. Prior to removal of a newsrack pursuant to subsection (f) or subsection (g) of this section, the village administrator shall give seven (7) days' written notice of such removal, and opportunity to cure all violations, to the person identified pursuant to subsection (c)(2) of this section. If any violation remains after such seven-day notice and opportunity to cure, then the village administrator may immediately remove the newsrack. 
(i)  Abandoned newsracks. Any newsrack that, at any time, does not contain a current edition of the publication specified therefor for seventy-two (72) consecutive hours or longer, or that is empty at any time for seven (7) consecutive days or longer, shall be deemed abandoned, regardless of any intent or purpose of the owner or operator thereof to use or not abandon such newsrack. Every abandoned newsrack may be removed immediately by the village administrator. 
(j)  Reimbursement for damage caused by newsracks. The owner of any newsrack located within the village shall be responsible for payment of any damages caused by such newsracks to public property, including but not limited to sidewalks, streets light poles and village provided newsrack structures located within the CBD. 
(k)  Penalty. Any person who violates this section shall be subject to a fine of not less than two hundred fifty dollars ($250.00) and not more than seven hundred fifty dollars ($750.00) for each offense. Each day on which a violation occurs or continues shall be considered a separate offense. 
(Ord. No. 02-O-68, § 2, 6-12-02) 
Secs. 21-7-21-25. - Reserved.

Secs. 21-26-21-39. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - STREET VACATION 

Sec. 21-40. - Initiating petition. 
    Any person or persons owning real property abutting any village street, alley, or public way within the village limits who wish to institute proceedings for the vacation of such street, alley, or public way shall file with the village clerk a written petition setting forth the following information: 
(1)  The name and address of the petitioner/owner. 
(2)  A complete disclosure of interest of the ownership of petitioner's property including the names of the trustees and the beneficial owners of such property and, if such property is owned by a corporation, a disclosure of the shareholders of such corporation and the names of the officers and directors of such corporation. 
(3)  The common description of the village street, alley, or public way to be vacated as well as the legal description of same. 
(4)  The intended land use of the village street, alley, or public way to be vacated. 
(5)  The names and addresses of all property owners within two hundred fifty (250) feet of the village street, alley, or public way to be vacated. 
(6)  A plat of vacation meeting all of the requirements of 765 ILCS 205/9. 
(7)  A fee determined in accordance with the annual fee ordinance to cover administrative costs. 
    The provisions of this section shall not apply when the village, of its own volition, proposes to vacate any village street, alley, or public way. 
(Ord. No. 94-0-54, § 2, 11-8-94) 
Sec. 21-41. - Public meeting. 
    Within sixty (60) days of receipt of an initiating petition filed pursuant to section 21-40 above, or if the village, of its own volition, proposes to vacate any village, street, alley or public way within the village limits, the village clerk shall send a general letter notifying the property owners within two hundred fifty (250) feet of the village street, alley, or public way to be vacated of the date on which a public meeting will be held for a determination as to whether the board of trustees shall vacate the subject street, alley, or public way. The notification letter shall be mailed not less than fifteen (15) days, nor more than thirty (30) days, prior to the public meeting. 
(Ord. No. 94-0-54, § 2, 11-8-94) 
Sec. 21-42. - Action by board of trustees. 
    If the board of trustees finds and determines that the vacation of any village street, alley, or public way is in the best interest of the citizens of the village and the public interest will be served by vacating such street, alley, or public way, the board of trustees shall, by ordinance duly adopted upon the affirmative vote of three-fourths (3/4) of the trustees then holding office, vacate the subject street, alley, or public way, with or without such terms and conditions as the board of trustees shall determine, including without limitation (i) providing that the ordinance shall not become effective until the petitioner/owner or the owners of property abutting the subject street, alley, or public way shall pay to the village compensation in an amount to be determined in accordance with the provisions of section 21-43 below, and all other amounts due to the village pursuant to this article, and (ii) reserving property, rights-of-way, and easements as, in the judgment of the board of trustees, are necessary or desirable for the construction, reconstruction, operation, maintenance, repair, replacement, or alteration of existing or future public service facilities. 
(Ord. No. 94-0-54, § 2, 11-8-94) 
Sec. 21-43. - Compensation. 
(a)  Compensation required. The petitioner/owner or the owners of property abutting the village street, alley, or public way to be vacated shall pay to the village one hundred (100) percent of the fair market value of the vacated street, alley, or public way. 
(b)  Determination of fair market value. The fair market value of the village street, alley, or public way to be vacated shall be determined by one (1) (or two (2)) appraiser(s) retained by the village. One (1) appraiser shall be used, unless the village determines that the estimated value of the land is sufficient to warrant a second opinion. The fair market value shall be determined by considering the benefits that will accrue by reason of the vacation, including the intended land use without the benefit of public improvements. In the event public improvements already benefit such street, alley, or public way, the fair market value shall be determined by considering the benefits that will accrue by reasons of the vacation, including the intended land use as benefited by the public improvements. 
    If an initiating petition is filed pursuant to section 21-40 above and the village requests, the petitioner/owner shall sign a restrictive covenant reciting that the vacated village street, alley, or public way shall be used only in a manner consistent with the use represented in the initiating petition. The restrictive covenant shall be in a form approved by the village attorney. 
(c)  Cost of appraisal. The petitioner/owner shall pay all costs incurred by the village in having the village street, alley, or public way to be vacated appraised except in cases where the village, of its own volition, proposes to vacate any village street, alley, or public way within the village limits, in which case the village shall pay all such costs. 
(Ord. No. 94-0-54, § 2, 11-8-94) 
Sec. 21-44. - Variances. 
    In recognition of the fact that there may be unique situations whereby the rigid application of this article may result in an inequity to the village or the petitioner/owner or, in light of special circumstances making compliance with the provisions of this article either unnecessary or unduly burdensome, the board of trustees may, by ordinance duly adopted for good cause shown, vary or waive the procedures and requirements of sections 21-40, 21-41, and 21-43 above as to a particular parcel of land. 
(Ord. No. 94-0-54, § 2, 11-8-94) 
Secs. 21-45-21-55. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE IV. - PARADES[3] 
Footnotes: 
--- (3) --- 
Cross reference- Traffic, Ch. 23. 
State Law reference- Authority to regulate parades, 625 ILCS 5/11-208(a)(3). 

DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 21-56. - Definitions. 
    In this article "parade" means any parade, march, ceremony, show, exhibition, pageant or procession of any kind, or any similar display, in or upon any street in this village. 
Secs. 21-57-21-70. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - PERMIT 

Sec. 21-71. - Required. 
    No person shall engage in, participate in, aid, form or start any parade, unless a parade permit shall have been obtained from the village administrator. 
Sec. 21-72. - Application. 
(a)  A person seeking issuance of a parade permit shall file an application with the village administrator not less than five (5) days nor more than ten (10) days before the date on which it is proposed to conduct the parade on forms provided by the administrator. 
(b)  The application for a parade permit shall set forth the following information: 
(1)  The name, address and telephone number of the person seeking to conduct the parade. 
(2)  If the parade is proposed to be conducted for, on behalf of, or by an organization, the name, address and telephone number of the headquarters of the organization, and of the authorized and responsible heads of the organization. 
(3)  The name, address and telephone number of the person who will be the parade chairman and who will be responsible for its conduct. 
(4)  The date when the parade is to be conducted. 
(5)  The route to be traveled, the starting point and the termination point. 
(6)  The approximate number of persons who, and animals and vehicles which, will constitute such parade; the types of animals; and description of the vehicles. 
(7)  The hours when the parade will start and terminate. 
(8)  A statement as to whether the parade will occupy all or only a portion of the width of the streets proposed to be traversed. 
(9)  The location by streets of any assembly areas for the parade. 
(10)  The time at which units of the parade will begin to assemble at the assembly areas. 
(11)  The interval of space to be maintained between units of the parade. 
(12)  If the parade is designed to be held by, or on behalf of or for, any person other than the applicant, a communication in writing from the person proposing to hold the parade, authorizing the applicant to apply for the permit. 
(13)  Any additional information which the director shall find reasonably necessary to a fair determination as to whether a permit should issue. 
(c)  The village administrator, where good cause is shown therefor, shall have the authority to consider any application that is filed less than five (5) days before the date the parade is proposed to be conducted. 
Sec. 21-73. - Standards for issuance. 
    The village administrator shall issue a parade permit when, from a consideration of the application and from such other information as may otherwise be obtained, the administrator finds that: 
(1)  The conduct of the parade will not substantially interrupt the safe and orderly movement of other traffic contiguous to its route. 
(2)  The conduct of the parade will not require the diversion of so great a number of police officers of this village to properly police the line of movement and the areas contiguous thereto as to prevent normal police protection to this village. 
(3)  The conduct of such parade will not require the diversion of so great a number of ambulances as to prevent normal ambulance service to portions of this village other than that to be occupied by the proposed line of march and areas contiguous thereto. 
(4)  The concentration of persons, animals and vehicles at assembly points of the parade will not unduly interfere with proper fire and police protection of, or ambulance service to, areas contiguous to the assembly areas. 
(5)  The conduct of the parade will not interfere with the movement of firefighting equipment en route to a fire. 
(6)  The conduct of the parade is not reasonably likely to cause injury to persons or property, to provoke disorderly conduct or create a disturbance. 
(7)  The parade is scheduled to move from its point of origin to its point of termination expeditiously and without unreasonable delays en route. 
Sec. 21-74. - Notice of permit rejection. 
    If the village administrator disapproves the parade permit application, the administrator shall mail to the applicant within three (3) days after the date upon which the application was filed, a notice of such action. 
Sec. 21-75. - Alternative permit. 
    The village administrator, in denying an application for a parade permit, may authorize the conduct of the parade on a date, at a time, or over a route different from that named by the applicant. An applicant desiring to accept an alternate permit shall, within two (2) days after notice of the action of the administrator, file a written notice of acceptance with the administrator. An alternate parade permit shall conform to the requirements of, and shall have the effect of a parade permit. 
Sec. 21-76. - Contents of permit. 
    Each parade permit shall state the following information: 
(1)  Starting time. 
(2)  Minimum speed. 
(3)  Maximum speed. 
(4)  Maximum interval of space to be maintained between the units of the parade. 
(5)  The portions of the streets to be traversed that may be occupied by the parade. 
(6)  The maximum length of the parade in miles or fractions thereof. 
(7)  Such other information as the village administrator shall find necessary to enforce the provisions of this article. 
Sec. 21-77. - Possession of permit. 
    The parade chairperson or other person heading or leading the activity shall carry the parade permit during the conduct of the parade. 
Sec. 21-78. - Compliance with law required. 
    A parade permittee shall comply with all permit directions and conditions and with all applicable laws and ordinances. 
Sec. 21-79. - Revocation of permit. 
    The village administrator may revoke a parade permit issued hereunder upon application of the standards for issuance set forth in this division. 
Chapter 22 - SUBDIVISIONS AND OTHER DEVELOPMENTS[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Editor's note- Ordinance No. 96-0-14, § 2, adopted March 14, 1996, amended ch. 22, §§ 22-1-22-6, 22-26, 22-27, 22-46-22-48, 22-61-22-63, 22-70-22-72, 22-81-22-86, 22-101-22-113, 22-131-22-143, 22-161-22-171, 22-186-22-190 in their entirety by replacing it with a new ch. 22. Formerly, such chapter pertained to similar provisions and derived from sections in the 1977 Code. See Code Comparative Table for 1977 Code. 
Cross reference- Buildings and technical regulations, Ch. 6; community appearance, Ch. 7; environmental preservation, Ch. 9; planning and development, Ch. 18; zoning, Ch. 26. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 22-1. - Title. 
    This chapter 22 shall be known as, and may be referred to as, the "Libertyville Subdivision Code." 
(Ord. No. 96-0-14, § 2(22-100), 3-14-96) 
Sec. 22-2. - Purposes. 
    The Libertyville Subdivision Code has been adopted for the following purposes: 
(1)  To provide for the harmonious development of the village and its environs; 
(2)  To establish reasonable design standards and procedures for subdivisions and other developments; 
(3)  To provide for the preparation of subdivision and development plans and the procedures for submittal, approval and recording of plats of subdivisions in and about the village; 
(4)  To protect valuable natural and cultural resources; 
(5)  To guarantee the construction, inspection, dedication and acceptance of appropriate public improvements; 
(6)  To provide for the coordination of new streets with existing or other planned streets; 
(7)  To promote the logical arrangement of lots for future development; 
(8)  To provide adequate storm drainage and flood control measures; 
(9)  To provide for the dedication and acceptance of land required for schools, parks, playgrounds and other municipal public uses; and 
(10)  To insure proper legal descriptions and monumenting of subdivided properties. 
(Ord. No. 96-0-14, § 2(22-101), 3-14-96) 
Sec. 22-3. - Jurisdiction. 
    The Libertyville Subdivision Code shall apply to every subdivision and development within the corporate limits of the village and within one and one-half (11/2) miles of those corporate limits. Valid, binding boundary line agreements between the village and other municipalities may take precedence in establishing the village's jurisdiction in unincorporated areas within such one and one-half (11/2) mile area. 
(Ord. No. 96-0-14, § 2(22-102), 3-14-96) 
Sec. 22-4. - Component of comprehensive plan. 
    The Libertyville Subdivision Code is a part of the official comprehensive plan of the village, in accordance with section 3-1.2 of the Libertyville Zoning Code. 
(Ord. No. 96-0-14, § 2(22-103), 3-14-96) 
Sec. 22-5. - Definitions. 
    When used in this chapter, the following terms shall have the definitions herein ascribed to them: 
    Abut means to touch, to lie immediately next, to share a common wall or lot line, or to be separated by only a street, alley or drainage course. 
    Adjacent means to lie near, close to or in the vicinity. 
    Annual fee ordinance means the ordinance of the village adopted pursuant to section 1-19 of the Libertyville Municipal Code setting forth applicable fees and charges for various, licenses, permits and services. 
    Block means a tract of land bounded by streets or by a combination of streets, public parks, cemeteries, railroad rights-of-way, bulkhead lines or shorelines, waterways or boundary lines of the village. 
    Board of trustees means the president and board of trustees of the village. 
    Developer means any person who undertakes the "subdivision" or "developer" of land, as those terms are defined in this chapter, including without limitation all record owners and beneficial owners of the property that is the subject of the subdivision or development. 
    Development means: 
(1)  Any of the following actions that are not included within the definition of, and governed by the regulations applicable to, a "subdivision" as that term is defined in this chapter: Any change, rearrangement or resubdivision in the boundary or divisional lines of any parcel or parcels of real estate, or the creation of, or change to or rearrangement of the boundaries of, any public street; 
(2)  Construction of a new building or structure having a floor area in excess of five hundred (500) square feet, other than one (1) single-family dwelling unit; 
(3)  Expansion by more than twenty-five (25) percent of an existing structure to which this chapter would apply if the structure were being constructed new; or 
(4)  Construction on any parcel of land that will create more than three (3) parking spaces. 
Any development that also is defined as a "subdivision" as that term is defined in this chapter, and that is governed by the regulations applicable to a subdivision, shall be regulated as a subdivision for purposes of this chapter. 
    Easement means authorization by a property owner for the use by another, for a specified purpose, of any designated area of that property owner's property. The term "easement" also refers to such a designated area. 
    Engineering plans means complete plans, specifications and analyses governing the design and construction of all required public improvements, including without limitation streets, sidewalks, sewer systems, water distribution and supply systems, lighting systems and landscaping. 
    Improvement, public means any facility necessary in the determination of the village to provide a parcel with access to a public right-of-way or with utility service of any kind or with water, sanitary sewage treatment or disposal, stormwater control or drainage, or other necessary public service, including, but not limited to, any street, alley, public way, way for public service facilities, storm and flood water run-off system, storm sewer, channel, basin, sanitary sewer, septic system, water main, public grounds, sidewalk, planting strip, landscaping, off-street parking area. 
    Outlot means a parcel of land which is intended for a public or quasi-public purpose, including open space, conservation, storm water detention, utility facilities, or other similar use. An outlot shall not be required to meet the minimum lot dimension requirements established by the Village of Libertyville Zoning Code or Subdivision Code. An outlot may not be created for the purpose of changing or preserving the bulk, space, and yard regulations of an adjacent parcel. 
    Person means any individual, firm, corporation, partnership, joint venture, trust, trustee, estate, association or other similar legal entity and any agent thereof. 
    Plan commission means the Libertyville Plan Commission. 
    Plat officer means the village administrator or his or her duly authorized delegate or delegates. 
    Public improvement. See "improvement, public." 
    Requirements of law means all applicable federal, state and village laws, statutes, codes, ordinances, resolutions, rules and regulations, and written administrative policies of the village, including without limitation all village design standards. 
    Right-of-way means a strip of land occupied or intended to be occupied by a street or sidewalk or related facilities, railroad, electric line, oil or gas pipeline, water main, sanitary or storm sewer or communications line or for other special uses. 
    Street means a public or private right-of-way that affords a primary means of vehicular access to abutting properties, whether designated as a street, avenue, highway, road, boulevard, lane or throughway or however otherwise designated. 
    Street, private means a street situated within an outlot or private easement, not dedicated to or maintained by the village or any other government agency. 
    Street, public means a street located within a public right-of-way dedicated to or maintained by the village or any other governmental agency. 
    Street width means the shortest distance between the backs of parallel curbs or outer parallel limits of the paved portion of a street. 
    Subdivision means all of the following divisions, rearrangements or developments of land: 
(1)  Any change, rearrangement or resubdivision in the boundary or divisional lines of any parcel or parcels of real estate, or the creation of, or change to or rearrangement of the boundaries of, any public street; 
(2)  The platting of a parcel or tract of land into a single numbered lot without alteration of its boundaries; or 
(3)  Any planned development, as that term is defined by the Libertyville Zoning Code; 
provided, however, that the requirements of this chapter applicable to subdivisions shall not apply in the following instances: 
(1)  The subdivision of land into parcels of five (5) acres or more in size that does not involve any new street or easement of access. 
(2)  The division of lots or blocks of less than one (1) acre in any recorded subdivision which does not involve any new street or easement of access. 
(3)  The sale or exchange of parcels of land between owners of abutting land. 
(4)  Any subdivision that will not result in the creation of any additional buildable lot or parcel of land. 
(5)  The conveyance of land for highway or other public purposes or grants or conveyances relating to the dedication of land for public use or instruments relating to the vacation of land impressed with a public use. 
(6)  The sale or exchange of parcels or tracts of land following the division into no more than two (2) parts of a particular parcel or tract of land existing on July 17, 1959, and not involving any new streets or easements of access. 
(7)  The sale of a single lot of less than five (5) acres from a larger tract when a survey is made by a state registered surveyor; provided, however, that this exemption shall not apply to the sale of any subsequent lots from the same larger tract of land, as determined by the dimensions and configuration of the larger tract on October 1, 1973. 
    Village means the Village of Libertyville, Illinois. 
    Village administrator means the village administrator of the Village of Libertyville or his or her duly authorized delegate or delegates. 
    Village design standards means all codes, ordinances, regulations and written administrative policies and orders of the village, as they may be supplemented and amended from time to time, establishing standards and specifications for construction in the village, including without limitation construction of public improvements as part of a subdivision or development. 
    Village engineer means the village engineer of the Village of Libertyville or his or her duly authorized delegate or delegates. 
(Ord. No. 96-0-14, § 2(22-104), 3-14-96; Ord. No. 98-O-65, § 2, 8-11-98) 
Cross reference- Definitions and rules of construction generally, § 1-2. 
Sec. 22-6. - Word usage. 
(a)  Tense. Words used in the present tense shall include the future, and words used in the singular number shall include the plural number, and the plural the singular. 
(b)  Shall. The word "shall" is mandatory and not discretionary. 
(c)  May. The word "may" is permissive. 
(d)  Gender. Every reference in either the masculine gender or the feminine gender includes both of those genders and the neuter gender. 
(e)  Meanings. Any term not defined in this chapter shall have the meaning given first in the Libertyville Zoning Code; then, if none, in any other applicable village code or ordinance; then, if none, in the most recent edition of "Illustrated Book of Development Definitions"; then, if none, in "Transportation and Land Developments," published by the Institute of Transportation Engineers; and then, if none, in Webster's International Dictionary of the English Language. 
(f)  Text controlling. In case of any difference in meaning or implication between the text of this chapter and any caption, illustration, or table, the text shall control. 
(g)  Computation of time. The time within which any act required by this chapter is to be performed shall be computed by excluding the first day and including the last day, unless the last day is a Saturday or Sunday or a holiday declared by the United States Congress or the Illinois General Assembly, in which event it shall also be excluded. 
(Ord. No. 96-0-14, § 2(22-105), 3-14-96) 
Sec. 22-7. - Severability. 
    The various provisions of this chapter shall be severable in accordance with the following rules: 
(1)  Other provisions binding. If any court of competent jurisdiction shall adjudge any provision of this chapter to be invalid, such judgment shall not affect any other provisions of this chapter. 
(2)  Other applications valid. If any court of competent jurisdiction shall adjudge invalid any application of any provision of this chapter to a particular parcel of land, such judgment shall not affect the application of such provision to any other parcel of land. 
(Ord. No. 96-0-14, § 2(22-106), 3-14-96) 
Secs. 22-8-22-25. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - ADMINISTRATION 

Sec. 22-26. - Application and compliance required. 
(a)  Subdivision or development. No subdivision or development shall be undertaken within the jurisdiction defined in section 22-28 of this chapter, except after application pursuant to this chapter, and except only in compliance with the provisions of this chapter. 
(b)  Recording; improvements. No subdivision shall be filed for record, nor any public improvement made related to any subdivision or development, until after approval thereof pursuant to this chapter. 
(c)  Conveyances. No lot, tract or parcel of land within any proposed subdivision shall be conveyed until such subdivision has been approved and recorded pursuant to this chapter. 
(d)  Reimbursement of legal fees for negotiation and drafting of development agreements. No application for approval of a subdivision or development shall be deemed complete and no permits requested in connection with such applications shall be issued unless the developer has executed an agreement, upon forms approved by the village, agreeing to reimburse the village for all legal fees incurred by the village and billed to the developer in connection with the negotiation and preparation of any development agreements which may be required in connection with such subdivision or development. No certificates of occupancy shall be issued in connection with such subdivision or development if the legal fees billed to the developer pursuant to this section not been paid by the developer to the village. 
(Ord. No. 96-0-14, § 2(22-200), 3-14-96; Ord. No. 07-O-70, § 2, 10-9-07) 
Sec. 22-27. - Administrative review of developments by plat officer. 
    All applications for approvals of developments shall be reviewed by the plat officer in accordance with the standards and procedures set forth in sections 22-51 and 22-71 of this chapter. 
(Ord. No. 96-0-14, § 2(22-201), 3-14-96) 
Sec. 22-28. - Administrative review of plats of consolidation by plat officer. 
    All applications for approvals of plats of consolidation shall be reviewed by the plat officer in accordance with the standards and procedures set forth in sections 22-52 and 22-71 of this chapter. 
(Ord. No. 96-0-14, § 2(22-202), 3-14-96) 
Sec. 22-29. - Review of applications for plats of subdivision. 
    All applications for approvals of plats of subdivision shall be reviewed by the plan commission and the board of trustees in accordance with the standards and procedures set forth in sections 22-53 through 22-56 and 22-72 through 22-74 of this chapter. 
(Ord. No. 96-0-14, § 2(22-203), 3-14-96) 
Sec. 22-30. - Review of applications for plats of vacation. 
    All applications for approvals of plats of vacation shall be reviewed by the board of trustees in accordance with the standards and procedures set forth in sections 22-57 and 22-75 of this chapter. No application for vacation of a plat of subdivision shall be reviewed unless all owners of all property within such subdivision have joined in writing in such application. 
(Ord. No. 96-0-14, § 2(22-204), 3-14-96) 
Sec. 22-31. - Modifications of certain application requirements by plat officer. 
    The plat officer may modify or waive any requirement established in article III of this chapter applicable to an application for a development, a plat of consolidation, a preliminary plat of subdivision, or a plat of vacation if the plat officer, in the exercise of his or her discretion, determines that such waiver will not have a detrimental impact on the village and will not be contrary to the purposes and intents of this chapter. 
(Ord. No. 96-0-14, § 2(22-205), 3-14-96) 
Sec. 22-32. - Variations. 
    On application to the plat officer in writing on a form provided by the village and payment of the fee required by the annual fee ordinance, variations from the provisions of this chapter may be authorized by the board of trustees in accordance with the provisions of this section. 
(1)  Statement of justification. In applying for a variation from the provisions of this chapter, the applicant shall demonstrate in writing that: 
a.  The requested variation is in keeping with the overall purpose and intent of this chapter;
