b.  The grant of the requested variation will serve the public health, safety or general welfare and will alleviate a practical difficulty or particular hardship; 
c.  The grant of the variation will not be to the detriment of adjacent properties; and 
d.  The situation of the applicant is not of a general or recurring nature for similarly situated properties within the village or within its jurisdiction. 
(2)  Limitations on variations. No variation granted pursuant to this section shall relieve a developer from complying with every other requirement of law. Nothing provided in this section 22-32 shall be construed or applied as authority of the board of trustees to vary any requirement of law other than the provisions of this chapter. 
(3)  Conditions may be imposed. In authorizing a variation, the board of trustees may impose such conditions regarding the location, character and other features of the proposed subdivision or development as it may, in its sole and absolute discretion, deem necessary in the public interest, and may require the posting of a performance guarantee to insure compliance with the conditions imposed. 
(4)  Procedure for review of variation requests. Applications for variations from the provisions of this chapter shall be reviewed concurrently with the related subdivision or development application, except as otherwise provided by the board of trustees on a case by case basis. Every such application, however, shall be heard at a public meeting of the board of trustees after notice thereof given to the applicant in writing not less than five (5) days nor more than thirty (30) days before such public meeting. 
(Ord. No. 96-0-14, § 2(22-206), 3-14-96) 
Sec. 22-33. - Exceptions for annexed land. 
    The board of trustees may modify or waive any requirement of this chapter for any land newly annexed to the village when such modification or waiver is in pursuance of an annexation agreement entered into as authorized by an ordinance or resolution duly adopted under the provisions of division 15.1 of article 11 of the Illinois Municipal Code as amended. 
(Ord. No. 96-0-14, § 2(22-207), 3-14-96) 
Sec. 22-34. - Building permits. 
    Except as specifically provided otherwise in writing by the board of trustees in an approved development agreement, annexation agreement, or other agreement: 
(1)  General prohibition. No building permit shall be issued for any work within any subdivision or for a development until after final engineering plans for all required public improvements have been approved by the village engineer as provided in section 22-103 and 22-104 of this chapter and appropriate security has been posted as provided in article VII of this chapter and, for subdivisions, until after a plat of the subdivision as recorded in the office of the county recorder of deeds has been filed with the plat officer; and 
(2)  Minimum required public improvements. No building permit shall be issued for work on any site or lot within such subdivision or development until after such site or lot is served by public water and sewer and a street improved at least through binder course. 
(Ord. No. 96-0-14, § 2(22-208), 3-14-96) 
Sec. 22-35. - Occupancy certificates. 
    Except as specifically provided otherwise in writing by the board of trustees in an approved development agreement, annexation agreement, or other agreement, no certificate of occupancy shall be issued for any building or structure until after all required public improvements are completed, approved, and, when appropriate, dedicated to and accepted by the village. 
(Ord. No. 96-0-14, § 2(22-209), 3-14-96) 
Sec. 22-36. - Interpretations. 
    On application to the plat officer in writing on a form provided by the village, the plat officer shall render interpretations of the provisions of this chapter. Applications for interpretations may be filed by any person having an interest in the circumstances giving rise to the need for an interpretation; provided, however, that interpretations shall not be given based solely on hypothetical facts or when the interpretation would have no effect other than as an advisory opinion. The plat officer shall render the requested interpretation within thirty (30) days after the receipt of a properly completed application therefor. The failure of the plat officer to act within the time period specified in this section, or such further time to which the applicant may agree, shall be deemed to be a decision of the plat officer denying the application. Appeals from interpretations rendered by the plat officer may be taken as provided in section 22-37 of this chapter. 
(Ord. No. 96-0-14, § 2(22-210), 3-14-96) 
Sec. 22-37. - Appeals; stay pending decision. 
(a)  Any person aggrieved by a decision or interpretation of the plat officer pursuant to this chapter may appeal such decision or interpretation by filing with the village clerk a notice of appeal within thirty (30) days after such decision or interpretation is made. The board of trustees shall cause notice to be given to the person making the appeal of a public meeting before the board of trustees to review such appeal. Such public meeting shall be held not fewer than five (5) days nor more than forty-five (45) days after the appeal has been filed. In making its decision, the board of trustees shall give proper deference to the reasonable decisions and interpretations of those charged with the administration of this chapter. The board of trustees shall make a decision on the appeal within sixty (60) days after the public meeting. The board of trustees may affirm, modify or reverse, in whole or in part, the decision or interpretation appealed from and may include such order or determination in its decision as the board of trustees determines, in the exercise of its discretion, is appropriate and proper under the circumstances. The decision of the board of trustees shall be final. The failure of the board of trustees to act within the time periods specified in this section, or within such further time or times to which the applicant may agree, shall be deemed to be a decision of the board of trustees denying the appeal in its entirety. 
(b)  A notice of appeal properly filed pursuant to this section shall stay all proceedings in furtherance of the action appealed from, unless the village administrator certifies to the board of trustees after the notice of appeal has been filed that, by reason of the facts stated in the notice of appeal, a stay would cause, in the village administrator's opinion, imminent peril to life or property, in which case the proceedings shall not be stayed other than by a restraining order, which may be granted by the board of trustees or which may be granted by the Illinois Circuit Court, but only on proper filing therefor, with reasonable written notice thereof to the village administrator and due cause therefor shown by the applicant. 
(Ord. No. 96-0-14, § 2(22-211), 3-14-96) 
Sec. 22-38. - Recording of approved plats. 
    After approval of a plat of consolidation, a final plat of subdivision, or a plat of vacation by the plat officer or board of trustees, the developer shall file with the plat officer two (2) original reproducible versions of the approved plat bearing all appropriate signatures and in proper form for recording with the county recorder of deeds. The developer shall pay, at the time of filing of the reproducible version of the plat, all costs and fees associated with the recording of the plat. After receipt of such payment, the plat officer shall cause such plat to be recorded. The recorded plat shall remain permanently on file with the village. 
(Ord. No. 96-0-14, § 2(22-212), 3-14-96) 
Sec. 22-39. - Penalties. 
    If a developer violates any provision of this chapter, then the village shall have, in addition to the remedies and penalties provided by section 1-12 or any other section of the Libertyville Municipal Code, the right, after two (2) days written notice to the developer stating the violation, to stop all work, or any portion of any work, being conducted on any property subject to the requirements of this chapter, to revoke any permit or authorization issued by the village for development on any such property, to discontinue processing and consideration of any pending application for any such permit or authorization, and to refuse to accept for processing or consideration any future application for any such permit or authorization. No notice to the developer shall be required pursuant to this section if the village administrator determines that, in his or her opinion, there is imminent peril to life or property requiring immediate action by the village in response to the violation. 
(Ord. No. 96-0-14, § 2(22-213), 3-14-96) 
Sec. 22-40. - Limitations on successive applications. 
    Whenever any application brought pursuant to the Libertyville Subdivision Code has been finally denied, a second application, pertaining to the same property, seeking an approval within one year following a denial of a similar request for approval shall not be brought unless, in the opinion of the plat officer, board of trustees or commission before which the application was brought, the second application contains modifications which render it materially different from the first application or there is substantial new evidence available or a mistake of law or fact which significantly affected the prior denial. 
(a)  Any new grounds to be stated. Any such second application shall include a detailed statement of the grounds justifying consideration of such application. 
(b)  Summary denial with or without hearing. Any such second application may be denied by the plat officer summarily, and without hearing, on a finding by the plat officer that no grounds appear that would warrant further processing of the application. In any case where the plat officer does not summarily deny the application, the application shall be referred to the board of trustees or the plan commission, as required by the Code, and the applicant shall be required to establish grounds warranting further consideration of the merits of its application prior to being allowed to proceed further with said second application. Unless such grounds are established, the second application may be summarily dismissed for such failure. 
(c)  Exceptions. Whether or not grounds are stated, any such second application filed more than one year after the final denial of a prior application shall be processed as though no prior application had been filed. The application shall, however, be required to place in the record all evidence available concerning changes of condition or new facts that have developed since the denial of the first application. In the absence of such evidence, it shall be presumed that no new facts exist to support the new application that did not exist at the time of the denial of the first application. 
(Ord. No. 98-O-49, § 2, 5-26-98) 
Secs. 22-41-22-50. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - APPLICATION REQUIREMENTS 

Sec. 22-51. - Development applications. 
    An application for approval of a development shall be filed with the plat officer on a form provided by the village and shall include (i) payment of the fees and escrow deposits required in the annual fee ordinance, (ii) all information required for site plan approval, as applicable, by section 16-10 of the Libertyville Zoning Code, and (iii) all information, plans and specifications required for issuance of a building permit for the proposed development. 
(Ord. No. 96-0-14, § 2(22-300), 3-14-96) 
Sec. 22-52. - Consolidation plat applications. 
    An application for approval of a plat of consolidation shall be filed with the plat officer on a form provided by the village and shall have the form and content provided in section 22-56 of this chapter for final plats of subdivision; provided, however, that the signature blocks for village officials, as required by subsection 22-56(18), shall be in a form satisfactory to the plat officer and shall read substantially as follows: 
This plat has been reviewed in accordance with the procedures and standards required by the Libertyville Subdivision Code and has been found to be in compliance with such procedures and standards. 
Such applications shall be accompanied by payment of the fees and escrow deposits required in the annual fee ordinance. 
(Ord. No. 96-0-14, § 2(22-301), 3-14-96; Ord. No. 96-O-64, § 2, 12-10-96; Ord. No. 97-O-29, § 20, 4-22-97) 
Sec. 22-53. - Preliminary plat applications. 
    An application for approval of a preliminary plat of subdivision shall be filed with the plat officer on a form provided by the village, shall have the form and content provided in section 22-54 of this chapter, and shall include, without limitation, the following: 
(1)  Payment of the fees and escrow deposits required in the annual fee ordinance. 
(2)  Names and addresses of all owners of record of the property, of all beneficial owners of any land trust, of all consultants who will be involved in the subdivision review process, and of the developer. 
(3)  Names and addresses of all owners of property located within two hundred fifty (250) feet of the property to be subdivided. 
(4)  The permanent real estate index numbers of the property to be subdivided. 
(5)  Copies of all applications to other agencies having jurisdiction over the subdivision. 
(6)  One copy of the preliminary plat on mylar and twenty-six (26) paper prints of the preliminary plat, not exceeding twenty-four (24) inches by thirty-six (36) inches in size and drawn to a stated scale of not less than one (1) inch equals one hundred (100) feet nor more than one (1) inch equals twenty (20) feet. 
(Ord. No. 96-0-14, § 2(22-302), 3-14-96) 
Sec. 22-54. - Form and contents of preliminary plat. 
    Every preliminary plat of subdivision shall include or be accompanied by the following information: 
(1)  A vicinity map. 
(2)  The proposed name of the subdivision. 
(3)  The location of the subject property by township, section, town and range, or by other legal description. 
(4)  The north point. 
(5)  Preliminary engineering plans for all required public improvements in accordance with section 22-104 of this chapter. 
(6)  The location of existing streets, sidewalks and other public ways, including width (in feet), sewers, water mains, culverts, gas, electric, telephone facilities, and all other existing man-made improvements within the tract, indicating pipe sizes, grades, manholes and exact location. 
(7)  The location of existing wells, septic fields and similar facilities. 
(8)  The layout of proposed streets, street widths (in feet), street names, crosswalks and easements. 
(9)  The location of all proposed utilities necessary to serve the proposed subdivision and the layout of all easements to serve the utilities. Utility easements shall be not less than fifteen (15) feet centered on side lot lines and twenty (20) feet centered on rear lot lines, and shall be dedicated across lots where required. Such easements shall be platted to achieve continuity within the subdivision and, where possible, with easements on property abutting the subdivision. All wires, cables, pipes, conduit and similar improvements shall be shown as installed underground. All service equipment and improvements shall be shown as installed along rear lot lines to the fullest extent practicable. 
(10)  All information required by the village's stormwater management ordinance. 
(11)  A tree survey indicating the location, species and condition of all trees with a caliper of six (6) inches or larger. 
(12)  The description and location of all existing survey monuments erected in the subdivision. 
(13)  The boundary line of the proposed subdivision indicated by solid heavy line, and the total approximate acreage encompassed thereby. 
(14)  The boundary lines of adjacent tracts of unsubdivided or subdivided land. 
(15)  Existing topography on the property and within twenty-five (25) feet of the proposed subdivision, with contour intervals shown at least for at least every one (1) foot. 
(16)  Signature blocks for approval signatures in a form approved by the plat officer. 
(17)  The identity of parcels of land intended to be dedicated or temporarily reserved for public use or set aside for use in common of property owners in the subdivision. 
(18)  The layout, numbers, are (in square feet) and dimensions (in feet) of lots. 
(19)  The existing and, if different, proposed zoning of the proposed subdivision and the existing zoning of adjacent tracts. 
(20)  The identification of all proposed uses of the property to be subdivided. 
(21)  Indication of proposed phases or sections within the subdivision and the order of site development. 
(22)  Minimum building setback lines, showing dimensions. 
(23)  Minimum lot areas, widths and depths proposed for all lots and the minimum standards required by the Libertyville Zoning Code or other applicable zoning regulations. 
(24)  Such other information as the plat officer, the plan commission, or the board of trustees may require at any time. 
(Ord. No. 96-0-14, § 2(22-303), 3-14-96) 
Sec. 22-55. - Final plat applications. 
    An application for approval of a final plat of subdivision shall be filed with the plat officer on a form provided by the village, shall have the form and content provided in section 22-56 of this chapter, and shall include, without limitation, the following: 
(1)  A copy of the approved preliminary plat. 
(2)  Payment of the fees and escrow deposits required in any related agreement or in the annual fee ordinance. 
(3)  Copies of all applications to other agencies having jurisdiction over the subdivision. 
(4)  One (1) copy of the final plat on floppy disk in an electronic format compatible with the village's computer system, one (1) copy of the final plat on mylar, and twenty-six (26) paper prints of the final plat not exceeding twenty-four (24) inches by thirty-six (36) inches in size and drawn to a stated scale of not less than one (1) inch equals one hundred (100) feet nor more than one (1) inch equals twenty (20) feet. 
(Ord. No. 96-0-14, § 2(22-304), 3-14-96) 
Sec. 22-56. - Form and contents of final plat. 
    Every final plat of subdivision shall include or be accompanied by the following information: 
(1)  The name of subdivision. 
(2)  The location of the subject property by township, section, town and range, or by other legal description. 
(3)  The north point. 
(4)  The boundary of plat, based on an accurate traverse, with angular and lineal dimensions. 
(5)  Final engineering plans for all required public improvements, in accordance with section 22-104 of this chapter. 
(6)  The exact locations and widths of all existing and proposed streets and sidewalks within and adjacent to the subject property, the exact location and widths of all crosswalks, and the names of all streets, which names shall have been approved by the fire marshal and the postmaster. 
(7)  True angles and distances to the nearest established street lines or official monuments (not fewer than three), all of which shall be accurately located and described in the plat. 
(8)  Municipal, township, county or section lines accurately tied to the lines of the subdivision by distances and angles. 
(9)  Radii, internal angles, points and curvature, tangent bearings and lengths of all arcs. 
(10)  All easements for rights-of-way provided for public services or utilities, and delineation of all overland drainage paths with appropriate reservation of areas to contain them. 
(11)  Statements granting necessary easements to the village and to appropriate utility companies for rights-of-way and for public service or utilities, in forms specified by the village. 
(12)  All lot numbers and lines, with accurate dimensions in feet and hundredths. 
(13)  Accurate outlines and legal descriptions of all areas to be dedicated or reserved for public use, with the purpose or purposes indicated thereon, and of every area to be reserved by deed covenant for common uses of all property owners. 
(14)  Minimum building setback lines accurately shown with dimensions. 
(15)  Protective covenants, in a form acceptable to the plat officer, if necessary. 
(16)  Certification by a registered surveyor to the effect that the plat represents a survey made by him or her, that the monuments and markers shown thereon exist as located, and that all dimensional and geodetic details are correct, in a form provided by the village. 
(17)  Notarized certification, by all property owners and by any mortgage holder of record, of the adoption of the plat and the dedication of streets and other public areas, in a form provided by the village. 
(18)  Signature blocks and certifications, in forms provided by the village, for the following persons: 
Village president 
Village treasurer 
Village engineer 
Plan commission chairperson 
County clerk 
County highway department, if necessary 
State department of transportation, if necessary 
Drainage design engineer, if necessary 
(19)  Such other information as the plat officer, the plan commission, or the board of trustees may require at any time. 
(Ord. No. 96-0-14, § 2(22-305), 3-14-96) 
Sec. 22-57. - Plats of vacation applications; form and contents. 
    An application for approval of a plat of vacation shall be filed with the plat officer on a form provided by the village. The plat of vacation shall be prepared in accordance with the requirements of Section 6 of the Illinois Plat Act, 765 ILCS 205/6, and shall have the form and content provided in section 22-56 of this chapter for final plats of subdivision. 
(Ord. No. 96-0-14, § 2(22-306), 3-14-96) 
Secs. 22-58-22-70. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE IV. - DEVELOPMENT AND SUBDIVISION REVIEW PROCESS 

Sec. 22-71. - Plat officer review of developments and consolidation plats. 
    The plat officer shall review every application for approval of a development or a plat of consolidation. 
(1)  Development review; action. The plat officer shall review an application for approval of a development for compliance with all requirements of law and to determine whether subdivision approvals, public improvements, or land dedications are required for such development. The plat officer, within forty-five (45) days after receipt of all required information and payment of all required fees, shall approve the application, shall approve the application with written conditions, shall disapprove the application in writing stating the reasons for such disapproval, or shall refer the application to the board of trustees for review as provided in subsection (6) of this section. The failure of the plat officer to act within the time period specified in this subsection, or such further time to which the developer may agree, shall be deemed to be a decision of the plat officer denying the development application. 
(2)  Effect of development approval. Approval of the plat officer of a development shall not entitle the developer to any other approval or issuance of any permit until after all of the standards and procedures for such other approval or issuance of such permit have been satisfied. 
(3)  Engineering plans and development agreement for certain developments. 
a.  Except as specifically provided otherwise by the board of trustees, no development for which public improvements are required shall be approved by the plat officer until after the final engineering plans for the development have been approved in accordance with the provisions of sections 22-103 and 22-104 of this chapter. 
b.  Except as specifically provided otherwise by the board of trustees, no development for which public improvements are required shall be approved by the plat officer until after the developer has entered into a development agreement with the village in accordance with the provisions of section 22-604 of this chapter. 
(4)  Consolidation plat review; action. The plat officer shall review an application for approval of a plat of consolidation for compliance with all requirements of law. The plat officer, within forty-five (45) days after receipt of all required information and payment of all required fees, shall approve the application, shall disapprove the application in writing stating the reasons for such disapproval, or shall refer the application to the board of trustees for review as provided in subsection (6) of this section. The failure of the plat officer to act within the time period specified in this subsection, or such further time to which the developer may agree, shall be deemed to be a decision of the plat officer denying the application for consolidation plat approval. Every written disapproval by the plat officer of a consolidation plat shall include a statement of the reason or reasons for the disapproval and the changes required to the plat, or additional information or other matters required, before the plat may be approved. Upon approval of the consolidation plat, the plat officer shall cause the appropriate signatures of village officials to be affixed to such plat. 
(5)  Effect of consolidation plat approval. Approval of the plat officer of a plat of consolidation shall not entitle the developer to any other approval or issuance of any permit until after all of the standards and procedures for such other approval or issuance of such permit have been satisfied. 
(6)  Referral to board of trustees by plat officer. The plat officer may, in the exercise of his or her sole discretion, refer any application for approval of a development or of a plat of consolidation to the board of trustees for review, if the plat officer determines that such application involves matters or raises issues appropriate for board of trustees analysis. Any application so referred to the board of trustees shall be reviewed by the board of trustees in the same manner as final plats of subdivisions provided in subsection 22-74(c) of this chapter; provided, however, that the board of trustees, in the exercise of its sole discretion, may refer any such application to the plan commission for its review and recommendation. 
(Ord. No. 96-0-14, § 2(22-400), 3-14-96; Ord. No. 96-O-64, §§ 3, 4, 12-10-96) 
Sec. 22-72. - Preliminary plat review. 
(a)  Filing; deadline; plat officer general review. 
(1)  An application for approval of a preliminary plat of subdivision shall be filed with the plat officer, in complete and proper form, at least thirty (30) days before the meeting of the plan commission at which it is to be considered. 
(2)  The plat officer shall review the preliminary plat for general completeness, for compliance with requirements of law, including without limitation the application requirements established in article III of this chapter, and for technical accuracy. Within fifteen (15) days after the date of filing of the application has been accepted for processing or that the application may not be processed because of deficiencies or inaccuracies in it. Every deficient or inaccurate application shall be returned to the developer. If the plat officer determines that the application should be accepted for processing, then the plat officer shall refer the application to all appropriate staff members and committees for review. 
(b)  Notice of public meeting. After receipt of all required information, payment of all required fees, and satisfactory general review pursuant to subsection (a) of this section, the plat officer shall cause notice to be given of a public meeting of the plan commission for review of the preliminary plat. Such notice shall (i) include the date, time and place of the public meeting, (ii) include a general description of the matters to be considered, (iii) include the address or particular location of the subject property, (iv) be published not fewer than fifteen (15) days nor more than thirty (30) days before the public meeting in a newspaper having general circulation in the village, and (v) be given by hand delivery or first class mail to the developer. 
(c)  Action by the plan commission. The plan commission shall conduct a public meeting to review the preliminary plat in accordance with the notice published pursuant to subsection (b) of this section. Within forty-five (45) days after the conclusion of the public meeting, but in no event more than ninety (90) days after the date of proper filing of the application including all required items of supporting data, the plan commission shall recommend whether the preliminary plat should be approved, approved with modifications or conditions, or disapproved, and shall transmit such recommendation to the board of trustees. A recommendation for disapproval shall specify with particularity the reasons for disapproval and the aspects of the preliminary plat that fail to conform to the requirements of law. The plan commission may recommend approval of a plat subject to certain conditions or modifications as are deemed necessary in the interests and needs of the community. The failure of the plan commission to act within the time period specified in this subsection, or such further time to which the developer may agree, shall be deemed to be a recommendation of the plan commission to disapprove the preliminary plat. 
(d)  Action by board of trustees. The board of trustees, within thirty (30) days after its first regular meeting following the action of the plan commission pursuant to subsection (c) of this section, shall disapprove the preliminary plat or shall approve it by ordinance or resolution duly adopted. If the board of trustees disapproves the preliminary plat, then the plat officer shall notify the applicant in writing of the reasons stated for such disapproval. The failure of the board of trustees to act within the time period specified in this subsection, or such further time to which the developer may agree, shall be deemed to be a decision of the board of trustees disapproving the preliminary plat. 
(e)  Effect of approval. The approval of a preliminary plat by the board of trustees is strictly tentative in nature, involving merely the general acceptability of the layout as submitted. Approval of the preliminary plat shall be deemed only to be permission for the developer to prepare a final plat of subdivision including detailed plans and specifications for the subdivision and public improvements in accordance with the preliminary plat and within the requirements of this chapter. Approval of a preliminary plat shall not entitle the developer to any other approval or issuance of any permit until after all of the standards and procedures for such other approval or issuance of a permit have been satisfied. 
(f)  Limitation on preliminary plat approval. Every approval by the board of trustees of a preliminary plat of subdivision shall be effective for a maximum period of twelve (12) months after the date of approval unless, pursuant to a written application therefor filed by the developer before the expiration of the preliminary plat approval, the board of trustees grants an extension of that twelve-month period. If, within the twelve-month period, no extension of time has been granted by the board of trustees and no application for approval of a final plat of subdivision has been filed with the plat officer, then the developer must resubmit an application for approval of a preliminary plat for full review of the plan commission and board of trustees. 
(Ord. No. 96-0-14, § 2(22-401), 3-14-96; Ord. No. 96-O-64, § 5, 12-10-96) 
Sec. 22-73. - Optional submission of final plat for simultaneous review. 
    The developer, at the developer's option, may submit a final plat of subdivision pursuant to the requirements of article III of this chapter simultaneously with the submission of the preliminary plat of subdivision, if the proposed subdivision meets all of the following qualifications: 
(1)  The proposed subdivision includes three (3) platted lots or fewer; 
(2)  The proposed subdivision does not require or create any new public rights-of-way or easements for access; and 
(3)  The proposed subdivision requires no extensions of public utilities and no new public facilities, except street trees and other landscaping. 
In the event of a simultaneous submission, the developer shall comply with all provisions of this chapter applicable to submission of the preliminary plat of subdivision and to submission of the final plat of subdivision. The plan commission and the board of trustees shall consider such plans simultaneously and shall grant or deny final plat of subdivision approval in accordance with the provisions of section 22-74 of this chapter. 
(Ord. No. 96-0-14, § 2(22-402), 3-14-96) 
Sec. 22-74. - Final plat review. 
(a)  Filing; deadline; plat officer general review. 
(1)  An application for approval of a final plat of subdivision shall be filed with the plat officer, in complete and proper form, at least fifteen (15) days before the meeting of the plan commission at which it is to be considered. 
(2)  The plat officer shall review the final plat for general completeness, for compliance with requirements of law, including without limitation the application requirements established in article III of this chapter, for compliance with the approved preliminary plat and any modifications and conditions imposed on the preliminary plat, and for technical accuracy. With ten (10) days after the date of filing of the application, the plat officer shall notify the developer either that the application has been accepted for processing or that the application may not be processed because of deficiencies or inaccuracies in it. Every deficient or inaccurate application shall be returned to the developer. If the plat officer determines that all required information has been received, that all required fees have been paid, and that the application should be accepted for processing, then the plat officer shall refer the application to all appropriate staff members and committees for review. 
(b)  Action by the plan commission. The plan commission shall conduct a public meeting to review the final plat. Within fifteen (15) days after the conclusion of the public meeting, the plan commission shall recommend whether the final plat should be approved, approved with modifications or conditions, or disapproved, and shall transmit such recommendation to the board of trustees. A recommendation for disapproval shall specify with particularity the reasons for disapproval and the aspects of the final plat that fail to conform to the requirements of law. The plan commission may recommend approval of a final plat subject to certain conditions or modifications as are deemed necessary in the interests and needs of the community. The failure of the plan commission to act within the time period specified in this subsection, or such further time to which the developer may agree, shall be deemed to be a recommendation of the plan commission to disapprove the final plat. 
(c)  Action by board of trustees. The board of trustees, within sixty (60) days from the date of filing by the applicant of the last required document, plan, agreement, or other paper or within sixty (60) days from the date of filing of the application for final approval of the plat, whichever is later, or any mutually agreeable later time, shall disapprove the final plat or shall approve it by ordinance or resolution duly adopted. If the board of trustees disapproves the final plat, then the plat officer shall notify the applicant in writing of the reasons stated for such disapproval. The failure of the board of trustees to act within the time period specified in this subsection, or such further time to which the developer may agree, shall be deemed to be a decision of the board of trustees disapproving the final plat. 
(d)  Final engineering plans and development agreement required. 
(1)  Except as specifically provided otherwise by the board of trustees, no final plat of subdivision shall be approved by the board of trustees until after the final engineering plans for the subdivision have been approved in accordance with the provisions of sections 22-103 and 22-104 of this chapter. 
(2)  Except as specifically provided otherwise by the board of trustees, no final plat of subdivision for which public improvements are required shall be approved by the board of trustees until after the developer has entered into a development agreement with the village in accordance with the provisions of section 22-105 of this chapter. 
(e)  Effect of approval. Approval of a final plat shall not entitle the developer to any other approval or issuance of any permit until after all of the standards and procedures for such other approval or issuance of a permit have been satisfied. 
(Ord. No. 96-0-14, § 2(22-403), 3-14-96; Ord. No. 96-O-64, § 6, 12-10-96) 
Sec. 22-75. - Plat of vacation review. 
(a)  Filing; deadline; plat officer general review. 
(1)  An application for approval of a plat of vacation shall be filed with the plat officer, in complete and proper form, at least thirty (30) days before the meeting of the board of trustees at which it is to be considered. 
(2)  The plat officer shall review the final plat for general completeness, for compliance with requirements of law, including without limitation the application requirements established in article III of this chapter, and for technical accuracy. With fifteen (15) days after the date of filing of the application, the plat officer shall notify the developer either that the application has been accepted for processing or that the application may not be processed because of deficiencies or inaccuracies in it. Every deficient or inaccurate application shall be returned to the developer. If the plat officer determines that the application should be accepted for processing, then the plat officer shall refer the application to all appropriate staff members and committees for review. 
(b)  Notice of public meeting. After receipt of all required information, payment of all required fees, and satisfactory general review pursuant to subsection (a) of this section, the plat officer shall cause notice to be given of a public meeting of the board of trustees for review of the plat. Such notice shall be given in the same form and manner as provided in subsection 22-72(b) of this chapter. 
(c)  Action by board of trustees. The board of trustees, in the exercise of its sole discretion, may refer any application for plat of vacation approval to the plan commission for its review and recommendation, in which case the plan commission shall review such plat in the manner provided in subsection 22-74(b) of this chapter. The board of trustees, within thirty (30) days after the public meeting or, if the application has been referred to the plan commission, the date of action by the plan commission, shall disapprove the plat or shall approve it by ordinance or resolution duly adopted. If the board of trustees disapproves the plat, then the plat officer shall notify the applicant in writing of the reasons stated for such disapproval. The failure of the board of trustees to act within the time period specified in this subsection, or such further time to which the developer may agree, shall be deemed to be a decision of the board of trustees disapproving the plat. 
(d)  Effect of approval. Approval of a plat of vacation shall not entitle the developer to any other approval or issuance of any permit until after all of the standards and procedures for such other approval or issuance of a permit have been satisfied. 
(Ord. No. 96-0-14, § 2(22-404), 3-14-96) 
Secs. 22-76-22-85. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE V. - DESIGN STANDARDS 

Sec. 22-86. - Preservation of natural features. 
    Every development and subdivision shall be designed to preserve to the fullest extent possible all natural features of the land such as large trees and water courses; all historic areas or features; and the like, which add to the attractiveness or environmental or historic value of the land and the proposed development or subdivision. Every development and subdivision shall satisfy all requirements of law applicable to stormwater management, tree preservation and other natural resource protections. Every developer shall be required to dedicate, or record restrictive covenants against, all land as required or necessary to protect such natural and historic features. 
(Ord. No. 96-0-14, § 2(22-500), 3-14-96) 
Sec. 22-87. - Street standards. 
    Every plat of subdivision shall provide by dedication for streets and public rights-of-way sufficient to serve all property within the subdivision. Such streets and rights-of-way shall: 
(1)  Meet all village design standards and the requirements of section 22-109 of this chapter; 
(2)  Conform to all requirements of the village's official comprehensive plan; and 
(3)  Be designed to standards appropriate to the proposed use of the land to be served by them and to fully protect public safety and convenience. 
(Ord. No. 96-0-14, § 2(22-501), 3-14-96) 
Sec. 22-88. - Block standards. 
    Blocks shall be arranged to conform to all village design standards. If a block exceeds eight hundred (800) feet in length, then the village may require crosswalks, bike paths, additional sidewalks, emergency access easements, and similar improvements to facilitate safe and convenient pedestrian movement and emergency vehicle access. 
(Ord. No. 96-0-14, § 2(22-502), 3-14-96) 
Sec. 22-89. - Lot standards. 
(a)  Compliance with requirements of law. All lots shall comply with all requirements of law. 
(b)  Minimum lot dimensions. All lots shall have at least the minimum lot dimensions required by the Libertyville Zoning Code for the zoning district in which the property is zoned. Lots lying outside the village's corporate limits shall have at least the minimum lot dimensions required by the Libertyville Zoning Code for the zoning district most closely related to the use of the property, as determined by the plat officer. 
(c)  Side lines. Side lot lines shall be as close as practicable to right angles with, or radial to, the street line. 
(d)  Frontage. All lots shall have frontage on an improved public street. 
(e)  Through lots. Through lots shall not be permitted; provided, however, that reverse frontage lots may be permitted where lots back up on a major thoroughfare so long as vehicular access to the major thoroughfare from such lots is prohibited. 
(f)  Unsuitable land. No lot shall be created that includes lands subject to flooding, topographically unsuitable land, or other land whose use may increase the threat of flooding, aggravated erosion or other danger to public health or property. 
(Ord. No. 96-0-14, § 2(22-503), 3-14-96) 
Sec. 22-90. - Monuments. 
    Permanent monuments shall be placed at each corner or angle on the outside boundary of each lot. Each monument shall be constructed of concrete, shall have the dimensions six (6) inches × six (6) inches × thirty (30) inches, and shall have an iron pipe cast in the center. Pipes or other physical markers shall be placed at each intersection of street center lines. All U.S., state, county or other official benchmarks, monuments or triangulation stations in or adjacent to the property shall be preserved in precise position. 
(Ord. No. 96-0-14, § 2(22-504), 3-14-96) 
Secs. 22-91-22-100. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE VI. - PUBLIC IMPROVEMENTS 

Sec. 22-101. - Improvements required. 
(a)  Subdivisions. Every subdivision shall be improved by the developer with the public improvements set forth in this article VI and with all such other improvements as may be necessary to serve the subdivision, as determined by the village engineer. All such improvements shall be designed and constructed by the developer in accordance with village design standards, the provisions of this chapter, and other requirements of law, all as approved by the village engineer. 
(b)  Developments. Every development shall be improved by the developer with all public improvements as may be necessary to serve the development, as determined by the village engineer. All such improvements shall be designed and constructed by the developer in accordance with village design standards, the provisions of this chapter, and other requirements of law, all as approved by the village engineer. 
(Ord. No. 96-0-14, § 2(22-600), 3-14-96) 
Sec. 22-102. - Permits required; exception for certain preliminary site work. 
    No construction work of any kind, including grading, shall be performed on any proposed street, sewer, water main or other public improvement without all applicable permits and approvals, including when required final plat approval, having first been obtained from the village. Notwithstanding this requirement, the board of trustees may grant authorization for preliminary site work, including but not limited to earth moving, prior to the approval of final engineering plans and issuance of all required permits and approvals; provided, however, that any such preliminary site work, regardless of board of trustees approval therefor, shall be undertaken entirely and solely at the developer's own risk that final permits and approvals shall be issued therefor. If such final permits and approvals are not so issued, then the developer shall be responsible for restoring all property disturbed by such preliminary site work to the condition it was in prior to such preliminary site work unless otherwise specifically excused in writing by the board of trustees. 
(Ord. No. 96-0-14, § 2(22-601), 3-14-96) 
Sec. 22-103. - Engineering plans required. 
(a)  General requirement; standards. The developer shall submit five (5) printed sets of complete engineering plans for all required public improvements and one (1) copy of such plans on floppy disk in an electronic format compatible with the village's computer system. The engineering plans shall be prepared in accordance with requirements of law, including without limitation village design standards, the standards and procedures required by this chapter, and all applicable standards of other agencies with jurisdiction. 
(b)  Distribution of plans. The village engineer shall cause the engineering plans to be distributed to all village officials and other agencies with jurisdiction over any aspect of such plans. 
(Ord. No. 96-0-14, § 2(22-602), 3-14-96) 
Sec. 22-104. - Engineering plan review. 
(a)  Submission of preliminary engineering plans. For all subdivisions and developments requiring or proposing public improvements, preliminary engineering plans shall be submitted to the plat officer simultaneously with the application for approval of the preliminary plat of subdivision or the development. Such plans shall be accompanied by payment of all fees and escrow deposits required by the annual fee ordinance. 
(b)  Preliminary engineering plan review. The village engineer shall review all preliminary engineering plans to determine that they are in substantial compliance with all requirements of law. Such review shall be completed with forty-five (45) days after submission of the complete plans and payment of all required fees and escrow deposits. The village engineer may approve the plans, may approve the plans subject to modifications or conditions, or may disapprove the plans in writing delivered to the developer stating the reasons for such disapproval. The failure of the village engineer to act within the time period specified in this subsection, or such further time to which the developer may agree, shall be deemed to be a decision of the village engineer disapproving the plans. No development or preliminary plat of subdivision shall be approved by the plat officer or the board of trustees until after approval by the village engineer of the preliminary engineering plans for such subdivision or development. 
(c)  Submission of final engineering plans. Final engineering plans shall be submitted to the plat officer at any time after approval of the development or of the preliminary plat of subdivision but in no event later than the time of filing, in the case of a development, of an application for a building permit or, in the case of a subdivision, of an application for approval of the final plat of subdivision. Such plans shall be accompanied by payment of all fees and escrow deposits required by the annual fee ordinance. 
(d)  Final engineering plan review. The village engineer shall review all final engineering plans to determine that they are in compliance with all requirements of law and, in the case of a subdivision, in substantial compliance with the approved preliminary plat of subdivision. Final engineering plans that are not in substantial compliance with the approved preliminary plat of subdivision shall not be approved until after they have been revised to be brought into such substantial compliance or until the preliminary plat of subdivision has been amended in a form approved by the village and the final engineering plans thus are in substantial compliance with the amended plat. The village engineer shall complete his or her review within forty-five (45) days after submission of the complete final engineering plans and payment of all required fees and escrow deposits. The village engineer may approve the plans, approve the plans subject to modifications or conditions, or disapprove the plans in writing stating the reasons for such disapproval. The failure of the village engineer to act within the time specified in this subsection, or such further time to which the developer may agree, shall be deemed to be a decision of the village engineer disapproving the final engineering plans. 
(e)  Development agreement required before approval of engineering plans. Except as provided in subsection 22-71(3) of this chapter for developments or in subsection 22-74(d) of this chapter for final plats of subdivision, no final engineering plans shall be approved for a development or a subdivision requiring public improvements until after the developer has entered into a development agreement with the village pursuant to section 22-105 of this chapter. 
(f)  Effect of engineering plan disapproval. Except as provided in subsection 22-71(3) of this chapter for developments or in subsection 22-74(d) of this chapter for final plats of subdivision, no development or final plat of subdivision shall be approved in the absence of approved final engineering plans. 
(g)  Inspection fees. After approval of final engineering plans and prior to issuance of any permit authorizing commencement of construction of any public improvement, the developer shall pay to the village a fee for inspection of construction of the public improvements in the amount established in the annual fee ordinance. 
(h)  Record ("as-built") plans. After completion of construction of the public improvements and approval thereof by the village, but prior to acceptance, when appropriate, of any of the public improvements by the village, the developer shall file with the village two (2) sets of record ("as-built") engineering plans revised to reflect all improvements as constructed. Such record plans also shall be submitted to the village in a computerized format as specified by the village engineer. All elements of the record plans that have been revised from the approved final engineering plans shall be noted as revisions on the final engineering plans and signed and sealed by the engineer. 
(Ord. No. 96-0-14, § 2(22-603), 3-14-96; Ord. No. O-97-29, § 21, 4-22-97) 
Sec. 22-105. - Development agreement. 
    Unless the board of trustees has specifically determined pursuant to subsection 22-71(3) or subsection 22-74(d) of this chapter that no development agreement shall be required, the developer of a development or a subdivision requiring or providing public improvements shall enter into a development agreement in a form approved by the village providing for the construction of all required public improvements and other improvements necessary to serve the subdivision or development. The development agreement shall include, among other things, the following provisions: 
(1)  A description of the required improvements. 
(2)  A proposed schedule for installation of the required improvements, including a description of improvements that must be completed prior to issuance of a building permit for any individual lot and that must be completed prior to issuance of any certificate of occupancy. 
(3)  The estimated cost of the improvements, in an amount approved by the village engineer. 
(4)  The performance and maintenance security required by article VII of this chapter. 
(5)  A description of, and procedure for, required dedications of property or improvements. 
(6)  Covenants, restrictions and easements necessary to protect, preserve and maintain the improvements and other public land and facilities. 
(7)  The developer's agreement to pay required fees, donations and costs, including, but not limited to, all legal fees incurred by the village in connection with the negotiation and preparation of any development agreement which may be required in connection with such subdivision or development. 
(8)  Acknowledgements and indemnifications from the developer. 
(Ord. No. 96-0-14, § 2(22-604), 3-14-96; Ord. No. 07-O-70, § 3, 10-9-07) 
Sec. 22-106. - Water service. 
(a)  Type of service required. Each subdivision within the corporate limits of the village shall be connected to the village's water supply system. Each subdivision outside of the village's corporate limits shall be connected to a public water supply system unless an adequate underground water supply is readily available and sufficient to serve the entire subdivision. Each development shall provide for water service in accordance with all requirements of law. 
(b)  System standards. Every water distribution system shall be constructed in accordance with requirements of law, including without limitation village design standards, and in such a manner as to provide each lot and principal building with a separate service connection. Water mains shall be of a size determined to be appropriate by the village engineer based on hydraulic studies, required fire flows, land uses, compatibility with the village's current water system and future needs, and other relevant factors, but shall not be less than eight (8) inches in diameter for single-family detached residential uses nor less than twelve (12) inches in diameter for every other use. Water mains shall extend to the extremities of streets or easements which are served by the water mains and shall be arranged to avoid dead ends. Shut-off valves shall be provided at each branch main connection and elsewhere as determined by the village engineer to be required to permit adequate sectionalizing for maintenance and repair purposes. A building service connection shall be provided for each lot and principal building and shall extend to a point within one (1) foot of the property line of the property being served. Such building service connection shall be installed prior to installation of any pavement over the area of such connection. 
(c)  Fire hydrants. Fire hydrants shall be installed throughout all additions to the water system in accordance with village design standards. 
(Ord. No. 96-0-14, § 2(22-605), 3-14-96) 
Sec. 22-107. - Sanitary sewer service. 
(a)  Type of service required. Each subdivision within the corporate limits of the village shall be connected to the village's sanitary sewage transmission system. Each subdivision outside of the village's corporate limits shall be connected to a public sanitary sewage transmission and treatment system unless all agencies with jurisdiction determine that no such connection is required. Each development shall provide for sanitary sewer service in accordance with all requirements of law. 
(b)  System standards. Every sanitary sewer system shall be constructed in accordance with requirements of law, including without limitation village design standards. Sewer mains, with separate building service stubs for each lot and principal building, shall be installed prior to construction of street improvements. Sewer mains shall be sized in accordance with village design standards and in accordance with the capacity requirements of the village's sanitary sewage transmission system as determined by the village engineer, but shall be not less than eight (8) inches in diameter. Building service stubs shall be sized according to the requirements of the use being served, as determined by the village engineer; provided, however, that service stubs shall be not less than six (6) inches in diameter. Building service stubs shall extend to a point within one (1) foot of the property line of the property being served. 
(c)  Combined systems prohibited. No sanitary sewer system shall be connected to or combined in any way with a storm sewer system. 
(Ord. No. 96-0-14, § 2(22-605), 3-14-96) 
Sec. 22-108. - Stormwater drainage and storm sewers. 
(a)  System standards. Stormwater management systems shall be designed and installed by the developer in accordance with all requirements of law, including without limitation village design standards and the village's stormwater management ordinance. 
(b)  Inlets. Stormwater inlets shall be placed in street gutters at all street intersections and elsewhere as determined by the village engineer based on an analysis of the terrain. 
(c)  Stubs. Building service stubs shall be installed to receive sub-soil drain pump discharge from each building and shall connect to a storm sewer within the drainage system of the subdivision or development. 
(Ord. No. 96-0-14, § 2(22-607), 3-14-96) 
Sec. 22-109. - Streets. 
(a)  Street classifications; geometric standards: 
Geometric

(b)  Pavement widths. All streets shall be improved with paved roadways to an overall width as follows:

(c)  Pavement materials. Roadway pavements shall be designed and constructed in accordance with village design standards, including one of the methods specified in the following table: 
Street Classification
