    A grantee that desires to renew its franchise under this chapter shall, not more than two hundred forty (240) days nor less than one hundred fifty (150) days before expiration of the current franchise, file an application with the village for renewal of its franchise which shall include the following information: 
(a)  The information required pursuant to section 22.5-42 of this chapter; and 
(b)  Any information required pursuant to the franchise agreement between the village and the grantee. 
(Ord. No. 97-O-47, § 2, 6-10-97) 
Sec. 22.5-54. - Renewal determinations. 
    Within one hundred fifty (150) days after receiving a properly completed application under section 22.5-53 of this chapter, or such additional time to which the applicant and the village shall mutually agree, the village shall issue a written determination granting or denying the renewal application in whole or in part. If the renewal application is denied, the written determination shall include the reasons for non-renewal. The village's determination shall be based on the following standards. 
(a)  The financial and technical ability of the applicant; 
(b)  The legal ability of the applicant; 
(c)  The continuing capacity of the public ways to accommodate the applicant's existing facilities; 
(d)  The applicant's compliance with the requirements of this chapter and the franchise agreement; 
(e)  Applicable federal, state, and local telecommunications laws, rules, and policies; and 
(f)  Such other factors as may demonstrate that the continued grant to use the public ways will serve the community interest. 
(Ord. No. 97-O-47, § 2, 6-10-97) 
Sec. 22.5-55. - Obligation to cure as condition of renewal. 
    No franchise shall be renewed until any ongoing violations or defaults in the grantee's performance of the franchise agreement, or of the requirements of this chapter have been cured, or a plan detailing the corrective action to be taken by the grantee has been approved by the village. 
(Ord. No. 97-O-47, § 2, 6-10-97) 
Secs. 22.5-56-22.5-59. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE V. - CABLE FRANCHISES (Reserved) 

Secs. 22.5-60-22.5-89. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE VI. - COSTS; EXPENSES; FEES; OTHER PAYMENTS 

Sec. 22.5-90. - Registration fee. 
    Each application for registration as a telecommunications carrier or provider shall be accompanied by a fee in the amount established in the village's annual fee ordinance. 
(Ord. No. 97-O-47, § 2, 6-10-97) 
Sec. 22.5-91. - Application fees. 
(a)  Fees required. Each applicant for a license or franchise pursuant to article III or article IV of this chapter shall be subject to a non-refundable application and review fee in the amount established in the village's annual fee ordinance plus the actual cost incurred by the village in processing such application. Such fee shall be deposited with the village as part of the application required pursuant to section 22.5-22 or section 22.5-42 of this chapter. 
(b)  Recoverable costs. For purposes of calculating the fee due pursuant to subsection (a) above, the actual costs incurred by the village in processing an application shall be deemed to consist of the following items of direct and indirect expense: (1) professional and technical consultant services (direct cost) and (2) legal review, consultation, and advice (direct cost). 
(c)  Fee payment and escrow. 
1.  Initial payment and escrow. Every application filed pursuant to this chapter shall be accompanied by the required fee plus an additional amount for recoverable costs as provided in subsection (b) above, as fixed from time to time by administrative order of the village administrator, to be deposited in an application fee escrow. No interest shall be payable on any such escrow. 
2.  Charges against escrow. From the date of filing of any application pursuant to this chapter, the village shall maintain an accurate record of the actual costs, as hereinabove defined, of processing such application. The village administrator shall, from time to time, draw funds from the escrow account established for such application to pay such costs and shall transfer such funds to the appropriate village accounts. The administrator shall maintain an accurate record of all such drawings. 
(d)  Additional escrow deposits. Should the village administrator at any time determine that the escrow account established in connection with any application is, or is likely to become, insufficient to pay the actual costs of processing such application, the administrator shall inform the applicant of that fact and demand an additional deposit in an amount deemed by him to be sufficient to cover foreseeable additional costs. Unless and until such additional amount is deposited by the applicant, the village administrator may direct that processing of the application shall be suspended or terminated. 
(e)  Final settlement. As soon as reasonably feasible following final action on an application, the village administrator shall cause a final accounting to be made of the escrow deposits made in connection with such application and the actual cost of processing such application and shall make a final charge of such costs against such escrow deposits. A copy of the accounting shall be provided to the applicant. 
If the amount in the escrow account is insufficient to pay the total actual costs, a written demand for payment of the balance due shall be mailed to the applicant. If unused balance remains in the escrow account after paying the total actual costs, it shall be returned to the applicant. 
(f)  Condition of all applications, approvals, and permits; time periods. No application filed pursuant to this chapter shall be considered complete unless and until all fees and deposits due pursuant to this section have been paid. Every approval granted and every permit issued pursuant to this chapter shall, whether or not expressly so conditioned, be deemed to be conditioned upon payment of fees as required by this section. 
Where this chapter provides that the passage of time without decision or action shall be deemed an approval or a recommendation for approval, time periods shall be tolled during any period of non-payment, but shall otherwise continue to run. 
The failure to fully pay any such fee or deposit, when due, shall be grounds for refusing to process an application. 
(Ord. No. 97-O-47, § 2, 6-10-97) 
Sec. 22.5-92. - Annual fees. 
(a)  License. Each grantee of a license shall pay an annual license fee to the village as established in the village's annual fee ordinance, as reimbursement for the village's continuing costs in connection with reviewing, inspecting, and supervising the use and occupancy of the public ways on behalf of the public and existing and future users. 
(b)  Franchise. Each grantee of a franchise shall pay an annual franchise fee equal to five (5) percent of the grantee's gross revenue, as reimbursement for the village's costs in connection with reviewing, inspecting, and supervising the use and occupancy of the public ways on behalf of the public and existing and future users, and to support public, educational, and government access. 
The annual franchise fee shall be paid annually not later than ninety (90) days after the conclusion of grantee's fiscal year. Each annual franchise fee payment shall be accompanied by a report prepared in accordance with generally accepted accounting principles, in sufficient detail to show the gross revenues, by service category, for the fiscal year just concluded and the basis for the computation and other relevant facts. 
(c)  Other payments and compensation. The annual fee payments shall not be deemed to be a tax and shall be in addition to any and all taxes, fees, or charges that the grantee shall be required to pay to the village or to any other governmental authority. 
(Ord. No. 97-O-47, § 2, 6-10-97) 
Sec. 22.5-93. - Engineering review fee. 
    The grantee shall pay to the village, immediately after presentation of a written demand or demands therefor, all engineering fees in an amount equal to three and one-half (31/2) percent of the cost of any proposed construction, as such cost is reasonably determined by the village engineer, as compensation to the village for the review and processing of any and all plans for any construction of the telecommunications system including, without limitation, the review and processing of the preliminary plans and specifications and the final plans and specifications. 
(Ord. No. 97-O-47, § 2, 6-10-97) 
Sec. 22.5-94. - Municipal services. 
    If any portion of the telecommunications system is placed in any public way located adjacent to property on which a municipal building is located, then the grantee shall provide at a minimum, upon written request by the village at no cost to the village, and as additional compensation to the village for the license or franchise, such services to or on behalf of the village on which the village and the grantee may mutually agree. 
(Ord. No. 97-O-47, § 2, 6-10-97) 
Sec. 22.5-95. - Acceptance by the village. 
    The acceptance by the village of any payment shall not be construed as an accord by the village that the amount of such payment is the correct amount due from grantee pursuant to the license or franchise agreement entered into with the grantee, nor shall such acceptance of any payment be construed to be a release or waiver of any claim the village may have for further or additional sums due and payable pursuant to a license or franchise agreement. 
(Ord. No. 97-O-47, § 2, 6-10-97) 
Sec. 22.5-96. - No right of setoff. 
    All payments due to the village from a grantee pursuant to this chapter shall be paid without counterclaim, setoff, deduction, or defense. If the grantee does set off or deduct any amount from any such payment or otherwise reduces the amount due based on a counterclaim or defense, then the village shall have the right, without any liability to the grantee, its customers, or any third persons, to pursue any and all remedies available to it at law or in equity including, without limitation, revocation of the license or franchise. 
(Ord. No. 97-O-47, § 2, 6-10-97) 
Secs. 22.5-97-22.5-109. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE VII. - CONSTRUCTION STANDARDS 

Sec. 22.5-110. - Location of facilities. 
(a)  All telecommunications system facilities shall be installed underground in accordance with all village standards and specifications for public and private improvements, except in the following circumstances: 
1.  Electric distribution transformers, switchgear, and pedestals that are normally installed above ground may continue to be so installed, in accordance with accepted practices for underground distribution; 
2.  Temporary overhead facilities during periods of construction; 
3.  Service connectors and similar equipment normally attached to the outside wall of the premises they serve; and 
4.  Where the grantee can demonstrate that the telecommunications system facilities cannot be constructed underground and that existing utility poles are available and contain sufficient surplus space for such facilities. 
(b)  Whenever an existing utility conduit, duct, vault, or other existing utility facility can physically accommodate any cable, wire, or other facility, without substantial modification or expense to the grantee, then the grantee shall utilize such pole or other facility and shall not construct or install any new, different, or additional facilities. 
(Ord. No. 97-O-47, § 2, 6-10-97) 
Sec. 22.5-111. - Construction of telecommunications system. 
(a)  Plans and specifications. 
1.  Submission of preliminary plans and specifications. The grantee shall, within forty-five (45) days after the effective date of a license or franchise agreement, submit to the village engineer for review and comment six complete sets of preliminary plans and specifications which shall include, without limitation: 
(i)  A map in sufficient detail indicating (A) the proposed route for all facilities including, without limitation, detailed drawings of the location in each public way where such facilities are proposed to be placed underground and above ground; (B) all existing utilities in such public ways; (C) all trees, structures, improvements, and obstructions in such public ways; and (D) the names of owners of all properties, public or private, under, over, or across which the facilities are proposed to be constructed or installed. Such map also shall identify which trees, utility facilities, structures, other improvements, and all other obstructions that the grantee proposes to remove or relocate temporarily or permanently. 
(ii)  A complete list of all permits required to be obtained from governmental authorities and from persons. 
(iii)  A written traffic control plan delineating the proposed construction schedule and traffic impacts on public ways. The plan shall be proposed in accordance with the manual on uniform traffic control devices published by the state department of transportation. 
2.  Review by village. The village engineer shall review, and provide comments to the grantee on, the preliminary plans and specifications within forty-five (45) days after receipt thereof. 
3.  Submission of final plans and specifications. The grantee shall, within thirty (30) days after the date the grantee receives the village engineer's comments on the preliminary plans and specifications, submit to the village engineer for review and approval six (6) complete sets of the final plans and specifications. The final plans and specifications shall consist of final, complete, and revised versions of each of the documents that are specified in subsection 22.5-111(a) above as composing the preliminary plans and specifications. No construction of any kind shall commence, and the village shall not be required to issue any permits for any construction, unless and until the village engineer approves the final plans and specifications. 
(b)  Permits. 
1.  Obligation to obtain permits. The grantee shall, before commencing construction of any kind in the village, obtain all permits as may be necessary or required for the use of property in connection with and for the construction of the telecommunications system. The grantee shall submit copies of all permits received by it, with the exception of those issued by the village, to the village engineer prior to the commencement of construction. Each permits application submitted by the grantee to the village shall contain drawings sufficiently detailed to demonstrate to the village that the telecommunications system will be constructed in accordance with all applicable codes and ordinances. When cable is to be installed on existing utility poles, the permits application shall include a drawing showing the existing utility poles. Where cable is to be buried underground, the permits application shall include a drawing depicting the proposed depth of such burial. 
2.  Membership in J.U.L.I.E. The grantee shall, before commencing construction, become a member of J.U.L.I.E. and shall at all times during the term of the franchise comply with all regulations of J.U.L.I.E. 
3.  Construction in accordance with permits. The grantee shall construct its telecommunications system in strict accordance with all applicable codes, rules, and regulations of all governmental authorities, all permits, and the final plans and specifications. Without characterizing the breach of other covenants in this chapter, the failure to obtain and comply with any permits, the failure to comply with all applicable codes, rules, and regulations of all governmental authorities, or the failure to comply with the final plans and specifications shall constitute a violation of this chapter. The grantee shall, as diligently as possible but in no event later than thirty (30) days after delivery of a violation notice by the village, correct every such violation. Notwithstanding the foregoing, if the violation constitutes a potential threat to the public, the grantee shall correct the violation within two (2) days after delivery of a violation notice. 
(c)  Construction on and in public ways. 
1.  Minimal interference. All work performed on, in, under, across, or along the public ways shall be conducted so as to minimize any interference with the rights and convenience of the general public including, without limitation, traffic flow. The grantee shall at all times while performing work in the public ways (i) employ reasonable oars to protect the health and safety of the general public and (ii) operate in accordance with the traffic control plan as approved by the village engineer. 
2.  Barricades. The grantee shall use suitable barricades, flags lights flares, or other protective devices at such times and places as are required by its traffic control plan and all applicable ordinances, codes, rules, and regulations and at such additional times and places as are required for the safety of all members of the general public, so as to prevent injury to any person or vehicle by reason of any work being performed, as determined by the village in its sole judgment and discretion. 
(d)  Excavation work and time periods. 
1.  Prior notification. The grantee shall prepare excavation plans and submit such plans to the village engineer not less than ten (10) days prior to the start of any excavation work. The grantee shall notify the village engineer and the owner of all private property abutting the proposed excavation at least seventy-two (72) hours prior to any such excavation in any public way. Nothing herein shall be construed as preventing the grantee from making immediate repairs to any damage caused to any facilities; provided however that the grantee shall notify the village engineer as promptly as possible before such repair work or if in an emergency as soon thereafter as possible and in any event shall notify J.U.L.I.E. before such repair work. 
2.  Excavation plans. No excavation on any public way or private property shall be conducted more than twenty-four (24) hours prior to the installation therein of the facilities. 
3.  Excavations in lawns and parkways. All excavations in lawns or grassy parkways shall be immediately backfilled, tamped and restored with sod in accordance with the applicable provisions of this chapter. All restoration work shall be completed in accordance with the provisions of section 22.5-113 of this chapter. 
4.  Compaction standards. All backfill shall be impacted to the standards set forth in the village's design manual and other village codes, ordinances, and regulations. 
(e)  Trimming trees prohibited. The grantee shall be prohibited from cutting or trimming any tree shrub, or other vegetation in or on any public way. The grantee may cut or trim trees on private property as necessary; provided however that the grantee shall first obtain the permission of the effected property owner. All such trimming shall be in accordance with standard local horticultural practices and no trimming shall occur until the wires cables or other facilities first have been attached to the poles to ensure trimming to the minimum extent necessary. All trimming debris shall be removed from the work area on a daily basis. 
(f)  General construction standard. All work performed on the telecommunications system shall be performed in a good and workmanlike manner using materials of good and durable quality. If at any time it is determined by the village or any other governmental authority in its sole discretion and judgment, that any part of the telecommunications system, including, without limitation, any means used to distribute signals over or within the telecommunications system, is harmful to the health or safety of any person, then the grantee shall, at its sole cost and expense, promptly correct all such conditions to the satisfaction of such governmental authority. 
(g)  "As-built" plans. The grantee shall furnish to the village two (2) complete sets of all "as-built" plans for the telecommunications systems as originally constructed and for all reconstruction repair, relocation, and other work performed thereon, within sixty (60) days after completion of such work. The grantee at the same time also shall furnish such as-built plans to the village in a computerized format as specified by the village engineer. Notwithstanding the foregoing, the grantee shall not be required to provide "as-built" plans for routine maintenance work performed. 
(h)  Village right of inspection. The village shall have the right to inspect all construction to insure compliance with this chapter, the license or franchise agreement, and all applicable codes, laws, ordinances, rules, regulations, and permits. 
(Ord. No. 97-O-47, § 2, 6-10-97) 
Sec. 22.5-112. - Reservation of public way rights; construction restrictions. 
(a)  Title to public ways. All rights granted to the grantee in the public ways shall be granted based on the information and belief of the village that it has title to or an interest in such public ways and the right and power to grant the rights and interests granted to the grantee pursuant to this chapter. The village shall not represent or warrant that it has title to or any interest in the public ways, or the right to grant to the grantee the rights and interests granted in this chapter. The license or franchise agreement shall be deemed to grant only such rights to use the public ways as the village may have the right and power to grant in this chapter. The grantee has the right to conduct or obtain a title search of the public ways to ascertain the status of the village's rights and interest in the same, which shall be at the grantee's sole cost and expense. 
(b)  Nonexclusive use. The grantee's right to use and occupy the public ways shall not be exclusive. The village hereby reserves the right to grant any right or use of the public ways to any person at any time during the period of a license or franchise and any renewal or extension thereof, provided that such grant does not obstruct, injure, or prevent the use and operation of the telecommunications system or any facilities. 
(c)  Other utilities. The village shall retain the right to lay and permit to be laid sewer, gas, water, and other pipelines, cables, and conduits in any public way, to change any curb or sidewalk or the grade or dimension of any street, and to do and to permit to be done any other work as the village shall deem necessary or proper in its sole judgment and discretion. All such work shall be done, insofar as practicable, in such manner as not to obstruct, injure, or prevent the free use and operation of facilities. If any such facilities shall interfere with the construction or repair of any public way or public improvement therein, the grantee shall, at its sole cost and expense, commence and diligently prosecute to completion the relocation, removal, or replacement of such facilities within one hundred twenty (120) days after the delivery of written notice by the village. Such work shall be performed as be reasonably directed by the village. In the event the facilities must be so relocated, the village engineer and the village director of public works shall cooperate with the grantee in identifying alternative rights of way for the relocated facilities. 
(d)  Creation or dedication of public way. The grantee shall discontinue any use of the public way if the village reasonably determines that such use is inconsistent with the public health or safety or with the purposes for which such public way was created or dedicated or is currently being used. 
(e)  Improvements or changes on public way. If the village shall desire to make any improvements or changes on or to all or any part of any public way over, under, or along which any part of the telecommunications system has been installed, then the grantee shall, at its sole cost and expense within one hundred twenty (120) days after written notice from the village, proceed to alter, change, vacate, or remove as directed by the village, from the public way any part of the telecommunications system necessary to accommodate the village's planned improvements or changes. In the event such facilities shall be required to be removed, the village engineer and the village director of public works shall cooperate with the grantee in identifying alternative rights-of-way for the relocation of the grantee's facilities; provided, however, that nothing in this subsection shall be construed as requiring or obligating the village to identify alternative rights-of-way. 
(f)  Vacation or abandonment of public way. If any public way or portion thereof used by the grantee shall be vacated by the village, then, upon request and notice from the village, the grantee shall, at its sole cost and expense, remove its facilities therefrom within one hundred twenty (120) days of the date after such notice. In the event such facilities shall be required to be removed, the village engineer and the village director of public works shall cooperate with the grantee in identifying alternative rights-of-way for the relocation of the grantee's facilities; provided, however, that nothing in this subsection shall be construed as requiring or obligating the village to identify alternative rights-of-way. 
(g)  Temporary removal of telecommunications system. If it is necessary to temporarily remove any facilities in order to move any object, vehicle, building, or other structure over the public ways, then the grantee shall, within thirty (30) days after written notice from the village, and at its sole cost and expense, temporarily remove such facilities. 
(Ord. No. 97-O-47, § 2, 6-10-97) 
Sec. 22.5-113. - Restoration. 
(a)  Grantee's obligation. Upon completion of any construction work, the grantee shall, at its sole cost and expense and in the manner approved by the village or the affected property owner in its sole judgment and discretion, as the case may be, promptly repair the public way, private property, or improvement and restore the same to, as nearly as practicable, the condition existing prior to the performance of the work. Such restoration shall be completed within ten (10) days after the date of commencement of such work. If the grantee fails to commence or complete the restoration work in the manner and within the time periods prescribed herein, then the village may, but shall have no obligation to, perform such work and recover from the security fund established pursuant to section 22.5-121 of this chapter all costs and expenses the village incurs. If such public way, private property, or improvement cannot be so repaired, replaced, or restored, then the grantee shall cause the village or the affected owner of the same, as the case may be, to be justly compensated. 
(b)  Continuing responsibility. When any such destruction, damage, or disturbance is not immediately discovered, or when any such restoration effort fails or is otherwise inadequate or insufficient, the grantee shall have a continuing obligation to perform all necessary restoration work despite the prior termination or expiration of any applicable license or franchise agreement. 
(c)  Failure, neglect, or refusal to repay. In the event of any failure, neglect, or refusal by the grantee, within ten (10) days after written notice from the village, to repair or provide just compensation for such destruction, damage, or disturbance as provided in subsections 22.5-113(a) and (b) above, the village may, but shall be under no obligation to, perform such work or cause it to be done, and the actual cost thereof as found and declared by the village shall be paid by the grantee within thirty (30) days after demand therefor. If the grantee fails to so reimburse the village, then the village may collect the amount due from the security fund established pursuant to section 22.5-121 of this chapter, by court action or otherwise. 
(Ord. No. 97-O-47, § 2, 6-10-97) 
Sec. 22.5-114. - Damage to grantee's facilities. 
    The village shall not be liable for any damage to or loss of any telecommunications system or facility within the public ways of the village as a result of or in connection with any public works, public improvements, construction, excavation, grading, filling, or work of any kind in the public ways by or on behalf of the villages, unless such damage or loss is directly and proximately caused by the willful, intentional, or malicious acts by the village. 
(Ord. No. 97-O-47, § 2, 6-10-97) 
Sec. 22.5-115. - Facilities maps. 
    Every grantee shall provide the village with an accurate map or maps certifying the location of all telecommunications facilities within the public ways. Every grantee shall provide updated maps annually. 
(Ord. No. 97-O-47, § 2, 6-10-97) 
Sec. 22.5-116. - Duty to provide information. 
    Within ten (10) days after a written request from the village administrator, the grantee shall furnish the village with information sufficient to demonstrate: 
(a)  That the grantee has complied with all requirements of this chapter; 
(b)  That all municipal sales, message and telecommunications taxes due the village in connection with the telecommunications services and facilities provided by the grantee have been properly collected and paid by the grantee; and 
(c)  That all books, records, maps and other documents maintained by the grantee with respect to its facilities within the public ways are available for inspection by the village at all reasonable times and intervals. 
(Ord. No. 97-O-47, § 2, 6-10-97) 
Sec. 22.5-117. - Leased capacity. 
    Every grantee shall have the right, without prior village approval to offer or provide capacity bandwidth to its customers; provided however that: 
(a)  Prior to such capacity or bandwidth being provided, the grantee shall furnish the with a copy of any such lease or agreement; and 
(b)  Prior to such capacity or bandwidth being provided, and at all times after it is provided, such customer or lessee has complied and shall at all times continue to comply, to the extent applicable with all requirements of this chapter. 
(Ord. No. 97-O-47, § 2, 6-10-97) 
Secs. 22.5-118, 22.5-119. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE VIII. - FINANCIAL DATA; SECURITY; INDEMNIFICATION; INSURANCE 

Sec. 22.5-120. - Financial data of grantee of franchise. 
(a)  Annual reports. The grantee of a franchise shall, annually, within ninety (90) days after the close of its fiscal year, submit to the village a written statement, approved by an officer of the grantee, of the grantee gross revenues for the year just concluded. Such statement shall be supplemented by an audit prepared by an independent certified public accountant in accordance with generally accepted accounting principles, as well as by such additional financial statements and records as may be required by the village, within six (6) months following the close of the grantee's fiscal year. Unless required by applicable law, the village shall keep all financial statements and records of the grantee confidential. 
(b)  Books and records. The grantee shall maintain, at all times during the term of the franchise, (1) complete, accurate and properly totaled books and records of showing the business conducted by the grantee in the village in sufficient detail to show all gross revenue; (2) complete, accurate and up-to-date maps of the telecommunications system. The village may require the grantee to keep additional records and maps which it determines are reasonably necessary. 
(c)  Inspection and audits. All of such books and records and originals of all maps and other documents pertaining to this franchise shall be maintained in and made available for inspection by the village or its agents or employees, at the grantee's principal office, at reasonable times and intervals. The village shall have the right to obtain copies of all documents, maps, or records pertaining to the franchise. The grantee shall fully cooperate in assisting in this regard. 
(d)  Inquiries. The village may, at any time, make inquiries pertaining to the franchise and the operation of the telecommunications system. The grantee shall respond to such inquiries within five (5) business days of such inquiry. 
(Ord. No. 97-O-47, § 2, 6-10-97) 
Sec. 22.5-121. - Security fund for franchise. 
(a)  Amount. On or before the effective date of a franchise agreement, the grantee shall establish a "security fund" by depositing with the village or a financial institution approved by the village an amount determined by the village in its sole judgment and discretion and specified in the franchise agreement in the form of an unconditional, irrevocable letter of credit, or other instrument, in form and substance acceptable to the village attorney. At a minimum, the letter of credit or other instrument shall (1) provide that it shall not be canceled without the prior written consent of the village and (2) not require the consent of the grantee prior to the collection by the village of any amounts covered by said letter of credit or other instrument. The security fund shall be maintained during the term of the franchise and at the grantee's sole cost and expense. 
(b)  Purpose. The security fund shall serve as security for (1) the faithful performance by the grantee of all provisions of this chapter and the franchise agreement; (2) any expenditure, damage, or loss incurred by the village occasioned by the grantee's failure to comply with all codes, ordinances, rules, regulations, orders, permits, the final plans and specifications, and other directives of the village issued pursuant to this chapter or the franchise agreement; (3) the payment by the grantee of all liens and taxes, and all damages, claims, costs, or expenses that the village has paid or incurred by reason of any act or default of the grantee including, without limitation, any restoration work that the village must perform itself or have completed as a consequence of the grantee's failure to so perform or complete, and all other payments due the village from the grantee pursuant to this chapter; (4) any costs, expenses, fees, or other payments due under article VI of this chapter or otherwise under the franchise agreement; and (5) any expenses incurred by the village pursuant to section 22.5-103 of this chapter or otherwise under the franchise agreement. The withdrawal of amounts from the security fund shall constitute a credit against the amount of the applicable liability of the grantee to the village, but only to the extent of such withdrawal. 
(c)  Replenishment. Within fourteen (14) days after receipt of notice from the village that any amount has been withdrawn from the security fund, the grantee shall restore the security fund to the amount specified in subsection 22.5-121(a) above. 
(d)  Withdrawals. If the grantee (1) fails to make any payment required to be made by the grantee hereunder or under the franchise agreement; (2) falls to pay any taxes or liens relating to the telecommunications system that are due and unpaid; (3) fails to pay to the village any damages, claims, costs, or expenses that the village has been compelled to pay or incur by reason of any act or default of the grantee; or (4) fails to comply with any provision of this chapter or the franchise agreement that the village determines can be remedied by an expenditure of an amount in the security fund; then, after three (3) days written notice from the village of its intention to exercise its rights under this subsection if not paid by the grantee and the failure of the grantee to pay the monies due, the village may withdraw the amount thereof from the security fund. 
(e)  Interest. Any and all interest accrued on the amount in the security fund may be withdrawn by the grantee upon written notification of such withdrawal to the village. 
(f)  Closing and return of security fund. Upon any termination of the franchise other than a revocation, the grantee shall be entitled to the return of the security fund, or portion thereof as remains on deposit at such termination, and after account is taken for all offsets necessary to compensate the village for the failure by the grantee to comply with any provision of this chapter or the franchise agreement. In the event of any revocation of the franchise, the security fund and any and all accrued interest therein shall become the property of the village to the extent necessary to cover any costs, loss, or damage incurred by the village as a result of such revocation, provided that any amounts in excess of said costs, loss, or damage shall be refunded to the grantee. 
(g)  Rights not limited. The rights reserved to the village with respect to the security fund are in addition to all other rights of the village, whether reserved by the chapter or, the franchise agreement or authorized by law, and no action, proceeding or exercise of a right with respect to such security fund shall affect any other right the village may have. 
(Ord. No. 97-O-47, § 2, 6-10-97) 
Sec. 22.5-122. - Construction and completion bond. 
(a)  One hundred (100) percent bond required. Unless otherwise provided in a license or franchise agreement, a performance bond written by a corporate surety acceptable to the village equal to at least one hundred (100) percent of the estimated cost of constructing the grantee's telecommunications facilities within the public ways of the village shall be deposited before construction is commenced. 
(b)  Term of bond. The construction bond shall remain in force until sixty (60) days after completion and approval of the work, as determined by the village engineer, including restoration of public ways and other property affected by the construction. 
(c)  Purpose of bond. The construction bond shall guarantee. to the satisfaction of the village 
1.  Timely completion of construction; 
2.  Construction in compliance with applicable plans, permits, technical codes, and standards; 
3.  Proper location of the facilities as specified by the village; 
4.  Restoration of the public ways and other property affected by the construction; 
5.  The submission of "as-built" drawings after completion of the work as required by this chapter; and 
6.  Timely payment and satisfaction of all claims, demands, or liens for labor, material, or services provided in connection with the work. 
(Ord. No. 97-O-47, § 2, 6-10-97) 
Sec. 22.5-123. - Liability; indemnification; insurance. 
(a)  Liability. 
1.  Grantee. The grantee shall be responsible for any damage or loss to any real or personal property of the village or of any person, and for any injury to or death of any individual person, or any officer, employee, or agent of the village, arising out of or in connection with the grantee's negligence or misconduct in the construction, installation, use, operation, maintenance, repair, and/or removal of the telecommunications system, or its failure to act in connection therewith when, in the reasonable judgment of the village, the grantee should have taken certain action. 
2.  Village. The village and its officers, employees, and agents shall not be liable for any loss or damage to any real or personal property of any person, or for any injury to or death of any individual person, arising out of or in connection with the grantee's negligence or misconduct in the construction, operation, maintenance, repair, removal of, or other action or event with respect to, the telecommunications system. 
3.  Emergency and other actions. 
(i)  The village may, at any time, in case of fire, disaster, or other emergency, as determined by the village, cut or move any facilities, in which event the village shall not be liable therefor to the grantee. When practical, as determined in the sole judgment and discretion of the village, the grantee shall be consulted prior to any such cutting or movement of its wires and be given the opportunity to perform such work itself. 
(ii)  Unless directly caused by the malicious or intentional acts of the village, the village shall not be liable to the grantee for any damage to or loss of all or any part of the telecommunications system, or otherwise, as a result of or in connection with the protection, breaking through, movement, removal, alteration, or relocation of any part of the telecommunications system by or on behalf of the grantee or the village in connection with any emergency, public work, public improvement, alteration of any municipal structure, any change in the grade or line of any public way, or the elimination, discontinuation, and closing of any public way, as provided herein. When practical, as determined in the sole judgment and discretion of the village, the grantee shall be consulted prior to any such cutting or movement of its wires and be given the opportunity to perform such work itself. 
4.  The village and its officers, employees, and agents shall not be liable to the grantee or any affiliate of the grantee for any special, incidental, consequential, punitive, or other damages as a result of the exercise of any right of the village pursuant to this chapter or the license or franchise agreement, including, without limitation, the right of the village to terminate the license or franchise and to take any action subsequent thereto. 
(b)  Indemnification. 
1.  Hold harmless. The grantee shall, in the license or franchise agreement, agree to save, indemnity, and hold the village and its corporate authorities, elected and appointed officials, officers, boards, commissions, legal counsel, employees, and agents harmless from any injury, claim, demand, suit, judgment, execution, liability, debt, damages, or penalty (the "claims") arising out of, resulting from, or alleged to arise out of or result from the grantee's negligence including, without limitation, its failure to act, its misconduct in the construction, operation, maintenance, repair, or removal of the telecommunications system, or the distribution of any service over the telecommunications system, whether such acts or omissions are those of the grantee or its officers, employees, agent, or contractors and regardless of whether any such act or omission is authorized, allowed, or prohibited by this chapter or the license or franchise agreement. 
2.  Defense expense. The grantee shall pay all expenses incurred by the village in defending itself with regard to any and all of the claims. Such expenses shall include, without limitation, all out-of-pocket expenses such as attorneys' and experts' fees and the reasonable value of any services rendered by any employee of the village. 
(c)  Release and waiver of claims. The grantee shall have no recourse against the village for any loss, expense, or damage resulting from the terms and conditions of this chapter or because of the village's enforcement thereof. The grantee shall be deemed to expressly agree that it accepts the franchise relying solely upon its own investigation and understanding of the power and authority of the village to grant said franchise and that, in partial consideration of the grant of said license or franchise, the grantee shall be deemed to expressly waive and release the village from, and of, all claims of damages of any kind whatsoever, either known or unknown, existing or future, which it has or may have in connection with any matter specified in this chapter, unless such damage is directly caused by the malicious or intentional acts of the village. 
(d)  Insurance. 
1.  General liability. The grantee shall maintain, throughout the term of the license or franchise, comprehensive general liability insurance, with coverage written on an "occurrence" basis, insuring both the grantee and the village, and the village's officers, boards, commissions, elected and appointed officials, agents, and employees, in the amounts determined by the village in its sole judgment and discretion which at a minimum shall be: 
(i)  General aggregate: $5,000,000.00; and 
(ii)  Bodily injury: 
$5,000,000.00 per person 
$5,000,000.00 per occurrence; and 
(iii)  Property damage: 
$5,000,000.00 per occurrence 
$5,000,000.00 aggregate. 
Coverages shall include premises/operations, products/completed operations, independent contractors, personal injury (with employment exclusion deleted), broad form property damage endorsement, blanket contractual liability, and bodily injury and property damage. "X," "C" and "U" exclusions shall be deleted. All grantee employees shall be included as insured. 
2.  Automobile. The grantee shall maintain in its own name comprehensive motor vehicle liability insurance with a combined single limit of liability for bodily injury and property damage of not less than three million dollars ($3,000,000.00) for vehicles owned, non-owned, and rented. All grantee employees shall be included as insureds. 
3.  Worker's compensation and employer's liability. The grantee shall maintain worker's compensation insurance with limits not less than the statutory requirement, and employer's liability insurance with limits not less than one million dollars ($1,000,000.00) injury-per occurrence, one million dollars ($1,000,000.00) disease-per employee, and two million dollars ($2,000,000.00) disease-policy limit. 
4.  Umbrella policies. The required coverages may be in any combination of primary, excess, and umbrella coverages. Any excess or umbrella policy must provide excess coverage over underlying insurance on a following-form basis such that when any loss covered by the primary policy exceeds the limits under the primary policy, the excess or umbrella policy becomes effective to cover such loss. 
5.  Evidence of insurance policies. On or prior to the effective date of a license or franchise agreement, the grantee shall furnish proof to the village administrator that the foregoing insurance policies have been obtained, along with written evidence of payment of required premiums, in the form of a certificate of insurance. Such proof shall include evidence of amounts of remaining aggregate coverages for each required policy. 
6.  Maintenance of insurance policies. The liability insurance policies required by this subsection shall be maintained by the grantee throughout the term of the license or franchise and such other period of time during which the grantee operates or is engaged in the removal of the telecommunications system. Each such insurance policy shall contain the following endorsement: 
It is hereby understood and agreed that this policy may not be canceled nor the intention not to renew be stated until ninety (90) days after receipt by the village, by registered mail, of a written notice addressed to the village administrator of such intent to cancel or not to renew. Within sixty (60) days after receipt by the village of such notice, and in no event later than thirty (30) days prior to such cancellation, the grantee shall obtain and furnish to the village replacement insurance policies in forms acceptable to the village attorney. 
7.  Alteration of minimum limitations. The village may increase the minimum limitations of the insurance policy or policies required in this subsection (d) by a percentage not to exceed the percentage increase in the index as of the effective date of the license or franchise agreement. 
8.  No limit of liability. The legal liability of the grantee to the village and any person for any of the matters that are the subject of the insurance policies required by this subsection (d) shall not be limited by such insurance policies or by the recovery of any amounts thereunder. 
(Ord. No. 97-O-47, § 2, 6-10-97) 
Secs. 22.5-124-22.5-129. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE IX. - GENERAL PROVISIONS 

Sec. 22.5-130. - Assignments, transfers, and similar actions. 
(a)  Village approval required. Unless otherwise agreed to in the license or franchise agreement, neither the license or franchise, nor any rights or obligations of the grantee pursuant to this chapter, nor any of the grantee's interest in the telecommunications system shall be assigned, transferred, pledged, leased, sublet, hypothecated, or mortgaged in any manner, in whole or in part, to any person, nor shall title thereto, either legal or equitable, or any right or interest therein, or any property or assets relating to the license or franchise or the telecommunications system, pass to or vest in any person, without the prior consent of the village, which consent shall not be unreasonably withheld, as expressed by ordinance duly adopted and then only on such reasonable conditions as may therein be prescribed. Any such action completed without such prior consent of the village shall be a violation of this chapter and shall, at the option of the village which option may be exercised in the village's sole judgment and discretion and without further notice or procedure, render the license or franchise void and entitle the village to pursue all remedies available to it. The grant or waiver of any one or more of such consents shall not render unnecessary any subsequent consent or consents, nor shall the grant of any such consent constitute a waiver of any other rights of the village. 
(b)  Notice to village. The grantee shall promptly notify the village of any proposed action requiring the consent of the village pursuant to subsection 22.5-130(a) of this chapter, by submitting to the village at least ninety (90) days prior to the proposed action a petition requesting the approval of the village. The petition shall fully describe the proposed action and shall be accompanied by a justification for the action and such additional supporting information as the village may require in order to review and evaluate such action. 
(Ord. No. 97-O-47, § 2, 6-10-97) 
Sec. 22.5-131. - Transactions affecting control of grant. 
    Any transactions that singularly or collectively result in a change of ten (10) percent or more of the ownership or working control of the grantee, of the ownership or working control of a telecommunications license or franchise, of the ownership or working control of affiliated entities having ownership or working control of the grantee or of a telecommunications system, or of control of the capacity or bandwidth of the grantee's telecommunication system, facilities, or substantial parts thereof, shall be considered an assignment or transfer requiring village approval pursuant to section 22.5-130 of this chapter. Transactions between affiliated entities are not exempt from village approval. 
(Ord. No. 97-O-47, § 2, 6-10-97) 
Sec. 22.5-132. - Foreclosure, condemnation, and receivership. 
(a)  Foreclosure. Upon the scheduled occurrence of any foreclosure or other judicial sale of all or any part of the telecommunications system, or the, termination of any lease or mortgage covering all or any material part of the telecommunications system, the grantee shall immediately notify the village of such occurrence. Such notification shall be treated as a notification of a proposed change in control of the grantee, and the provisions of section 22.5-130 of this chapter shall apply. 
(b)  Condemnation. In the event that the telecommunications system, or any material part thereof, is taken, appropriated, or condemned pursuant to law, and the effect of such taking is to materially frustrate or impede the ability of the grantee to carry out any of its obligations pursuant to, and the purposes of, this chapter, then the village may revoke the license or franchise In accordance with the applicable provisions of this chapter. 
(c)  Receivership. The grantee shall notify the village, in writing, immediately if: (1) the grantee files a voluntary petition in bankruptcy, a voluntary petition to reorganize its business, or a voluntary petition to effect a plan or other arrangement with creditors; (2) the grantee files an answer admitting the jurisdiction of the court and the material allegations of an involuntary petition filed pursuant to the bankruptcy code, as amended from time to time; (3) the grantee is adjudicated bankrupt, makes an assignment for the benefit of creditors, or applies for or consents to the appointment of any receiver or trustee of all or any part of its property including, without limitation, all or any part of the telecommunications system; (4) the grantee institutes dissolution or liquidation proceedings with respect to its business; (5) an order is entered approving an involuntary petition to reorganize the business of the grantee or to effect a plan or other arrangement with creditors or appointing a receiver or trustee for the grantee of all or a part of its property including, without limitation, all or any part of the telecommunications system; or (6) a writ or warrant of attachment, execution, distraint, levy, possession, or any similar process shall be issued by any court against all or any part of the property of the grantee including, without limitation, all or any part of the telecommunications system. 
(Ord. No. 97-O-47, § 2, 6-10-97) 
Sec. 22.5-133. - Safety. 
(a)  Standard of care. The grantee shall at all times utilize the standard of care attendant to the risks involved and shall install and maintain in use commonly accepted methods and devices for preventing failures and accidents which are likely to cause damage, injury, or nuisance to the public or to employees of the grantee. 
(b)  Equipment installation and maintenance. All installations in the telecommunications system shall be made so as not to impair the fire integrity of any building or structure. The grantee shall install and maintain its facilities in accordance with the requirements of all applicable codes and in such manner that they will not interfere with any installations of the village or any public utility. All facilities in, over, under, and upon the public ways and private property within the village, wherever situated or located, shall at all times be kept and maintained in a safe and suitable condition and in good order and repair. 
(Ord. No. 97-O-47, § 2, 6-10-97) 
Sec. 22.5-134. - Compliance with law. 
    The grantee shall at all times comply with laws, codes, rules, and regulations of all governmental authorities, regardless of whether such law, code, rule, or regulation is expressly referenced in this chapter or the license or franchise agreement. The grantee shall at all times comply with all applicable laws, ordinances, resolutions, codes, rules, and regulations of the village and all applicable memoranda and other directives of the village, as such laws, ordinances, resolutions, codes, rules, regulations, memoranda, and directives may be modified or amended provided that such modification or amendment does not impair, conflict with, or diminish the rights granted to the grantee under this chapter or the license or franchise agreement. 
(Ord. No. 97-O-47, § 2, 6-10-97) 
Sec. 22.5-135. - Subsequent action by government authorities. 
    If any subsequent law, ordinance, rule, code, regulation. controlling judicial review, or decision shall require or permit the grantee to perform any act or shall prohibit the grantee from performing any act such that the grantee may be in conflict with the terms of this chapter or an applicable license or franchise agreement, then as soon as possible following knowledge thereof, the grantee shall so notify the village. If the village determines, in its sole judgment and discretion, that a material provision of this chapter or the license or franchise agreement is affected by such changed or new law, ordinance, or regulation, then the village and the grantee shall enter into good faith negotiations to modify the license or franchise agreement to conform with such changed requirements. 
(Ord. No. 97-O-47, § 2, 6-10-97) 
Sec. 22.5-136. - Non-enforcement by village. 
    No grantee shall be excused from complying with any of the terms and conditions of this chapter or the license or franchise agreement by any failure of the village, on any one (1) or more occasions, to insist on the grantee's performance of, or to seek the grantee's compliance with, any one or more of such terms or conditions. 
(Ord. No. 97-O-47, § 2, 6-10-97) 
Sec. 22.5-137. - Rights and remedies. 
(a)  Cumulative effect. All rights and remedies given to the village by this chapter and the license or franchise agreement shall be in addition to and cumulative with each other and with any and all other rights or remedies, existing or implied, now or hereafter available to the village, at law or in equity, and such rights and remedies shall not be exclusive, but each and every right and remedy specifically provided or otherwise existing or given may be exercised from time to time and as often and in such order as may be deemed expedient by the village in its sole judgment and discretion, and the exercise of one (1) or more rights or remedies shall not be deemed a waiver of the right to exercise at the same time or thereafter any other right or remedy nor shall any such delay or omission be construed to be a waiver of or acquiescence to any default. The exercise of any such right of remedy by the village shall not release the grantee from its obligations of any liability under this chapter or the license or franchise agreement. 
(b)  Injunction or decree. In addition to all other remedies granted or available to the village, the village shall be entitled to the restraint by injunction of the violation, or attempted or threatened violation, by the grantee of any terms or provisions of this chapter or the license or franchise agreement, or to a decree compelling performance by the grantee of any term or provision thereof. 
(c)  Village rights reserved. The village expressly reserves the following rights which shall not be deemed to be waived or abrogated by any license or franchise granted or any license or franchise agreement executed pursuant to this chapter: 
1.  To exercise its governmental powers, now or hereafter, to the full extent that such powers may be vested in or granted to the village; 
2.  To adopt, in addition to the provisions contained herein, in the license or franchise agreement, or in any existing applicable ordinance, such additional regulations as it shall find necessary in the exercise of its police power, and 
3.  To modify the license or franchise agreement executed pursuant to this chapter. 
The express reservation of the foregoing rights shall not be construed as a waiver of any other rights lawfully belonging to the village. 
(Ord. No. 97-O-47, § 2, 6-10-97) 
Sec. 22.5-138. - Revocation or termination of grant. 
    A license or franchise granted by the village to use or occupy public ways of the village may be revoked for any one or more the following reasons: 
(a)  Construction or operation in the village or in the public ways of the village without a license or franchise grant of authorization; 
(b)  Construction or operation at an unauthorized location; 
(c)  Unauthorized substantial transfer of control of the grantee; 
(d)  Unauthorized assignment of a license or franchise; 
(e)  Unauthorized sale, assignment, or transfer of the grantee's license or franchise assets or a substantial interest therein; 
(f)  Misrepresentation or lack of candor by or on behalf of a grantee in any application to the village; 
(g)  Abandonment of telecommunications facilities in the public ways; 
(h)  Failure to relocate or remove facilities as required in this chapter; 
(i)  Failure to pay taxes, compensation, fees, or costs when and as due the village; 
(j)  Insolvency or bankruptcy of the grantee; 
(k)  Violation of a material provision of this chapter; 
(l)  Violation of a material term of a license or franchise agreement; 
(Ord. No. 97-O-47, § 2, 6-10-97) 
Sec. 22.5-139. - Notice and duty to cure. 
    If the village administrator believes that grounds exist for revocation of a license or franchise, the village administrator shall give the grantee written notice of the apparent violation or noncompliance, providing a short and concise statement of the nature and general facts of the violation or noncompliance, and providing a reasonable period of time not exceeding thirty (30) days to furnish evidence: 
(a)  That corrective action has been, or is being actively and expeditiously pursued, to remedy the violation or noncompliance; or 
(b)  That rebuts the alleged violation or noncompliance; or 
(c)  That it would be in the public interest to impose some penalty or sanction less than revocation. 
(Ord. No. 97-O-47, § 2, 6-10-97) 
Sec. 22.5-140. - Hearing. 
    If a grantee fails to provide evidence reasonably satisfactory to the village administrator as provided in section 22.5-139 of this chapter, then the village administrator shall refer the apparent violation or noncompliance to the corporate authorities. The corporate authorities shall provide the grantee with notice and a reasonable opportunity to be heard concerning the matter. 
(Ord. No. 97-O-47, § 2, 6-10-97) 
Sec. 22.5-141. - Standards for revocation or lesser sanctions. 
    If persuaded that a grantee has violated or failed to comply with material provisions of this chapter, or of a license or franchise agreement, then the corporate authorities shall determine whether to revoke the license or franchise or to establish some lesser sanction and cure, considering the nature, circumstances, extent, and gravity of the violation as reflected by any one (1) or more of the following factors: 
(a)  Whether the misconduct was egregious; or 
(b)  Whether substantial harm resulted; or 
(c)  Whether the violation was intentional; or 
(d)  Whether there is a history of violations of the same or other requirements; or 
(e)  Whether there is a history of overall compliance; or 
(f)  Whether the violation was voluntarily disclosed, admitted, or cured. 
(Ord. No. 97-O-47, § 2, 6-10-97) 
Sec. 22.5-142. - Time of the essence. 
    Except as provided in sections 22.5-143 and 22.5-144 of this chapter, whenever this chapter or the license or franchise agreement sets forth any time for any act to be performed by the grantee, such time shall be deemed to be of the essence, and the grantee's failure to perform within the time allotted shall, in all cases, be sufficient grounds for the village to invoke the penalties and remedies available under the terms and conditions of this chapter and the license or franchise agreement. 
(Ord. No. 97-O-47, § 2, 6-10-97) 
Sec. 22.5-143. - Time for notice if emergency. 
    In the event of an emergency involving life or property, as determined by the village in its sole judgment and discretion, the village may reduce or eliminate the notice requirements set forth in this chapter, and any such reduction or elimination shall be deemed to be reasonable under the circumstances. 
(Ord. No. 97-O-47, § 2, 6-10-97) 
Sec. 22.5-144. - Force majeure. 
    Whenever a period of time is provided for in this chapter for either the village or the grantee to do or perform any act or obligation, neither the village nor the grantee shall be liable for any delays or inability to perform due to causes beyond their respective control such as war, riot, insurrection, rebellion, strike, lockout, unavoidable casualty or damage to personnel, materials, or equipment, fire, flood, storm, earthquake, tornado, or any act of God; provided, however, that such time period shall be extended for only the actual amount of time the village or grantee is so delayed and provided further, however, that an act or omission shall not be deemed to be "beyond the grantee's control" if committed, omitted, or caused by the grantee, the grantee's employees, officers, or agents or a subsidiary, affiliate, or parent of the grantee or by any corporation or other business entity that holds a controlling interest in the grantee, whether held directly or indirectly. 
(Ord. No. 97-O-47, § 2, 6-10-97) 
Sec. 22.5-145. - Notice. 
    Any required notice or other communication shall be in writing and shall be (a) personally delivered, or (b) delivered by a reputable overnight courier, or (c) delivered by certified mail, returned receipt requested, and deposited in the U.S. Mail, postage prepaid. Facsimile notices shall be deemed valid only to the extent they are (i) actually received by the individual to whom addressed and (ii) followed by delivery of actual notice in the manner described in either (a), (b), or (c) above within three (3) business days thereafter. Unless otherwise expressly provided in the license or franchise, notices shall be deemed received at the earlier (x) of actual receipt; or (y) one business day after deposit with an overnight courier as evidenced by a receipt of deposit; or (z) three (3) business days following deposit in the U.S. mail, as evidenced by a return receipt. Notice shall be directed to a party at its address set forth in the license or franchise. 
(Ord. No. 97-O-47, § 2, 6-10-97) 
Sec. 22.5-146. - Severability. 
    If any section, subsection, sentence, clause, phrase, or other portion of this chapter, or its application to any person, is, for any reason, declared invalid, in whole or in part, by any court, agency, commission, legislative body, or other authority of competent jurisdiction, such decision shall not affect the validity of the remaining portions hereof. 
(Ord. No. 97-O-47, § 2, 6-10-97) 
Chapter 23 - TRAFFIC[1]

Cross reference- Motor vehicle license tax, § 13-46 et seq.; junked vehicles, § 15-71 et seq.; streets and sidewalks, Ch. 21; parades, § 21-56 et seq.; vehicles for hire, Ch. 24.
