ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 23-1. - Definitions. 
    The definitions applicable to the Illinois Vehicle Code [625 ILCS 5/1-100 et seq.] are applicable to this chapter. 
(Code 1977, § 41.1; Ord. No. 82-0-31, § 1, 8-10-82) 
Cross reference- Definitions and rules of construction generally, § 1-2. 
State Law reference- Adoption of the Illinois Vehicle Code by reference, 625 ILCS 5/1-100; adoption by reference, 65 ILCS 5/1-3-1 et seq., 50 ILCS 220/1 et seq. 
Sec. 23-2. - Adoption of state law. 
(a)  The Illinois Vehicle Code [625 ILCS 5/1-100 et seq.] is adopted by reference. 
(b)  Any person violating any of the provisions of the Illinois Vehicle Code shall be punished as provided in section 1-12. 
(Code 1977, § 41.1; Ord. No. 82-0-31, § 1, 8-10-82) 
Sec. 23-3. - Penalties. 
(a)  Generally. Except as otherwise provided in this chapter, violations of this chapter are punishable as provided in section 1-12. 
(b)  Load limits. Whenever any vehicle is operated in violation of the provisions of section 15-111 of the Illinois Vehicle Code [625 ILCS 5/15-111], the owner or driver of such vehicle shall be deemed guilty of such violation and either the owner or the driver of such vehicle may be prosecuted for such violation. Any person convicted of any violation of such section shall be fined in an amount equal to two cents ($0.02) per pound for each pound of excess weight when the excess exceeds one thousand (1,000) pounds and is two thousand (2,000) pounds or less; six cents ($0.06) per pound for each pound of excess weight when the excess exceeds two thousand (2,000) pounds and is three thousand (3,000) pounds or less; eight cents ($0.08) per pound for each pound of excess weight when the excess exceeds three thousand (3,000) pounds and is four thousand (4,000) pounds or less; ten cents ($0.10) per pound for each pound of excess weight when the excess exceeds four thousand (4,000) pounds and is five thousand (5,000) pounds or less; and twelve cents ($0.12) per pound for each pound of excess weight when the excess exceeds five thousand (5,000) pounds; provided, however, that in no event shall any such fine for any one (1) violation exceed the sum of five hundred dollars ($500.00). 
(c)  Minors convicted of bicycle violations. If a minor under seventeen (17) years of age at the time of the alleged offense is fined for a violation of article V of this chapter or chapter 11, article XV of the Illinois Vehicle Code [625 ILCS 5/11-1501 et seq.] and is committed for a failure to pay the fine, the confinement shall be subject to the provisions of applicable law. 
(Code 1977, §§ 41.1, 41.9.2, 41.9.3, 42.8; Ord. No. 81-0-3, § 3, 2-24-81; Ord. No. 83-0-9, § 2, 5-17-83) 
Sec. 23-4. - Application of chapter to animals. 
    Every person riding an animal or driving any animal drawing a vehicle upon any street shall be subject to the provisions of this chapter applicable to the driver of a motor vehicle, except those provisions which can have no application to such specific activity. 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, 625 ILCS 5/11-206. 
Sec. 23-5. - Obedience by public officers and employees; exceptions. 
(a)  The provisions of this chapter applicable to the drivers of vehicles upon the highways shall apply to drivers of all vehicles owned or operated by the United States, this state or any county, city, town, district or any other political subdivision of the state, except as provided in this section and subject to such specific exceptions as set forth by law with reference to authorized emergency vehicles. 
(b)  The driver of an authorized emergency vehicle, when responding to an emergency call, in the pursuit of an actual or suspected violator of the law, responding to but not returning from a fire alarm, or in the process of a medical emergency transport, may exercise the privileges set forth in this section but subject to the conditions herein stated. 
(c)  The driver of an authorized emergency vehicle may: 
(1)  Park or stand, irrespective of the provisions of this chapter. 
(2)  Proceed past a red or stop signal or stop sign, but only after slowing down as may be required and necessary for safe operation. 
(3)  Exceed the maximum speed limits so long as he does not endanger life or property. 
(4)  Disregard regulations governing direction of movement or turning in specified directions. 
(d)  The exceptions herein granted to an authorized emergency vehicle, other than a police vehicle, shall apply only when the vehicle is making use of either an audible signal when in motion or visual signals meeting the requirements of state law. 
(e)  The foregoing provisions do not relieve the driver of an authorized emergency vehicle from the duty of driving with due regard for the safety of all persons, nor do such provisions protect the driver from the consequences of his reckless disregard for the safety of others. 
(f)  Unless specifically made applicable, the provisions of this chapter shall not apply to persons, motor vehicles and equipment while actually engaged in work upon a highway but shall apply to such persons and vehicles when traveling to or from such work. 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, 625 ILCS 5/11-205. 
Sec. 23-6. - Automated traffic law enforcement. 
(a)  As used in this section, "automated traffic law enforcement system" means a device with one (1) or more motor vehicle sensors working in conjunction with a red light signal to produce recorded images of motor vehicles entering an intersection against a red signal indication in violation of Section 11-306 of the Illinois Vehicle Code or a similar provision of this Code. 
(b)  As used in this section, "recorded images" means images recorded by an automated traffic law enforcement system on: 
(1)  Two (2) or more photographs; 
(2)  Two (2) or more microphotographs; 
(3)  Two (2) or more electronic images; or 
(4)  A video recording showing the motor vehicle and, on at least one (1) image or portion of the recording, clearly identifying the registration plate number of the motor vehicle. 
(c)  The automated traffic law enforcement system shall not be used for the purpose of recording the speed of vehicles. 
(d)  For each violation of this section recorded by an automatic traffic law enforcement system, the village or its service provider shall issue a written notice of the violation to the registered owner of the vehicle as the alleged violator. The notice shall be delivered to the registered owner of the vehicle, by mail, within thirty (30) days after the secretary of state notifies the municipality or county of the identity of the owner of the vehicle, but in no event later than ninety (90) days after the violation. The notice shall include: 
(1)  The name and address of the registered owner of the vehicle; 
(2)  The registration number of the motor vehicle involved in the violation, 
(3)  The violation charged; 
(4)  The location where the violation occurred; 
(5)  The date and time of the violation; 
(6)  A copy of the recorded images; 
(7)  The amount of the civil penalty imposed and the date by which the civil penalty should be paid; 
(8)  A statement that the recorded images are evidence of violation of a red light signal; 
(9)  A warning that failure to pay the civil penalty or to contest liability in a timely manner is an admission of liability and may result in a suspension of the driving privileges of the registered owner of the vehicle; and 
(10)  A statement that the person may elect to proceed by paying the fine or by challenging the charge in court, or by mail, or by administrative hearing. 
(e)  If a person, charged with a traffic violation as a result of an automated traffic law enforcement system, does not pay or successfully contests the civil penalty resulting from that violation, the secretary of state shall suspend the driving privileges of the registered owner of the vehicle under Section 6-306.5 of this Illinois Vehicle Code for failing to pay any fine or penalty due and owing as a result of five (5) violations of the automated traffic law enforcement system. 
(f)  Based on inspection of recorded images produced by an automated traffic law enforcement system, a notice alleging that the violation occurred shall be evidence of the facts contained in the notice and admissible in any proceeding alleging a violation under this section. 
(g)  Recorded images made by an automatic traffic law enforcement system are confidential and shall be made available only to the alleged violator and governmental and law enforcement agencies for purposes of adjudicating a violation of this section, for statistical purposes, or for other governmental purposes. Any recorded image evidencing a violation of this section, however, may be admissible in any proceeding resulting from the issuance of the citation. 
(h)  The court or hearing officer may consider in defense of a violation: 
(1)  That the motor vehicle or registration plates of the motor vehicle were stolen before the violation occurred and not under the control of or in the possession of the owner at the time of the violation, 
(2)  That the driver of the vehicle passes through the intersection when the light was red either (i) in order to yield the right-of-way to an emergency vehicle or (ii) was part of a funeral procession; and 
(3)  Any other evidence or issues provided by municipal ordinance. 
(i)  To demonstrate that the motor vehicle or the registration plates were stolen before the violation occurred and were not under the control or possession of the owner at the time of the violation, the owner must submit proof that a report concerning the stolen motor vehicle or registration plates was filed with a law enforcement agency in a timely manner. 
(j)  Unless the driver of the motor vehicle received a Uniform Traffic Citation from a police officer at the time of the violation, the motor vehicle owner is subject to a civil penalty not exceeding one hundred dollars ($100.00), plus an additional penalty of not more than one hundred dollars ($100.00) for failure to pay the original penalty in a timely manner, if the motor vehicle is recorded by an automated traffic law enforcement system. A violation for which a civil penalty is imposed under this section is not a violation of a traffic regulation governing the movement of vehicles and may not be recorded on the driving record of the owner of the vehicle. 
(k)  An intersection equipped with an automated traffic law enforcement system must be posted with a sign visible to approaching traffic indicating that the intersection is being monitored by an automated traffic law enforcement system. 
(Ord. No. 08-O-55, § 2, 8-12-08) 
Secs. 23-7-23-25. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - ADMINISTRATION AND ENFORCEMENT 

Sec. 23-26. - Authority to direct traffic. 
    Members of the police department are authorized to direct traffic. The fire department officer in command, or any firefighter designated by him, may exercise the powers and authority of a police officer in directing traffic at the scene of any fire or where the fire department has responded to an emergency call for so long as fire department equipment is on the scene in the absence of or in assisting the police. 
(Code 1977, § 41.2.5) 
Sec. 23-27. - Ratification of existing signs, signals, devices. 
    All traffic control signs, signals, devices and markings in place on the adoption date of this Code are ratified and confirmed. 
Sec. 23-28. - Speed limits. 
(a)  Streets designated 20 miles per hour. The full length of: 
Elm Court 
Elm Drive 
Forest Lane 
Golf Road 
Homewood Drive 
Laurel Avenue 
Linden Lane 
Sunset Drive 
(b)  Streets designated 30 miles per hour. 
American Way Full length Artaius Parkway Full length Enterprise Court Full length Fourth Street Full length Franklin Boulevard Full length Hollister Drive Full length Industrial Drive Full length Temple Drive  
(c)  Streets designated 25 miles per hour. The speed limit for all residential streets, under the jurisdiction of the village, shall be twenty-five (25) miles per hour unless otherwise approved by ordinance and posted. 
(d)  Streets designated 40 miles per hour. 
Harris Road 
(e)  Maximum speed limit within any park and recreational area. The maximum speed limit for any vehicle within any park and recreational area owned and maintained by the village shall be fifteen (15) miles per hour. Speed must be decreased as may be necessary to avoid colliding with any person or vehicle in compliance with legal requirements and the duty of all persons to exercise due care. 
(Ord. No. 90-0-15, § 1, 5-22-90; Ord. No. 93-0-33, §§ 1, 2, 7-14-93; Ord. No. 94-0-29, § 1, 6-28-94; Ord. No. 94-0-41, § 1, 9-13-94; Ord. No. 98-O-75, § 2, 10-13-98; Ord. No. 98-O-96, § 2, 12-8-98; Ord. No. 03-O-04, § 2, 1-28-03) 
Sec. 23-29. - Weight limits. 
(a)  Except upon those streets designated as heavy traffic streets pursuant to subsection 23-29(b) below, it shall be unlawful for any person to operate any truck or other commercial vehicle having a gross weight in excess of twelve thousand (12,000) pounds upon any street under the jurisdiction of the village except in repairing or constructing such streets; provided, however, that any truck or other commercial vehicle having a gross weight in excess of twelve thousand (12,000) pounds and carrying goods, merchandise or other articles to or from any house or premises abutting upon any street upon which heavy traffic is otherwise prohibited may enter upon such street, and pass over the nearest route leading thereto or therefrom to a heavy traffic street, solely for the purpose of delivering or receiving goods, merchandise or other articles. In doing so, the driver of the vehicle shall proceed no farther than is necessary for such purpose upon any street upon which heavy traffic is prohibited, except when drivers are accessing their private residences. 
(b)  The following streets in the village shall be and they hereby are designated as heavy traffic streets under this section: Milwaukee Avenue, throughout the village limits; Park Avenue, throughout the village limits; Peterson Road, throughout the village limits; Harris Road, throughout the village limits; Midlothian Road, throughout the village limits; Winchester Road, between Milwaukee Avenue and the westerly village limits; Butterfield Road, between Old Peterson Road and the southerly village limits; Oak Spring Road between Second Street and the easterly village limits; Second Street between Church Street and Oak Spring Road; Cook Avenue, between the east end thereof and Brained Avenue; Brained Avenue between Cook and Church street; Church Street between Brainerd Avenue and Fifth Street; Fifth Street between Church Street and Park Avenue; North Avenue east of Second Street and Third Avenue north of Church Street. 
(c)  The provisions of this section governing weight do not apply to fire apparatus and other emergency vehicles as authorized by the Illinois Vehicle Code, or equipment for snow and ice removal operations owned or operated by a governmental body; to waste haulers making frequent stops for the purpose of removing waste, to school buses, to public utility vehicles; or to implements of husbandry temporarily operated or towed in a combination provided such combination does not consist of more than three (3) vehicles or, in the case of hauling fresh, perishable fruits or vegetables from farm to the point of first processing, not more than three (3) wagons being towed by an implement of husbandry. 
(Ord. No. 95-0-28, § 2, 5-9-95; Ord. No. 01-O-75, § 2, 10-9-01) 
Cross reference- Schedule of permits, fees and licenses established, § 13-171.

ARTICLE III. - GENERAL RULES OF VEHICLE OPERATION 

Sec. 23-46. - Driving under influence of alcohol, drugs. 
(a)  A person shall not drive or be in actual physical control of any vehicle within the village while: 
(1)  The alcohol concentration in such person's blood or breath is ten-hundredths (0.10) or more based on the definition of blood and breath units in section 11-501.2 of the Illinois Vehicle Code [625 ILCS 5/11-501.2]. 
(2)  Under the influence of alcohol. 
(3)  Under the influence of any other drug or combination of drugs to a degree which renders such person incapable of safely driving. 
(4)  Under the combined influence of alcohol and any other drug or drugs to a degree which renders such person incapable of safely driving. 
(b)  The fact that any person charged with violating this section is or has been legally entitled to use alcohol, or other drugs or any combination of both, shall not constitute a defense against any charge of violating this section. 
(c)  Every person convicted of violating this section shall be guilty of a Class A misdemeanor as defined in sections 1005-8-3(a)(1) and 1005-9-1(a)(2) of the Unified Code of Corrections [730 ILCS 5/5-8-3(a)(1), 5/5-9-1(a)(2)] and shall be punishable upon conviction by a fine not to exceed one thousand dollars ($1,000.00) and/or a sentence to a determinate term of imprisonment for any term less than one (1) year and, in addition to any the criminal or administrative action, for any second or subsequent conviction of violating this section or section 11-501(a) of the Illinois Vehicle Code [625 5/11-501(a)], or a similar provision of any local ordinance of any other municipal corporation committed within five (5) years of a previous violation of this section or such section 11-501(a), or a similar provision of any local ordinance of any other municipal corporation shall be mandatorily sentenced to a minimum of forty-eight (48) consecutive hours of imprisonment or assigned to a minimum of ten (10) days of community service as may be determined by the court. The imprisonment or assignment shall not be subject to suspension nor shall the person be eligible for probation in order to reduce the sentence or assignment. 
(d)  Prior to the imposition of sentence on an individual being sentenced under this section, the individual must undergo a professional evaluation to determine if an alcohol or other drug abuse problem exists and the extent of such a problem. Programs conducting these evaluations must meet standards prescribed by the department of alcoholism and substance abuse of the state. Whenever an individual is sentenced for a violation of this section, and the professional evaluation recommends remedial or rehabilitative treatment or education, neither the treatment nor the education shall be the sole disposition and either or both may be imposed only in conjunction with another disposition. The court shall monitor compliance with any remedial education or treatment recommendations contained in the professional evaluation. Programs conducting alcohol or other drug evaluation or remedial education must be licensed by the department of alcoholism and substance abuse of the state. Programs providing treatment must be licensed under existing applicable alcoholism and drug treatment licensure standards. 
(e)  Upon commencement of a prosecution for a violation of this section the victims of these offenses shall have all rights under this section as they do in section 4 of the Bill of Rights for Victims and Witnesses of Violent Crime Act [725 ILCS 120/4]. For the purpose of this section "victim" shall mean an individual who has suffered personal injury as a result of the commission of a violation of this section. Prior to the imposition of a sentence for violation of this section, the victim of the person found guilty of violating this section shall be afforded the opportunity to make a statement concerning the impact on the victim and to offer evidence in aggravation or mitigation; provided that the sentence must first be prepared in writing in conjunction with the village attorney before it may be presented orally at the hearing. All statements and evidence offered under this subsection shall become part of the record of the court. For the purpose of this subsection, "personal injury" shall include any injury requiring immediate professional attention in either a doctor's office or medical facility. In imposing a sentence for violating this section, when the violator has caused personal injury to another party, the trial judge shall specify on the record the particular evidence, information, factors in mitigation and aggravation or other reasons that led to his sentencing determination. The full verbatim record of the sentencing hearing shall be filed with the clerk of the court and shall be a public record. 
(Code 1977, § 41.8.11; Ord. No. 86-0-6, § 2, 1-28-86) 
State Law reference- Driving while intoxicated, etc., 625 ILCS 5/11-301 et seq. 
Sec. 23-47. - Negligent driving. 
(a)  A person is negligent or acts negligently when he fails to become aware of certain circumstances that exist, or of a possible result that will follow from his conduct, and such conduct constitutes a substantial deviation from the standard of care which a reasonable person would exercise in the situation. 
(b)  It shall be unlawful for any person to operate a motor vehicle in a negligent manner in this village. 
(Code 1977, § 41.8.15) 
State Law reference- Reckless driving, 625 ILCS 5/11-503; drag racing, 625 ILCS 5/11-504. 
Sec. 23-48. - Turning movements. 
    Except in compliance with law or the directions of a police officer or official traffic control device, no vehicle shall turn at any place or during the periods of time designated below provided appropriate signs prohibiting such turning are erected: 
    Appley Avenue , westbound, at Milwaukee Avenue, left turn prohibited between 4:00 p.m. and 6:00 p.m. on weekdays. 
    Butterfield Road onto Harding Avenue, all turns prohibited. 
    Butterfield Road, the southernmost driveway of 1795 N. Butterfield Road to southbound Butterfield Road, right turns prohibited, except emergency vehicles. 
    Butterfield Road onto Willow Drive, left turn prohibited. 
    Church Avenue onto Milwaukee Avenue, right turns on red traffic control signal prohibited between 7:00 a.m. and 7:00 p.m., inclusive, Monday through Saturday. 
    Cook Avenue onto Milwaukee Avenue, right turns on red traffic control signal prohibited between 7:00 a.m. and 7:00 p.m., inclusive, Monday through Saturday. 
    Illinois Highway 176, also known as Park Avenue, onto Harding Street, left turn prohibited. 
    Illinois Highway 176, also known as Park Avenue, onto Sunset Drive, left turn prohibited. 
    Rockland Road, westbound and eastbound, from the west curb of Milwaukee Avenue to the east curb of Garfield Avenue. 
    Willow Drive onto Butterfield Road, left turn prohibited. 
(Ord. No. 92-0-34, § 1, 7-14-92; Ord. No. 93-0-2, § 1, 1-12-93; Ord. No. 95-0-39, § 1, 6-13-95; Ord. No. 98-O-82, § 3, 11-10-98; Ord. No. 00-O-73, § 3, 12-12-00; Ord. No. 02-O-26, § 2, 3-12-02; Ord. No. 02-O-88, § 2, 7-23-02; Ord. No. 03-0-70, § 3, 10-15-03; Ord. No. 03-O-75, § 2, 10-29-03; Ord. No. 07-O-24, § 2, 3-27-07; Ord. No. 07-O-42, § 2, 6-12-07; Ord. No. 07-O-88, § 2, 12-11-07) 
Editor's note- Ord. Nos. 98-O-82 and 00-O-73 state: "Specific to this Ordinance, the term U-turn shall refer to the maneuver when a driver turns a vehicle using one or more turns, so as to proceed in the opposite direction of the vehicle at commencement of the maneuver." 
Secs. 23-49-23-65. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE IV. - STOPPING, STANDING AND PARKING[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Cross reference- Parking and storage on private property in residential districts, § 26-351 et seq. 
State Law reference- Stopping, standing and parking generally, 625 ILCS 5/11-1301 et seq.; authority to regulate standing or parking, 625 ILCS 5/11-208(a)(1). 

Sec. 23-66. - Responsibility of owner. 
    The fact that a vehicle is registered in a person's name shall be prima facie proof that such person was responsible for any violation of any parking regulation of this article involving such vehicle. 
(Code 1977, § 41.5.12) 
State Law reference- Responsibilities and liabilities of lessors of vehicles for parking violations, 625 ILCS 5/11-1305, 5/11-1306. 
Sec. 23-67. - Limited parking. 
(a)  The village board may designate such place or places, upon public streets and thoroughfares, upon municipal parking areas and upon other areas owned or controlled by the village, at which no person may park a vehicle longer than a designated period of time; provided, however, that if any such time limited parking place has also been designated by the village board, pursuant to section 23-74 of this Code, as employee or downtown resident permit parking, a vehicle bearing either an employee or downtown resident parking permit issued pursuant to section 23-74 of this Code shall be exempt from the time limitations imposed upon such place from 8:00 a.m. to 5:00 p.m., Monday through Saturday. Such designation is effective only after an appropriate sign, notice, signs or notices is or are installed or posted at such place or places stating the length of time for which a vehicle may be parked at such place or places, respectively. A vehicle shall be deemed to be parked in violation of any such limitation if it is moved with the purpose of evading such parking time limitation to another parking space located within five hundred (500) feet from the closest point of the parking space at which such vehicle shall have been so first parked. The movement of a vehicle less than thirty (30) minutes before or after the expiration of the parking time limitation from one (1) parking space to such other parking space shall be presumed to have been moved with the purpose of evading a parking time limitation. A vehicle shall be deemed to be parked in violation of any such limitation if a chalk mark placed on the tire of such vehicle by a police officer or community service officer shall be removed, altered or obliterated for the purpose of evading enforcement of any such parking time limitation. 
(b)  The director of public works shall have markings painted or placed where parking is limited pursuant to provisions hereof, and shall cause signs or notices to be painted, installed or posted as herein contemplated, as to the applicable parking time limitation, respectively. Such markings shall establish lines for each space within which vehicles are to be parked. It shall be unlawful to park any vehicle across any such line or marking or to park a vehicle in such a position that the vehicle shall not be entirely within the area so designated by such lines or markings. 
(c)  It shall be unlawful for any person to willfully impair any sign or notice painted, installed or posted under the provisions of this section or to in any way tamper with, willfully injure, break, destroy or impair any post, installation, surface or object upon which any such sign or notice is so painted, installed or posted. 
(d)  It shall be unlawful for any person to remove, alter or obliterate any chalk mark placed on the tire of a vehicle by a police officer or community service officer with the intent to evade enforcement of any parking time limitation imposed pursuant to the provisions of this section. 
(e)  Any person issued a parking ticket for unlawfully parking in districts zoned C-l may be issued an additional ticket for each hour subsequent to the issuance of first ticket that the vehicle remains unlawfully parked thereafter. Each hour that a vehicle remains unlawfully parked subsequent to the issuance of a first ticket shall constitute a separate offense. 
(f)  (1)  Where conspicuously posted within the C-I downtown commercial district, construction vehicles, machinery and developer and contractor personal vehicles may not stand or park at any time, except when actively loading or unloading such vehicles during a maximum period of thirty (30) minutes. 
(2)  Vehicles, machinery and developer and contractor personal vehicles found in violation of this section will be liable for a minimum fine of one hundred dollars ($100.00) and maximum fine of five hundred dollars ($500.00) for each such violation. Additionally, such vehicles and machinery found in violation of this section are subject to immediate removal by towing at the personal expense of the vehicle or machinery owner or operator. 
(3)  Vehicles, machinery and developer and contractor personal vehicles found in violation of this section will constitute a breach of a pertinent development agreement, building permit or other village-issued permit or license where such agreement includes specifications for the parking of vehicles used for construction purposes or for transportation to and from construction sites in the C-I downtown commercial district. 
(4)  To the extent that the size of vehicles, machinery and developer and contractor personal vehicles can be accommodated within certain parking areas, those vehicles are eligible for employee parking privileges pursuant to section 23-74 of the Municipal Code, "Employee and Downtown Resident Parking", subject to the fees established in section 13-171 of this Code, or as agreed to and expressed within a relevant development agreement, building permit or other village-issued permit or license. 
(g)  Within the municipal parking garage at 616 Brainerd Avenue, parking shall be limited as follows: 
(1)  Lower tier: Employee parking only, with employee vehicle identification required. 
(2)  Ground-level tier: Customer parking for a maximum of four (4) hours and accessible parking spaces where properly posted. 
(3)  Top tier: Customer parking for a maximum of four (4) hours. 
(h)  Within the municipal parking lot to the north of the municipal parking garage at 123 Church Street, parking shall be limited as follows: 
(1)  Eleven (11) spaces adjacent to the municipal parking garage shall be designated one-hour parking, from 6:00 a.m. to 6:00 p.m., Monday through Friday. 
(2)  Two (2) spaces adjacent to the southeast of Saint Lawrence Episcopal Church shall be designated one-hour parking, from 6:00 a.m. to 6:00 p.m., Monday through Friday. 
(3)  Lower tier: Employee parking only, with employee vehicle identification required. 
(4)  Ground-level tier: Customer parking for a maximum of four (4) hours and accessible parking spaces where properly posted. 
(5)  Top tier: Customer parking for a maximum of four (4) hours and employee parking, with employee vehicle identification required. 
(i)  Penalty. Any person, firm or corporation violating this section shall be fined in accordance with section 13-171, schedule of permits, fees and licenses, and when applicable, subsection 23-671, limited parking, of the Municipal Code. 
(j)  Lake Street, north side, three (3) parking spaces from the intersection of Milwaukee Avenue to the west, shall be designated as fifteen-minute parking zones, from 6:00 a.m. to 7:00 p.m., Monday through Saturday. 
(Code 1977, § 41.5.4; Ord. No. 92-0-23, §§ 1, 2, 5-26-92; Ord. No. 95-0-13, § 2, 3-14-95; Ord. No. 99-O-44, § 3, 5-11-99; Ord. No. 01-O-80, § 2, 10-23-01; Ord. No. 07-O-76, § 2, 10-23-07; Ord. No. 09-O-67, §§ 2, 3, 8-11-09; Ord. No. 10-O-17, § 2, 2-23-10; Ord. No. 17-O-12, § 2, 2-28-17; Ord. No. 17-O-35, § 2, 4-11-17) 
Sec. 23-67.5. - Parking in loading zones. 
(a)  The location listed below is designated as a loading zone by the parking limitation, to be posted indicating fifteen-minute parking between 8:00 a.m. and 5:00 p.m., Monday through Friday: 
    Church Street, north side, from west line of the driveway at 124-130 East Church Street, covering one (1) parking space to the west. 
(b)  Any person, firm or corporation violating this section shall be fined not less than ten dollars ($10.00) nor more than five hundred dollars ($500.00) for each offense, and separate offenses shall be deemed committed for each and every fifteen-minute period during which a violation continues or exists. 
(Ord. No. 01-O-04, §§ 2, 3, 1-9-01) 
Sec. 23-68. - All-night parking. 
    When signs are erected at the entrances of highways into the village, on streets leading into subdivisions, or on streets that lead away from highways, giving notice thereof, no person shall park a vehicle for longer than thirty (30) minutes between the hours of 2:00 a.m. and 6:00 a.m. on any day, except physicians on calls. 
(Code 1977, § 41.5.5; Ord. No. 06-O-84, § 2, 9-12-06) 
Sec. 23-69. - Parking in alleys. 
    No person shall park a vehicle within an alley except for the purpose of loading and unloading merchandise and then in such a manner or under such conditions as to leave available no less than ten (10) feet of the width of the roadway for the free movement of vehicular traffic. No person shall stop, stand or park a vehicle within an alley in such a position as to block the driveway entrance to any abutting property. 
(Code 1977, § 41.5.6) 
Sec. 23-70. - No parkway parking. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person, firm or corporation to stop, stand or park a motor vehicle, on a public parkway in the village. The term "public parkway" is defined as the area between the curb or regularly traveled portion of a public street and the public sidewalk, if one exists, or the adjoining property line if there is no public sidewalk. This prohibition against parking on public parkways shall also prohibit parking on that portion of a driveway constructed over the public parkway. 
(b)  That any person, firm or corporation violating this section shall be fined not less than five dollars ($5.00) nor more than five hundred dollars ($500.00) for each offense, and separate offenses shall be deemed committed for each and every one-hour period during which a violation continues or exists. 
(Code 1977, § 41.5.7; Ord. No. 96-0-12, § 1, 3-14-96) 
Sec. 23-71. - Parking after snowstorms. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful to park any vehicle on any village street or highway when there is one (1) inch or more of unremoved snow on the street, for a period of twenty-four (24) hours, or until such time as the roadway has been cleared of snow. (exempts the C-1 downtown core commercial district) 
(b)  Any vehicle parked in any public street in violation of this section may be removed by the department of public works or the police department, or any employee thereof, to any other part of the village, as may best suit the convenience of the department or the employee making the removal. The owner of each vehicle so removed shall pay to the village the amount of the reasonable cost of such removal and of storage pending the redemption of same, and the village shall have the right to retain the vehicle until such payment is made. 
(Code 1977, § 41.5.9; Ord. No. 11-O-24, § 2, 3-22-11) 
Sec. 23-72. - Parking on private property. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to park any vehicle on private property within the village (regardless of whether the property is open to customer or public parking under limited circumstances or not), in violation of any rule, regulation or prohibition of the owner or other person having possessory control of such private property when such rule, regulation or prohibition is conspicuously posted upon the premises or when it otherwise constitutes a trespass. Proof of ownership of such vehicle found parked in violation of the provision hereof shall constitute prima facie evidence of a violation of this section by such owner which, however, shall be rebuttable by competent evidence. 
(Code 1977, § 41.5.13) 
Sec. 23-73. - Commuter parking facilities. 
(a)  The following regulations apply to the off-street commuter parking facilities operated by the village. This includes the lot adjacent to the south line of the Milwaukee Road right-of-way in the vicinity of Milwaukee Avenue and Lake Street in the village and other lots as designated by the board of trustees. 
(1)  Parking of vehicles shall be permitted on a fee basis with some spaces being leased for an annual fee paid in advance, and other spaces being available for a metered time period or daily fee. 
(2)  When signs are erected giving notice thereof it shall be unlawful to enter or leave the parking lots or to park in any manner contrary to such signs. 
(3)  It shall be and is hereby declared to be the duty of any person who shall park or permit the parking of any motor vehicle in any municipally maintained parking area to lock and secure the motor vehicle for the prevention of theft of the vehicle or its contents, and the village shall not be liable in the maintenance of such parking area to any person for loss or damage to any motor vehicle or contents of any motor vehicle placed in such parking area, nor for the injury to person or property arising from the use and maintenance of any such parking area. 
(4)  It shall be unlawful for any person to: 
a.  Back into any parking space within the designated lots. 
b.  Park any vehicle across any line or marking designating a parking space or in such a position that the vehicle shall not be entirely within the area so designated by such lines and markings. 
c.  Park any vehicle in other than a designated space. 
d.  Park in a manner so as to obstruct the normal movement of traffic within the lot. 
(5)  Except by special permission granted by the village, no parking shall be permitted between 2:00 a.m. and 4:00 a.m. 
(6)  The daily parking fee shall be as established by the annual fee ordinance. It shall be unlawful to park in a daily fee space for a period of longer than a calendar day without the payment of an additional fee in the amount established by the annual fee ordinance. 
(7)  The annual parking fee shall be as established by the annual fee ordinance. It shall be unlawful to park in an annual fee space without a permit evidencing payment of the annual fee affixed to the vehicle in a manner and in a location prescribed by the village board. Upon application for and payment of the annual fee, a permit shall be issued to the applicant therefor. The applicant shall identify the vehicle for which a permit is requested and the registered owner thereof. The annual parking permit shall only be affixed to the vehicle identified in the application pursuant to which such permit was issued and such vehicle must be registered in the name of the applicant or members of his immediate family then currently residing on a permanent basis with the applicant. It shall be unlawful for any person to affix an annual parking permit to a vehicle not identified in the application pursuant to which such permit was issued and for any annual parking permit recipient to give, sell, transfer or convey such permit for use, or to permit its use, on a vehicle not identified in the application pursuant to which such permit was issued. 
(8)  All fees collected shall be placed in a special commuter parking fund, separate and apart from all other funds, and shall be used exclusively to pay the operating and maintenance costs of providing this parking facility, including such items as rental of land, electricity, snow removal, salaries, and insurance. 
(9)  The village board may from time to time adopt such other rules that may be necessary for the safe and efficient operation of the parking lots. 
(b)  Any police officer is hereby authorized to remove or cause to be removed to a place of safety at the expense of the owner any unattended, abandoned or disabled vehicle left standing within a designated space for more than seventy-two (72) hours or any vehicle left standing in such a manner as to obstruct the normal movement of traffic within the lot. 
(c)  Within the municipal parking lot at the northeast corner of Milwaukee Avenue and Newberry Avenue, when properly posted by the director of public works, parking restrictions shall be designated as: 
(1)  North row, adjacent to the railroad tracks, thirty-seven (37) parking spaces, and north side of privately owned property at 704 North Milwaukee Avenue, eleven (11) parking spaces, shall be designated for daily fee commuter use with applicable fees as established in chapter 13 of the Libertyville Municipal Code. 
(2)  All remaining parking spaces of the municipal parking lot at the northeast corner of Milwaukee Avenue and Newberry Avenue shall be limited to combined uses of four-hour general parking and no time limit downtown employee parking when such vehicles display a valid downtown employee parking permit. 
(3)  Western half, west of the landscaped dividing strip, thirty-nine (39) parking spaces, shall be designated for daily fee commuter use with applicable fees as established in chapter 13 of the Libertyville Municipal Code, and such use shall be limited to use by residents of the Village of Libertyville. 
(d)  Penalty. Any person, firm or corporation violating this section shall be fined in accordance with section 13-171, schedule of permits, fees and licenses, and when applicable, subsection 23-67(e), limited parking, of the Municipal Code. 
(Code 1977, § 41.5.14(a)-(h), (j), (k); Ord. No. 92-0-23, §§ 3-5, 5-26-92; Ord. No. 09-O-70, § 2, 9-8-09; Ord. No. 10-0-06, § 2, 1-26-10) 
Sec. 23-74. - Employee and downtown resident permit parking. 
(a)  The village board may designate such place or places upon municipal parking areas and upon other areas owned or controlled by the village as employee or downtown resident parking spaces. Such designation shall be effective only after an appropriate sign, notice, signs or notices is or are installed or posted at such place or places stating "employee or downtown resident parking." 
(b)  The director of public works shall have markings painted or placed where employee and/or downtown resident parking is designated pursuant to provisions hereof, and shall cause signs or notices to be painted, installed or posted as herein contemplated. Such markings shall establish lines for each space within which vehicles are to be parked. It shall be unlawful to park any vehicle across any such line or markings or to park a vehicle in such a position that the vehicle shall not be entirely within the area so designated by such lines or markings. 
(c)  It shall be unlawful for any person to willfully impair any sign or notice painted, installed or posted under the provisions of this section or to in any way tamper with, willfully injure, break, destroy or impair any post, installation, surface or object upon which any such sign or notice is so painted, installed or posted. 
(d)  The employee and downtown resident parking permit fee shall be as established by the annual fee ordinance. It shall be unlawful to park in an employee or downtown resident parking space without a permit evidencing payment of the annual fee affixed to the vehicle in a manner and in a location prescribed by the village board, except as otherwise provided in subsections 23-74(e) and (f) below. Upon application for and payment of the annual fee, a permit shall be issued to the applicant thereof if the applicant is employed in the village or a resident of the C-1 district. For both employee and downtown resident permits, the applicant shall identify the vehicle for which a permit is requested, including vehicle description and license number. For employee permit parking, such application shall be made on the letterhead of the applicant's employer. For downtown resident permit parking, the application shall include evidence of C-1 district residency by means of a utility bill, driver's license, state identification card, vehicle registration card or other documentation deemed by the village board sufficient to establish such residency. Employee and downtown resident permits shall only be affixed to the vehicle identified in the application pursuant to which such permit was issued, and such vehicle must be registered in the name of the applicant or members of his or her immediate family then currently residing on a permanent basis with the applicant. It shall be unlawful for any reason to affix an employee or downtown resident parking permit to a vehicle not identified in the application pursuant to which such permit was issued or for any employee or downtown resident parking permit recipient to give, sell, transfer or convey such permit for use, or to permit its use, on a vehicle not identified in the application pursuant to which such permit was issued. 
(e)  If any place designated by the village board as employee and/or downtown resident permit parking pursuant to subsection 23-74(a) above is additionally designated by the village board, pursuant to section 23-67 of this Code, as time limited parking, then (1) a vehicle bearing an employee or downtown resident parking permit issued pursuant to this section shall be exempt from the time limitations imposed upon such place, and no others, from 8:00 a.m. to 5:00 p.m. Monday through Saturday; and (2) a vehicle without an employee or downtown resident parking permit affixed thereto may, subject to the provisions of section 23-67 of this Code, park in such place for not longer than the designated times. 
(f)  If any place upon public streets and thoroughfares is designated by the village board, pursuant to section 23-67 of this Code, as time limited parking, the village may exempt vehicles bearing employee or downtown resident parking permits from the time limitations imposed pursuant to section 23-67 of this Code upon such place by additionally designating such place as employee and/or downtown resident permit parking; provided, however, that the exemption from the time limitations shall apply only from 8:00 a.m. to 5:00 p.m., Monday through Saturday; and provided further, however, that a vehicle without an employee or downtown resident parking permit affixed thereto may, subject to the provisions of section 23-67 of this Code, park in such place for not longer than the designated time. 
(g)  Vehicles bearing a valid downtown resident parking permit may park in posted two-hour, three-hour or four-hour parking spaces located within the parking lots designated as M-1 and M-2 of the Libertyville Comprehensive Plan without time limitations. 
(Ord. No. 95-0-13, § 3, 3-14-95; Ord. No. 99-O-44, § 4, 5-11-99; Ord. No. 06-O-05, § 2, 1-10-06) 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 95-0-13, § 3, adopted Mar. 14, 1995, added § 23-74, and renumbered former § 23-74 as § 23-75. 
Sec. 23-75. - Student permit parking. 
(a)  The village board may designate such place or places upon municipal parking areas and upon other areas owned or controlled by the village as student parking places. Such designation shall be effective only after an appropriate sign, notice, signs or notices is or are installed or posted at such place or places stating "Student Parking." 
(b)  The director of public works shall have markings painted or placed where student parking is designated pursuant to provisions hereof, and shall cause signs or notices to be painted, installed or posted as herein contemplated. Such markings shall establish lines for each space within which vehicles are to be parked. It shall be unlawful to park any vehicle across any such line or markings or to park a vehicle in such a position that the vehicle shall not be entirely within the area so designated by such lines or markings. 
(c)  It shall be unlawful for any person to wilfully impair any sign or notice painted, installed or posted under the provisions of this section or to in any way tamper with, wilfully injure, break, destroy or impair any post, installation, surface or object upon which any such sign or notice is so painted, installed or posted. 
(d)  The student parking permit fee shall be as established by the annual fee ordinance. It shall be unlawful to park in a student permit parking space from 7:00 a.m. to 2:00 p.m. on school days without a permit evidencing payment of the annual fee affixed to the vehicle in a manner and in a location prescribed by the village board. Upon application for and payment of the annual fee, a permit shall be issued to the applicant therefor if the applicant is enrolled in Libertyville High School during the year for which the student parking permit is issued. The applicant shall identify the vehicle for which a permit is requested, including vehicle description and license number, on the letterhead of Libertyville High School District. The student parking permit shall be affixed to the vehicle identified in the application pursuant to which such permit was issued and such vehicle must be registered in the name of the applicant or members of his or her immediate family then currently residing on a permanent basis with the applicant. It shall be unlawful for any person to affix a student parking permit to a vehicle not identified in the application pursuant to which such permit was issued and for any student parking permit recipient to give, sell, transfer or convey such permit for use, or to permit its use, on a vehicle not identified in the application pursuant to which such permit was issued. 
(Ord. No. 95-0-54, § 3, 8-22-95)

Sec. 23-77. - Authority to designate through highways, stop and yield intersections, one-way streets, and to place traffic control devices. 
(a)  The village board may designate through highways or may designate any intersection as a stop intersection or a yield intersection or may designate one-way streets and alleys and may place and maintain such traffic control devices and signs as are required to indicate and carry out the provisions of this chapter or to regulate, warn or guide traffic, all of the foregoing subject to the limitations of 625 ILCS 5/11-301 through 5/11-304. No such designation shall become effective unless and until appropriate signs are posted to show all through, stop and yield right-of-way streets, all one-way streets and alleys, and all stop intersections. 
(b)  The streets set forth in Schedule I attached hereto are hereby established and designated as one-way stop intersections. The streets set forth in Schedule II attached hereto are hereby established and designated as two-way stop intersections. The streets set forth in Schedule III attached hereto are hereby established and designated as three-way stop intersections. The streets set forth in Schedule IV attached hereto are hereby established and designated as four-way stop intersections. The streets set forth in Schedule V attached hereto are hereby established and designated as five-way stop intersections. The streets set forth in Schedule VI attached hereto are hereby established and designated as yield right-of-way intersections. The streets set forth in Schedule VII attached hereto are hereby established and designated as one-way streets.

Sec. 23-78. - No passing and parking zones. 
(a)  The village board is authorized to determine those portions of any highway under its jurisdiction where overtaking and passing or driving to the left of the roadway would be especially hazardous, or where a lane to the right of the roadway should be set aside for exclusive use as a parking lane and not for overtaking and passing or driving, and may, by appropriate signs or marking on the roadway, indicate the beginning and end of such no passing or parking zones. When such signs or markings are in place and clearly visible to an ordinarily observant person, every driver of a vehicle shall obey the directions thereof. 
(b)  Except as otherwise indicated in this section, where signs or markings are in place to define a no-passing or a parking zone as set forth in paragraph (a), no driver may at any time drive on the left side of the roadway within the no-passing zone or on the left side of any pavement striping designed to mark such no-passing zone throughout its length, nor may a driver at any time drive to the right of the roadway in a parking lane within the parking zone or on the right side of any pavement striping designed to mark such parking zone throughout its length. 
(c)  The pavement striping designed to mark the no-passing zone may be crossed (i) from the left-hand lane for the purpose of completing a pass that was begun prior to the beginning of the zone in the driver's direction of travel, (ii) when making a left turn into or from an alley, private road or driveway when such movement can be made with safety, or (iii) when an obstruction exists making it necessary to drive to the left of the center of the roadway; provided, any person so doing shall yield the right-of-way to all vehicles traveling in the proper direction upon the unobstructed portion of the roadway within such distance as to constitute an immediate hazard. 
(d)  The pavement striping designed to mark the parking zone may be crossed (i) from the parking lane for the purpose of completing a pass that was begun prior to the beginning of the zone in the driver's direction of travel, (ii) when making a left or right turn into or from an alley, private road or driveway when such movement can be made with safety, (iii) from the right-hand lane for the purpose of entering the parking lane to park when such movement can be made with safety, or (iv) from the parking lane for the purpose of merging into traffic in the direction being traveled by vehicles on the right side of the roadway when such movement can be made with safety. 
(Code 1977, § 41.2.35(a)2.; Ord. No. 93-0-33, § 3, 7-14-93) 
Sec. 23-79. - Residential parking zones. 
(a)  Definitions. 
    Guest vehicle: Vehicle parked in an established residential parking area while the operator is a guest of a household in the same parking area. 
    Nonresident vehicle: Parked vehicle, which is not owned or leased by person(s) residing within a specific residential area. 
    Residential area: Areas designated R-1 through R-9 by the official zoning map of the village. 
    Resident vehicle: Vehicle owned/leased by resident of a residential parking area, when parked in same residential parking area, and bearing valid village vehicle license/tax. 
    Residential parking area: A street parking area designated and posted to preserve parking spaces for residents of the immediate area and their guests. 
(b)  Residential streets may be posted. Establishment of a residential parking area may be recommended to the village president and board of trustees, providing written notice of the village board meeting has been provided to each affected household at least fifteen (15) days prior to the meeting, 
(1)  When fifty (50) percent or more of the households of an affected area petition the village for resident parking and village staff has completed a parking survey. If the survey discovers a period of two (2) hours or more when fifty (50) percent or more of available parking is utilized, and half or more of the parked vehicles are classified as nonresident vehicles, the area may be recommended for RESIDENT PARKING ONLY - PERMIT REQUIRED. Such posting will indicate hours of day and days of week, if applicable. 
(2)  The survey may be omitted and the affected area recommended for RESIDENT PARKING ONLY - PERMIT REQUIRED, following petition by fifty (50) percent or more of households of the affected area, and upon the unanimous recommendation of the village administrator, director of public works, director of planning and zoning and chief of police, if delaying action to conduct the survey would result in substantial or unusual hardship to the households of the affected street. 
(c)  Residential parking permits: 
(1)  The police department will issue one (1) residential parking permit at no cost for each vehicle registered by state license to a household in the affected area. The owner or lessee of each vehicle must demonstrate proof of residency and proper display of a valid village vehicle license/tax. Such permit will contain a code limiting the permit for use in one (1) residential area only, and will be valid during an annual period from May 1 through April 30. Such permits will be displayed on resident vehicles in the lower left corner of the rear most vehicle window or on the left rear vehicle window. 
(2)  Each household in the affected area will be issued two (2) paper guest cards, to be placed on the dashboard of guest vehicle while parking in the residential zone. Guest cards will contain a code limiting the permit for use in one (1) residential area only. Residents are not limited in numbers of guests, and are encouraged to notify the police department when additional guests park in the residential area to avoid unnecessary enforcement. 
(3)  It shall be unlawful to transfer residential parking permits to persons not residing in the affected area. Possession of a residential parking permit does not relieve the owner from compliance with other existing parking regulations. 
(d)  Parking in residential parking areas: 
(1)  It shall be unlawful for any person to park a vehicle in an area posted RESIDENT PARKING ONLY - PERMIT REQUIRED, unless the vehicle displays a valid resident parking permit or guest card. However, vehicles delivering good or services to households in the affected area may park for the length of time necessary to deliver the goods or services. Additional guest vehicles may be parked in the residential parking area when the police department is notified. 
(2)  It shall be unlawful for any person to use a resident parking permit or guest card to provide vehicle parking for mass transportation commuters, customers or persons commuting to local employment. 
(e)  Removal. On direction of the village administrator, residential parking areas may be eliminated when conditions no longer warrant such restrictions. Residential parking restrictions in a previously established area shall be considered void when signs posting such restrictions are removed by the village. 
(f)  [Fine.] The minimum fine for violation of any section of this section shall be twenty-five dollars ($25.00). 
(g)  Residential parking areas established. 
(1)  A residential parking area is established on East Ellis Avenue, on the east side, from the south curb of Winchester Road to a point two hundred sixty-two (262) feet to the south, on East Ellis Avenue, both sides, from the east limit of East Ellis Avenue to a point one thousand one hundred fifty-one (1,151) feet to the west. 
(Ord. No. 98-O-05, §§ 2-8, 1-13-98) 
Sec. 23-80. - Parking limitations during special events. 
(a)  NO PARKING signs may be temporarily or permanently posted on streets adjacent to Libertyville High School or Butterfield School when necessary to reduce risks to pedestrians, vehicular traffic and emergency vehicles. 
(b)  Temporary no parking zones shall be in effect beginning one (1) hour prior, and ending one (1) hour following the duration of the special event requiring parking control. 
(c)  Temporary parking signs shall have the same force and effect as permanently posted NO PARKING signs. 
(d)  The following streets are considered adjacent to Libertyville High School for purposes of parking control during special events: 
Acorn Lane Garfield Avenue Ames Street Gracewood Drive Arbor Court Havenwood Drive Blueberry Road Homewood Drive Burdick Street Jackson Avenue Burridge Court Lange Court Carter Avenue Laurel Avenue Cook Avenue Lincoln Avenue Dawes Street Linden Lane Douglas Avenue Maple Avenue Drake Street McKinley Avenue Dymond Road Pond Ridge Road Elm Court Rockland Road Elm Drive Stewart Avenue Florence Court Sunset Drive Forest Lane West Street  
(e)  The following streets are considered adjacent to Butterfield School for purposes of parking control during special events: 
Lake Street Quaker Hill Lane Springhaven Drive Windhaven Road  
(Ord. No. 00-O-44, § 2, 8-22-00; Ord. No. 01-O-68, § 3, 12-11-01) 
Sec. 23-81. - Parking of commercial vehicles in downtown west parking lot. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for vehicles making commercial deliveries to enter or park such vehicles in the area known as the downtown west parking lot for the purpose of making such deliveries between the hours of 11:00 a.m. and 1:00 p.m. any day of the week. The downtown west parking lot is defined as that area to the rear of businesses using addresses ranging from 501-633 N. Milwaukee Avenue and 101-150 Lake Street. 
    The prohibition set forth in this section shall not apply to vehicles registered to the United States Postal Service or other similar "parcel" delivery companies. 
(b)  Any person, firm or corporation violating this section shall be fined not less than ten dollars ($10.00) nor more than five hundred dollars ($500.00) for each offense, and separate offenses shall be deemed committed for each and every fifteen-minute period during which a violation continues or exists. 
(Ord. No. 11-O-50, § 2, 7-26-11) 
Secs. 23-82-23-90. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE V. - BICYCLES[3] 

Footnotes: 
--- (3) --- 
State Law reference- Bicycles generally, 625 ILCS 5/11-1301 et seq.; authority to register, license and regulate bicycles, 625 ILCS 5/11-208(a)(8). 

Sec. 23-91. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Bicycle means a light vehicle with two (2) or three (3) wheels, with solid or pneumatic tires, having a steering system and a saddle seat or seats, and propelled by the feet acting on treadles connected to cranks or levers. Conveyances designed for assisting transportation of handicapped persons are not included within this definition. 
    Chief of police means the chief of police, or any member of the police department designated by the chief of police to act in his place and stead. 
    Dealer in bicycles means any person engaged in the sale of bicycles at retail or wholesale. 
    Licensee means any person who procures from the village clerk a license plate for a bicycle, together with a registration card accompanying the plate. 
    Rental agency means any person engaged in the business of offering for rental and renting bicycles for use by the public. 
(Code 1977, § 42.1; Ord. No. 91-0-10, § 1, 2-26-91; Ord. No. 97-O-63, § 2, 8-12-97) 
Cross reference- Definitions and rules of construction generally, § 1-2. 
Sec. 23-92. - License. 
(a)  Required. Every owner of a bicycle, except a dealer in bicycles, who resides within the village shall obtain from the police department a bicycle license for each bicycle owned. 
(b)  Procedure. An application for a bicycle license shall be in writing. Each bicycle license issued shall remain in force so long as the licensee continuously remains the owner thereof, but shall expire immediately upon the sale or other transfer of such bicycle by such licensee. 
(c)  Fee. The fee for each bicycle license shall be as established by the annual fee ordinance. 
(d)  License emblems. Every person who procures a bicycle license shall receive an adhesive license emblem with distinguishing number. The license shall be attached to a clear and unobstructed location on the bicycle. The police department shall maintain a record of the date of issue of each license, to whom issued, the number thereof, and the number of the bicycle frame. 
(e)  Transfer. In case of the sale or other transfer by the licensee of any bicycle hereunder to a new owner who resides within the village, the new owner shall procure a license under this section for such bicycle within ten (10) days after such sale or other transfer. 
(Code 1977, § 42.2; Ord. No. 83-0-9, § 1, 5-17-83; Ord. No. 91-0-10, § 1, 2-26-91; Ord. No. 97-O-63, § 3, 8-12-97) 
Sec. 23-93. - Inspection. 
    The chief of police shall inspect each bicycle previous to the issuance of a license therefor, and he may refuse to approve any bicycle which is not equipped as required by this article or by law, or is otherwise in an unsafe condition. 
(Code 1977, § 42.3; Ord. No. 91-0-10, § 1, 2-26-91) 
Sec. 23-94. - Serial numbers. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person, willfully or maliciously, to remove, destroy, mutilate or alter the number of any bicycle frame of a bicycle licensed pursuant to this article, or to remove, destroy, mutilate or alter any license plate or registration card during the time for which the license plate or registration card is in force. This article does not prohibit the chief of police from stamping, in a distinguishing manner, numbers on the frame of a bicycle upon which no serial number can be found, or upon which the serial number is illegible or insufficient for identification purposes. 
(Code 1977, § 42.4; Ord. No. 91-0-10, § 1, 2-26-91) 
Sec. 23-95. - Sale or transfer. 
    Within ten (10) days after the sale or transfer of a licensed bicycle, the licensee thereof shall report to the chief of police the sale or transfer and the name and address of the purchaser or transferee, and shall surrender to the chief of police his registration card and license plate. 
(Code 1977, § 42.5; Ord. No. 91-0-10, § 1, 2-26-91) 
Sec. 23-96. - Rental agencies. 
    Bicycles offered for rent by a rental agency shall be equipped by the rental agency with the lights and other safety equipment required by this article or by law, and shall be kept in good and safe working order. Rental agencies shall comply, in all respects, with all of the provisions of this article, including the obtaining of a license for each rental bicycle, and they shall be responsible for the condition of the bicycles they rent. The chief of police shall make periodical inspections of rental agencies to ascertain that they are complying with the provisions of this article. 
(Code 1977, § 42.6; Ord. No. 91-0-10, § 1, 2-26-91) 
Sec. 23-97. - Suspension and revocation of licenses, impounding bicycles. 
    The chief of police is empowered to administer the provisions of this article. The chief of police is empowered to suspend for a period not to exceed thirty (30) days or revoke any license issued under the provisions of this article, for any violation thereof, or of any of the ordinances of the village relating to street traffic, insofar as they are applicable, and to impound for a period not to exceed thirty (30) days any unregistered or improperly registered bicycle or the bicycle of any person who violates any of the provisions of this article or of the ordinances of the village relating to street traffic, insofar as they are applicable. The action of the chief of police in suspending or revoking any license, or impounding a bicycle, as provided in this section, shall be conclusive and final. The suspension or revocation of a license or the impounding of a bicycle shall not preclude the infliction of any other penalties provided herein, upon the licensee whose license is suspended or revoked or the person whose bicycle is impounded. 
(Code 1977, § 42.7; Ord. No. 91-0-10, § 1, 2-26-91) 
Sec. 23-98. - Applicability of traffic laws. 
    Every person riding a bicycle upon a roadway shall be granted all of the rights and shall be subject to all of the duties applicable to the driver of a motor vehicle by the laws of this state declaring rules of the road applicable to vehicles, or by the traffic ordinances of this village applicable to a driver of a vehicle, except as to those provisions of laws and ordinances which be their nature can have no application. 
(Ord. No. 97-O-63, § 4, 8-12-97) 
Sec. 23-99. - Parental responsibility. 
    The parent or guardian of any child shall not authorize or knowingly permit any such child to violate any of the provisions of this chapter applicable to bicycles. 
(Ord. No. 97-O-63, § 4, 8-12-97) 
Sec. 23-100. - Special pedestrian area. 
    When so designated by sign indicating NO BICYCLE RIDING, it shall be unlawful for any person, except specially trained and uniformed police bicycle patrol officers, to operate a bicycle in the downtown area adjacent to Milwaukee Avenue, in the portion between Broadway Street and Lake Street, and in the area adjacent to Lake Street, in the portion between Brainerd Avenue and Milwaukee Avenue, including the buildings and grounds of properties immediately adjacent to the designated section of Milwaukee Avenue and Lake Street. Bicycles may be walked through the special pedestrian area, and may be parked only at locations designated for bicycle parking. 
(Ord. No. 97-O-63, § 4, 8-12-97; Ord. No. 98-O-63, § 2, 7-28-98; Ord. No. 10-O-65, § 2, 7-13-10) 
Sec. 23-101. - Bicycle safety. 
    The chief of police shall direct police officers to periodically conduct educational programs and offer incentives to youths wearing appropriate helmets and safety equipment while bicycling. 
(Ord. No. 97-O-63, § 4, 8-12-97) 
Secs. 23-102-23-115. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE VI. - SKATEBOARD PIPES AND RAMPS 

Sec. 23-116. - Purpose. 
    It has been determined that the unregulated construction and use of skateboard pipes or ramps in the village can be detrimental to the health, safety and welfare of residents of the village, and that regulation of these ramps is therefore essential. 
(Ord. No. 91-0-10, § 1, 2-26-91) 
Sec. 23-117. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Height means the vertical height of a skateboard pipe or ramp measured from the established natural grade to the highest point on the pipe or ramp. 
    Setback means the minimum distance between a specified lot line, measured along a straight line and at a right angle to such lot line, and the nearest point of any skateboard pipe or ramp. 
    Skateboard pipe or ramp means any outdoor structure, whether or not permanently affixed to the ground, that has a semicircular or semioval shape and that is intended or used to permit persons on skateboards or roller skates to move continuously from one side to the other or any other outdoor structure, whether or not permanently affixed to the ground, that has one or more surfaces designed, intended or used to permit persons on skateboards or roller skates to jump, to accelerate, to decelerate or to change directions. 
(Ord. No. 91-0-10, § 1, 2-26-91) 
Cross reference- Definitions and rules of construction generally, § 1-2. 
Sec. 23-118. - Applicability; compliance. 
    The provisions of this article shall apply to all skateboard pipes and ramps located in the village, whether constructed, erected, placed or maintained before or after the effective date of this article (February 28, 1991); provided, however, that in the case of any skateboard pipe or ramp in existence on February 28, 1991, the owner of such skateboard pipe or ramp and the owner of the zoning lot on which such skateboard pipe or ramp is located shall have a period of twelve (12) months from the effective date of this article either to remove such skateboard pipe or ramp or to bring it into compliance with the requirements of this article. 
(Ord. No. 91-0-10, § 1, 2-26-91) 
Sec. 23-119. - Restrictions on use on public property. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to erect, place or use a skateboard pipe or ramp on any public street, sidewalk, right-of-way, park or other public property or to skate onto any public property by means of momentum obtained by the use of any skateboard pipe or ramp. 
(Ord. No. 91-0-10, § 1, 2-26-91) 
Sec. 23-120. - Restrictions and requirements-Generally. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful to charge, receive or give any consideration for the use of any skateboard pipe or ramp. 
(b)  No more than one person shall use any skateboard pipe or ramp at any one (1) time. 
(c)  No skateboard pipe or ramp shall be used before 12:00 noon on any Sunday or before 9:00 a.m. on any other day. No skateboard pipe or ramp shall be used after 9:00 p.m. or sunset, whichever comes first, on any day. 
(Ord. No. 91-0-10, § 1, 2-26-91) 
Sec. 23-121. - Same-Private property. 
(a)  No skateboard pipe or ramp shall be located in any nonresidential zoning district. No more than one (1) skateboard pipe or ramp shall be permitted on any residential zoning lot. 
(b)  Skateboard pipes and ramps having a maximum height of three (3) feet or less shall be permitted in all residential zoning districts and shall not require a building permit. Every such skateboard pipe or ramp shall be set back at least fifteen (15) feet from every lot line. 
(c)  Skateboard pipes and ramps in excess of three (3) feet in height shall require a building permit and shall be permitted only in the following residential zoning districts and only in accordance with the following requirements: 
Residential 
zoning 
district Maximum height 
permitted Minimum 
setback 
required R-4 4 5 times height R-3 5 5 times height R-2 6 5 times height R-1 6 5 times height  
(d)  No skateboard pipe or ramp shall be located in any front yard, in any exterior side yard on a corner lot, in the front half of any lot, in any easement, or in violation of any building line. 
(e)  The area of land covered by a skateboard pipe or ramp shall be counted as lot coverage as required in each residential zoning district. 
(f)  The widest or longest dimension of every skateboard pipe or ramp shall face the dwelling unit on the zoning lot where such skateboard pipe or ramp is located and every portion of every skateboard pipe or ramp shall be closer to the dwelling unit on the zoning lot where such skateboard pipe or ramp is located than to any lot line of such zoning lot. There shall be a fire separation of at least ten (10) feet between every skateboard pipe or ramp and every dwelling unit. 
(g)  No skateboard pipe or ramp shall be wider than two (2) times the height of such skateboard pipe or ramp, measured by outside dimensions. 
(h)  No skateboard pipe or ramp shall be longer than three (3) times the height of such skateboard pipe or ramp, measured by outside dimensions. 
(i)  No materials or equipment of any kind shall be placed, kept or stored under the framework or structure of any skateboard pipe or ramp. 
(j)  Every skateboard pipe or ramp that exceeds three (3) feet in height shall be constructed in accordance with recognized engineering standards, including, but not limited to, materials, connectors, dead loads, live loads and impact loads. 
(k)  All structural members of every skateboard pipe or ramp that exceeds three (3) feet in height shall be enclosed with solid exterior walls made of the same material as the rolling deck of such skateboard pipe or ramp and such walls shall be insulated with sound-deafening insulation, type R-13, to reduce noise generated by the use of such skateboard pipe or ramp. 
(Ord. No. 91-0-10, § 1, 2-26-91) 
Secs. 23-122-23-129. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE VII. - SKATEBOARDS AND ROLLER SKATES 

Sec. 23-130. - Regulations for persons on roller skates and skateboards. 
    No person shall roller skate or ride upon a skateboard in the village in violation of the following regulations: 
(a)  Any person on roller skates or skateboard on a roadway shall obey the instruction of official traffic signals and signs unless otherwise directed by a police officers or community service officer. 
(b)  No person on roller skates or skateboard on the roadway shall operate in a reckless manner. 
(c)  Every person on roller skates or skateboard on a roadway shall ride as near as possible to the right-hand side of the roadway and exercise due care when passing a standing or parked vehicle. 
(d)  A person on roller skates or skateboard shall yield the right-of-way to any pedestrian. 
(e)  No person on roller skates or skateboard shall attach himself to any moving motor vehicle. 
(Ord. No. 97-O-63, § 5, 8-12-97) 
Sec. 23-131. - Prohibition of roller skates and skateboards. 
    No person shall operate roller skates or skateboard upon any private street, parking lot or other area open to the public within any area zoned as a business district under the zoning ordinance of the village, or upon any street, sidewalk or other open space within any area owned by the village and designated as a NO SKATEBOARD/NO ROLLER SKATE AREA. The village administrator will designate or rescind such areas according to public interest or nuisance level. 
(Ord. No. 97-O-63, § 5, 8-12-97) 
Sec. 23-132. - Parental responsibility. 
    The parent or guardian of any child shall not authorize or knowingly permit any such child to violate any of the provisions of this article. 
(Ord. No. 97-O-63, § 5, 8-12-97) 
Sec. 23-133. - Roller skating and skateboarding safety education. 
    The chief of police shall direct police officers to periodically conduct educational programs and offer incentives to youths found to be wearing appropriate safety equipment while roller skating or skateboarding. 
(Ord. No. 97-O-63, § 5, 8-12-97) 
Chapter 24 - VEHICLES FOR HIRE[1] 
  
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference- Licenses, taxation and miscellaneous business regulations, Ch. 13; traffic, Ch. 23. 
State Law reference- Power to license, tax and regulate vehicles for hire, 65 ILCS 5/11-42-6. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Secs. 24-1-24-25. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - TAXICABS 
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 24-26. - Definition. 
    For the purposes of this article, the term "taxicab" means any motor vehicle used or kept for use in the transportation of passengers for hire, except: 
(1)  Any vehicle operating under special agreement, ordinance or franchise of the village. 
(2)  State-licensed motor vehicles for the transportation of passengers or freight over a specific route which is repeated periodically. 
(3)  Motor vehicles rented by special contract and operated primarily for the benefit of the customer renting the vehicle and not for the purpose of transporting passengers for hire. 
(4)  Motor vehicles equipped to transport in excess of eight (8) passengers for hire. 
(5)  Motor vehicles discharging passengers for hire accepted for transportation from outside the corporate limits of the village where no roof light or other light on the vehicle indicates that the vehicle is for hire and a white card bearing the words "Not for Hire" printed in block letters not less than two (2) inches in height is displayed at the windshield of such vehicle. 
(6)  Motor vehicles transporting passengers for hire where such service is conducted through communication by the passenger to a fixed place of business, without the use of taximeters, cab stands or the initiation of passenger service on an en route basis, the service being limited to the transportation of passengers for hire at a fixed rate determined in advance. 
(Code 1977, § 23.2; Ord. No. 87-0-6, § 1, 2-10-87) 
Cross reference- Definitions and rules of construction generally, § 1-2. 
Sec. 24-27. - Vehicles generally. 
(a)  No taxicab shall be operated unless it bears a duly issued state license. No such cab shall be operated unless it is equipped with proper brakes, lights, tires, horns, mufflers, rear vision mirror and windshield wipers in good condition. It shall be the duty of the chief of police to inspect every taxicab so licensed as may be necessary to see to the enforcement of the provisions of this section. Such inspection shall be made by having the vehicle complete a state inspection at least twice per year, every six (6) months after issuance of the license. Every taxicab that is inspected pursuant to this section and passes such inspection shall promptly display a certificate or seal supplied by the village. The cost for such seal shall be as established by the annual fee ordinance and shall be paid by the taxicab license holder upon receipt of the seal from the village.
